questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to the ER with a history of a head injury following an RTA. CT head revealed a displaced fracture of the floor of the middle cranial fossa involving the pterygoid canal. Which of the following nerves are susceptible to injury?

choices.text: Lesser petrosal nerve and greater petrosal nerve
Greater petrosal nerve and deep petrosal nerve
Greater petrosal nerve and chorda tympani
Lesser petrosal nerve and deep petrosal nerve

questions.solution:
The involvement of the pterygoid canal can injure the vidian nerve, which is formed by:

  • Postganglionic sympathetic fibres of the deep petrosal nerve
  • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres of the greater petrosal nerve

Pterygoid canal (Vidian canal):

  • The pterygoid canal, also known as the Vidian canal, is a foramen in the base of the skull, located in the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone, superior to the pterygoid plates, and inferomedial to the foramen rotundum. It transmits the Vidian artery and Vidian nerve from the middle cranial fossa to the pterygopalatine fossa 
  • It transmits the artery, nerve, and vein of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve and Vidian artery) into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • The vidian nerve contains the preganglionic fibers of the pterygopalatine ganglion, which provide the secretomotor supply to the nasal mucous glands. Hence vidian neurectomy is indicated in vasomotor rhinitis and intractable rhinnorrhea which is refractory to other treatments.

questions.text:
A mother brings her 9-month-old baby to the immunization clinic. The baby is scheduled to receive the booster dose of his Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV 13). Which of the following statements are true about the vaccine in question?
  1. Includes the capsular polysaccharide of 13 serotypes of S. pneumoniae 
  2. Revaccination is not recommended after an anaphylactic reaction to the 1st dose
  3. The vaccine should be stored at <2 °C and kept frozen
  4. HIV-positive children benefit from a booster dose
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are true.

Pneumococcal vaccines include:

  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV): 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23)

The Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13: It includes purified capsular polysaccharides of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. Both PCV10 and PCV13 are preservative-free and their recommended storage temperature is 2-8°C. The vaccine must not be frozen.

WHO recommends 3 primary doses or 2 primary doses plus one booster of the PCV vaccine. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9-12 months.

Mild reactions like erythema and tenderness may occur, but systemic reactions are not known to occur. Revaccination is not recommended for those who had an anaphylactic reaction to the initial dose.

Regardless of the presence of underlying medical conditions (e.g., children with HIV infection, sickle cell disease, or who are otherwise immunocompromised), PCV should be given according to the national schedule. PCV is safe and well-tolerated among HIV-infected children. Children with HIV infection require a booster dose to sustain protection.

When primary immunization is initiated with one of these vaccines, it is recommended that the remaining doses are administered with the same product. WHO recommends the inclusion of PCVs in childhood immunization programs worldwide. 

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23: It contains polysaccharide antigen from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria and is available for adults and children over 2 years of age. Children under 2 years of age and immunocompromised individuals do not respond well to the vaccine. It is recommended for selected groups such as:

  • Post splenectomy
  • Sickle-cell disease
  • Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney
  • Generalized malignancies
  • Organ transplants

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge,  sinusitis, and chronic suppurative otitis media is scheduled for adenoidectomy. Which of the following is a contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The presence of a cleft palate is a contraindication for adenoidectomy. 

Performing an adenoidectomy in a patient with a cleft palate can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency, a disorder of the velopharyngeal valve. The function of this valve is to separate the oral and nasal cavities during actions like speaking, swallowing, vomiting, blowing, and sucking. Velopharyngeal insufficiency leads to reduced speech intelligence as well as social and functional impairment. Patients have hypernasal speech, compensatory facial grimacing, and misarticulation.  

Indications for adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy
  2. Recurrent sinusitis (Option A)
  3. Chronic otitis media (Option B) 
  4. Chronic suppurative otitis media and recurrent ear discharge
  5. Dental malocclusion (Option D) occurring due to a low-positioned tongue, and separated lips. 

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract

questions.text: During your community medicine postings, each student is assigned a family in the neighboring district for evaluating various social, economic, and health parameters. You were asked to grade the families according to the modified Kuppuswamy’s socioeconomic status scale. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this scale?

choices.text: Kuppuswamy scale does not include housing
This scale can be used for both rural and urban areas
There are 5 socio-economic classes according to this scale
Monthly income of the family is taken into consideration in this scale

questions.solution:
The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas and not in rural areas. 

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family 
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family 

Each of the components is assigned a score. It is then classified into socio-economic classes based on the total score as follows:

Socio-economic class Total Score
I Upper 26-29
II Upper-middle 16-25
III Lower-middle 11-15
IV Upper-lower 05-10
V Lower <5

Note:

  • Uday Pareek scale should be used for those in rural areas. 
  • BG Prasad scale can be used in both urban and rural areas.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: Which of the following is not a secondary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
A pustule is not a secondary skin lesion. It is a primary skin lesion. 

A pustule refers to a circumscribed lesion containing purulent material, that may occur within a pilosebaceous follicle, a sweat duct, or on glabrous skin. Pustules usually occur due to infections.

The image below shows circumscribed purulent lesion, suggestive of a pustule.

Other options:

Option A- Crusts are secondary skin lesions that consist of dried serum and other exudates. They can be yellow due to serous material or red due to blood. 

The following image shows dried exudate seen as yellow crusts on the chin in impetigo.

Option B- Erosion refers to the loss of the epidermis without loss of the dermis. It heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister. It is a secondary skin lesion.

The following image shows the erosions on the thumb, index, and middle finger with loss of the epidermis.

Option D- Ulcer refers to a loss of dermis and epidermis, often with the loss of underlying tissues. It is a secondary skin lesion.

The following image shows an ulcer on the dorsum of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Primary and Secondary Lesions of Skin

Primary lesions of the skin include:

  • Papule
  • Plaque
  • Wheal
  • Vesicle
  • Bulla
  • Nodule
  • Macule
  • Patch
  • Purpura
  • Pustule

For mnemonic lovers, the following mnemonic might help!

'Predatory Poisonous Wasps Viciously Bit on the Nose of My Patient causing Purulent Pus'

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

Mnemonic- 'LEAF SUCKS water'

  • L — Lichenification
  • E — Erosion / Excoriation
  • A — Atrophy
  • F — Fissure
  • S — Scale
  • U — Ulcer
  • C — Crust
  • K — Kind-of-hard to feel (Induration)
  • S — Scar

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is hyper-alert with normal EEG. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes, mydriatic pupil, and clonus.  What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
According to Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a hyperalert neonate with mydriatic pupil, hyperactive tendon reflex, clonus, and normal EEG belongs to stage 1. 

HIE is a brain injury that prevents adequate blood supply to the infant's brain. 

Sarnat staging of HIE:

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity

Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress it; otherwise, can remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits

Maternal causes for HIE are hypoventilation during anesthesia, cyanotic heart disease, respiratory failure, or carbon monoxide poisoning. Failure of oxygenation due to severe anemia, massive blood loss, and intracranial or adrenal hemorrhages are fetal causes of HIE. 

Hypoxia and ischemia cause anaerobic metabolism that generates a large amount of lactate and inorganic phosphates accumulation of toxic byproducts and overactivation of receptors. This leads to increased cellular permeability to sodium and calcium ions, resulting in cytotoxic edema and neuronal death. The most sensitive imaging modality for detecting hypoxic brain injury in neonates is an MRI.

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures. 

 Poor prognostic factors in HIE are:

  • Initial blood ph less than 6.7
  • Low (0-3) 10  in Apgar score
  • Delayed onset of spontaneous breathing
  • Seizure onset in less than 12 hours
  • Burst suppression pattern in EEG
  • Basal ganglia or thalamic lesion
  • Oliguria or anurias for more than 24 hours
  • Decerebrate posture

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ovarian follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding.

 Ovarian follicular cysts are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage, or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, ulcer, or cervical carcinoma.
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: An autopsy of a victim who sustained a revolver gun injury is being done. On examination of the entry wound, there is tattooing. However, there is no burning, no singeing of hair, and no blackening. What is the likely distance between the gun and the victim?
questions.solution:
The likely distance between the gun and the victim is 30-50 cm.

When the distance between the firing and the victim is between 30-50 cm (in the case of pistols and revolvers), it is a near-shot wound. The victim is within the range of powder deposition, so there is some amount of tattooing present. But it is outside the range of flame, so there will not be any burning or singeing. There will not be any blackening, as it is outside the range of smoke as well.

To determine the range of firing, the following parameters are used:

  • Entry wound size and shape
  • Blast effect – Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
  • Injuries related to firearms

The injuries related to firearms are:

  • Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing. It is seen in contact shot wounds or distances up to 5-8 cm. Singeing of hair is caused due to burns
  • Blackening - occurs due to the deposit of smoke. It can be removed with a wet cloth. This can be seen up to around 15 cm of firing
  • Tattooing - occurs due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • Greasing and collaring - occur due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues, during its penetration. It can be found in contact, near-shot, or distant shot wounds. 

Other options:

Option B: In a firm contact shot the imprint of the muzzle of the gun is seen on the skin around the wound. The victim is within the range of flame, hence singeing of the hair will be present. Tattooing begins only when the muzzle to target distance is >1cm, like in a loose contact shot.

Option C: When the distance between the victim and firing is 5-8cm, it is called a close shot. The victim is within the range of the flame, hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition will be seen. Singeing, burning, blackening and tattooing will be present.

Option D: When the distance between the victim and firing is >50 cm, it is a distant shot. The victim lies outside the range of flame and powder deposition. Hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition are absent. Burning, blackening, and tattooing are absent.

Contact shot:

This is a contact gunshot entrance wound. Since the barrel contacts the skin, the gases released by the fired round go into the subcutaneous tissue and cause the star-shaped laceration. Note also the grey-black discoloration from the soot, as well as the faint abrasion ring.

Close shot:

  • The wound has been washed and there is stippling. This indicates a close-range gunshot wound because both stippling and fouling are present.

Distant shot:

  • Distant range entrance gunshot wound with eccentric abrasion rim.

questions.text:
Which of the following indices are used to determine the sex of an individual?
  1. Intermembral index
  2. Sternal index
  3. Corporobasal sacral index
  4. Ischiopubic index
  5. Cephalic index
questions.solution:
Sternal index, corporobasal sacral index, and ischiopubic index are used to determine the sex of the individual.

The intermembral index and cephalic index are helpful in determining the race of the individual.

Indices for sex determination: 

Indices Calculation (x100) Male Female
Ischiopubic index Length of pubis/Length of ischium <90 >95
Corporobasal index Transverse diameter of body of S1 / Breadth of base of sacrum 40-50 35-45
Sciatic notch index Maximum breadth of greater sciatic notch / Maximum depth of greater sciatic notch 4-5 5-6
Sacral index Transverse diameter of base of sacrum / Length of sacrum <114 >114
Sternal index Length of manubrium / Length of mesosternum 32-85 44-80

 

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

questions.text: A 30-year old male patient presents with complaints of frequent, long-standing respiratory tract infections. He is a known case of cystic fibrosis. Which among the given organisms is more commonly implicated in such patients?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues. In this condition, due to the CFTR protein defect, there is thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to these factors, P. aeruginosa can cause chronic infection/colonization of the respiratory tract in patients of CF.

A complex bacterial flora that includes Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is routinely cultured from CF sputum. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility.

The GIF below shows swarming motility seen in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

The image given below shows green coloured colonies of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on a nutrient agar.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Burns infections
  • Opportunistic and nosocomial infections
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Stenotrophomonas maltophila, formerly called Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen that causes wound infection, urinary tract infection, and septicemia. It is sensitive to cotrimoxazole.

Option B: Burkholderia pseudomallei, formerly called Pseudomonas pseudomallei, is the causative agent of melioidosis, a disease that can manifest as acute septicemia, pneumonia, hemoptysis resembling tuberculosis, or a chronic form with abscess formation in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, bones, and internal organs.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia, formerly called Pseudomonas cepacia, is an opportunistic pathogen that causes fatal necrotizing pneumonia.

Stenotrophomonas maltophila, Burkholderia pseudomallei, Burkholderia cepacia infections have also been found to be associated with CF. However, among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections are more commonly seen in such patients.

questions.text: The image given below shows a dermatological manifestation of
questions.solution:
The given image shows rheumatoid nodules characteristically seen along the ulnar border of the forearm. They are one of the dermatological manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the most common form of chronic inflammatory arthritis. RA is a systemic disease with a variety of extra-articular manifestations like fatigue, dermatological manifestations, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities.

The incidence of RA is more between 25 and 55 years of age. Patients typically present with early morning joint stiffness lasting more than 1 hour and eases with physical activity. The earliest involved joints are the small joints of the hands and feet.

Dermatological manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis include:

  • Rheumatoid neutrophilic dermatosis: Symmetrical erythematous nodules and plaques on the dorsal aspects of the hands and arms, extensor aspects of the joints, and back of the neck, scalp, and trunk. They are sometimes tender, and ulceration and vesiculation may occur. Histologically, there is a dense diffuse infiltrate of neutrophils in the dermis.
  • Vascular lesions include small infarcts around the nails, sometimes at the apex of small cutaneous nodules.
  • Leg ulcers due to venous insufficiency, trauma, pressure, or arterial insufficiency.
  • Linear subcutaneous bands and interstitial granulomatous dermatitis may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus generally presents typically as symmetrical, slightly scaling erythema of the face and neck. Erythema of the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms may also be seen.

Option B: The cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis generally include a facial rash, eyelid erythema and edema, nail fold changes, Gottron’s papules, extensor surface dermatosis, scalp erythema, and hair loss.

Option C: Scleroderma is characterized by varying degrees of sclerosis, fibrosis, and atrophy in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Skin induration, calcinosis cutis, telangiectasia, hyperpigmentation, and xerosis are some dermatological manifestations.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nucleus lies under the elevation of the marked area?
questions.solution:
The elevation marked in the image, in the lowermost area of the rhomboid fossa away from the striae medullaris is known as the vagal trigone. The vagal nucleus is present beneath the vagal trigone.

The given image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped or rhomboid-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves V to XII. The fourth ventricle is continuous with the cerebral aqueduct cranially and the central canal of the spinal cord caudally.

The fourth ventricular floor is divided into superior and inferior halves by the striae medullaris. The superior triangular half is limited laterally by the superior cerebellar peduncles. The inferior triangular half is limited caudally by the gracile and cuneate tubercles that form the dorsal column. The floor is divided vertically into two halves by a longitudinal sulcus called the median sulcus. Each vertical half is further divided by the sulcus limitans to form the medial eminence and the lateral vestibular area.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (rhomboid fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullaris divide the floor into superior and inferior halves.

Medial to lateral in upper triangular part:

  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence contain the facial colliculus coiled around the abducens nucleus.
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area contains the vestibular nucleus

Sulcus limitans forms:

  • The bluish-colored area at the uppermost end of sulcus limitans denotes the underlying locus coeruleus
  • Superior fovea: A small depression between the facial colliculus and the vestibular area
  • Inferior fovea: lateral limit of sulcus limitans

Lower triangular part:

  • Hypoglossal trigone: represents the medial eminence in the lower triangle. It consists of the hypoglossal nucleus.
  • Vagal trigone: Is present caudal to the hypoglossal triangle consisting of the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve
  • Funiculus separans: A narrow translucent ridge that is present caudal to the vagal trigone. It is separated from the gracile tubercle by the small area postrema separating it from the vagal trigone.

The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the superior and inferior medullary veli. 

Given below are a schematic and clinical specimen depicting the structures present in the floor of the fourth ventricle:

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twin babies of gestational ages differing by a few weeks. On detailed evaluation, it was noted that the disparity in gestational age of babies was due to fertilization of 2 different ova released in 2 different menstrual cycles. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above phenomenon is known as superfetation. It occurs when there is fertilization of 2 different ova released in different menstrual cycles. The consequence is two children are born at the same time and one of them might be mature while another might be immature.

Ovulation usually stops with the onset of pregnancy, but in a few individuals, ovulation may be possible till the first trimester, after which the decidual cavity is obliterated. The fertilization of the newly released ovum in a woman who is already pregnant may take place following coitus. 

Other options:

Option A: Superfecundation is the fertilization of 2 different ova in the same menstrual cycle by separate acts of coitus. Heteropaternal superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may raise doubts regarding adultery and infidelity. 

Option C: A supposititious child is also known as a fictitious child. In such cases, a woman pretends to be pregnant and substitutes a living child as her own, or may substitute a male child for her female child, or abortion. This is done to claim property. This can be identified by verifying the signs of pregnancy and delivery in the woman and by DNA fingerprinting.

Option D: Atavism is the reappearance of a characteristic in an individual after several generations of absence. For example, the child may not resemble his parents but resembles his grandparents. This is attributed to the recombination of genes.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of pigmentation on her face as shown in the image. She says that this has been present for one year and there was no pigmentation prior to that. On examination, it appears flat with an irregular border. Which statement among the following accurately describes her condition?

choices.text: It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus
It is most aggressive variant of malignant melanoma
It is most common melanoma in darker-skinned patients

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is lentigo maligna melanoma.

Lentigo maligna melanoma (Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle) is a variant of malignant melanoma that occurs most commonly in the sun-exposed areas such as the face, neck, forearms. It is more commonly seen in elderly females than males. It starts as a flat, dark, variably pigmented lesion with irregular borders as shown in the image. It develops slowly over months and years. It has less malignant potential as they take a longer time to attain the vertical growth phase.

Other options:

Option A- Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant of malignant melanoma. It is more commonly seen on the trunk and proximal extremities. It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus after a chronic period of change in color and border. It presents as an atypical nevus that progressively becomes irregular in shape and appears in shades of brown, black, grey, red as well as depigmented areas. It undergoes rapid growth a few months before presentation. They later develop a vertical growth phase resulting in nodule formation that may bleed or ulcerate. 

Below is the image showing the dermoscopy of superficial spreading melanoma. 

Option B- Nodular melanoma is the most aggressive variant of malignant melanoma. They arise de novo in the skin and are more common in men than women. They can occur anywhere on the body but are usually found on the trunk, head, or neck. They present as symmetrical, elevated, dome-shaped polypoid or pedunculated lesions as shown below. They lack a horizontal growth phase and have a poor prognosis.

Below is the image showing nodular melanoma.

Option D- Acral lentiginous melanoma is the most common melanoma in darker-skinned patients. It is usually seen in people above 60 years of age. It occurs in subungual areas beneath the fingernails, toenails, palms of hands, and soles of feet. It presents as a flat, irregular macule often described as a 'dirty-like stain' as shown below. 

Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clue towards the diagnosis of subungual melanoma. It is characterized by the extension of the irregular pigmentation to the proximal or lateral nail fold as shown below:

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: What is the most important support of the pelvic viscera?
questions.solution:
The most important support of the pelvic viscera is the levator ani muscle. The levator ani forms a large portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles:

  • Pubococcygeus
  • Puborectalis
  • Iliococcygeus

Supports of the genital organs are given by DeLancey's levels of support. However, the broad ligament is a fold of the peritoneum, which doesn't provide support to pelvic organs. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: A technetium-99 m scan of a 3-year-old boy with Meckel's diverticulum is given below. Identify the false statement regarding this imaging modality in the given condition.

choices.text: Detects the presence of ectopic gastric tissue
Less sensitive for diagnosis in adults
CT is the most accurate investigation for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding imaging modalities in Merkel's diverticulum is- CT is the most accurate for diagnosis in Meckel's diverticulum. Sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel's diverticula in children.

Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally but may present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Diagnosis of Meckel’s diverticulum:

In the absence of bleeding, Meckel’s diverticula are rarely diagnosed prior to the time of surgical intervention. Plain abdominal X-ray, CT, and ultrasonography are rarely helpful in the diagnosis. 

Radionuclide scans like the 99mTc-pertechnetate accurately detect the presence of ectopic gastric mucosa. In children who present with bleeding, ectopic gastric mucosa is found in the majority of the cases. Hence, the most accurate diagnostic test in children. It is less accurate in adults. 

The sensitivity of the scan can be improved by H2-receptor antagonists like cimetidine. It leads to a higher concentration of radionucleotide in the wall of the diverticulum.

Angiography may be used to locate the site of bleeding in acute hemorrhage. The presence of a persistent vitelline artery is diagnostic.

questions.text: An obstetrician decided to allow vaginal delivery for a multiparous woman at 37 weeks of gestation in labor with the presentation seen in the image below.  Which of the following is not performed when delivering a baby with this presentation?

choices.text: Keep the fetus with back anteriorly
Traction to aid in the delivery of the head

questions.solution:
The baby is in flexed breech position. Traction to aid in the delivery of the head should not be performed in assisted breech delivery. This will cause entrapment of the head and cause nuchal displacement of arms. 

Breech presentation is when the buttocks are the presenting part of the fetus during labor. The fetus can be in complete breech where they are in full flexion. In incomplete breech, the lower limb is extended at the tights or the knees. 

Ideally, the fetus should be in vertex (head) presentation as the breech presentation can lead to complications for both mother and child. 

Breech delivery can be carried out vaginally provided the following criteria are met:

  • Fetal weight should be between 1.5 - 3.5kg. 
  • The fetal head should be flexed
  • The pelvis should be adequate
  • The mother has no medical or obstetric complications
  • Facility for cesarean section is available
  • Labor can be continuously monitored
  • Obstetrician has experience in vaginal breech delivery
  • Informed consent has been obtained from the mother.

Ultimately, it is the obstetrician's decision between cesarean and normal vaginal delivery based on their experience. 

The following are required for assisted breech delivery: 

  • Anesthesia
  • Assistant to provide fundal pressure during contraction (Option A)
  • Episiotomy materials
  • Obstetric forceps for the aftercoming head if required
  • Neonatologist

It is important to remember that assisted breach should not be rushed, the fetus should not be pulled but can be pushed from above, and that the fetus should be positioned with the back anteriorly (Option B).

The Mauriceau-Smellie-Viet maneuver is performed to avoid hyperextension of the fetal neck (Option C). Here, the index and middle fingers of one hand are positioned over the maxilla of the fetus in order to flex the head. Meanwhile, the rest of the body rests on the palm and forearm of the same hand. Two fingers of the other hand grasp the shoulders by hooking over the fetal neck. Downward traction is applied until the suboccipital region of the fetus is visible below the symphysis. Gentle suprapubic pressure can also be applied at the same time to assist in maintaining head flexion.  The obstetrician then elevates the fetal body towards the mother's abdomen which allows the occiput to emerge over the perineum. This method avoids hyperextension of the neck.

The following image shows the Mauriceau-Smellie-Viet maneuver. 

The image below shows various types of breech presentations.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A man who had undergone an exploratory laparotomy 6 months ago came for a follow-up visit. Which of the following statements about healed incision is false?

choices.text: Disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines
Strength of the scar is in their weave rather than in their amount
By the first week it is held by sutures and a weak type 3 collagen matrix
Tensile strength is about 60-80% of normal skin by  3 months

questions.solution:
During the first week, a surgical wound has minimal inherent strength because the dermal edges are held together solely by a hemostatic plug and sutures.

During the second postoperative week, fibroblasts proliferate rapidly and begin to produce type I collagen in addition to type III. The strength of the wound is still limited to less than 10% of its final strength. By week 6, the concentration of strong collagen fibers begins to resemble that of intact skin.

As the collagen matures and becomes denser, the scar becomes almost acellular as the fibroblasts and blood vessels reduce.The disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines with their strength being in their weave rather than in their amount.

Most of these changes occur over the first three months but a scar will continue to mature for 1 to 2 years. Tensile strength will continue to increase but would not be expected to exceed 60–80% of that of normal skin.

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student is testing the muscle labeled X in the given cadaveric image. He remembers studying that the muscle can be easily palpated when the forearm is semi-pronated and flexed against resistance. What is the nerve supply of the given muscle?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked X is identified as the brachioradialis and it is innervated by the radial nerve.

The radial nerve is the largest branch of the brachial plexus arising from the posterior cord. Its root values are C5, 6, 7, 8, and occasionally T1. 

Brachioradialis is the most superficial muscle present on the radial side of the flexor aspect of the forearm. It forms the lateral border of the cubital fossa. 

Origin - Proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and the anterior surface of the lateral intermuscular septum.

Insertion - It ends as a flat tendon inserted on the lateral side of the distal end of the radius, proximal to the styloid process. 

Innervation - Radial nerve (C5 and C6 ) before its division above the lateral epicondyle.

Relations - The radial nerve lies in the groove between the brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus laterally and brachialis medially. The radial artery is present on its ulnar side.

Vascular supply- Radial recurrent artery. In the distal part of the muscle, it is also supplied by the radial collateral branch of the profounda brachii and radial artery.

Actions- Brachioradialis is a powerful flexor of the elbow, acting most strongly with the forearm in mid-pronation; hence, it can be tested when the semi-pronated forearm is flexed against resistance.

The image given below shows the various muscles on the flexor aspect of the forearm.

The illustration given below depicts the course and muscle innervation of radial nerve.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent endoscopic evaluation. The biopsy image is shown below. Which of the following drugs is not used in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Warthin silver starry stained biopsy specimen, diagnostic for Helicobacter pylori. Sucralfate does not have any anti-H. pylori action and is not used in the treatment of H. pylori gastritis.

Option A: Metronidazole is used in the triple, quadruple therapy, and sequential therapy regimens. 

Option B: Proton pump inhibitors significantly enhance the effectiveness of regimens containing amoxicillin or clarithromycin.

Option D: Bismuth compounds have significant anti-bacterial action and are given in quadruple therapy.

Two or three antimicrobials are combined in regimens that range from 10-14 days. Monotherapy is not recommended due to the development of resistance.

questions.text: The mask given below is preferred in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a venturi mask and it is preferred in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

There is hypoventilation in patients with COPD and they require greater FiO2 than those provided by low-flow devices. Thus, they are ideal candidates for the use of a Venturi mask. The Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle to deliver a predetermined and fixed concentration of oxygen to the patient that is based on the size of the constriction present in the device. A fixed oxygen concentration is delivered irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern as it provides a higher gas flow than the peak inspiratory flow rate.

In the Venturi mask system, oxygen inflow is connected to a specific color-coded entrainment device at the base of the mask that provides a set Fio2 at a set oxygen inflow rate. The range provided by different devices is Fio2 of 0.24 to 0.5, oxygen inflow of 4 to 15 l/min, and the total flow delivered 35 to 45 l/min.

Disadvantages: Caution should be exercised when handling the mask as there can be an increase in the delivered FiO2 when the air entrainment ports are obstructed by the patient’s hands, bed sheets, or water condensate.

In cases of carbon monoxide inhalation, myocardial infarction, and trauma victims, non-rebreathing masks are preferred as they provide minimum oxygen flows of 10-15L/min which are required in cases of hypoxemia, but with normal respiratory efforts.

Below is an image of a non-rebreathing mask:

questions.text: A 13-month-old child was brought with an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 10 minutes, following a fever of 100.4°F.  There is no history of any prior unprovoked seizures. Which of the following is not a major risk factor for the recurrence of the above condition?

choices.text: Age of child less than 1 year

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 13-month-old child presenting with generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 10 minutes associated with high-grade fever in a neurologically healthy child is suggestive of febrile seizure. A family history of epilepsy is not a major risk factor for the recurrence of febrile seizures.

A family history of epilepsy is a minor risk factor for the recurrence of febrile seizures. 

Risk factors for the recurrence of febrile seizures:

Major:

  • Age less than 1 year
  • Duration of fever less than 24 hours (short duration of fever before the onset of febrile seizure)
  • Fever range: 38–39 °C (100.4–102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Low serum sodium level at the time of presentation

Having no risk factors carries a recurrence risk of around 12%.

Febrile seizures are seizures associated with a high-grade fever (more than 100.4°F). They occur between the age of 6 months to 5 years, without underlying intracranial infections or prior unprovoked seizures. 

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged (>15 min)
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent within 24 hours
Chances of going into epilepsy are 1% Chances of going into epilepsy are 6%

Simple febrile seizures will occur only once within 24 hours of the onset of fever in a neurologically normal child. Lumbar puncture should be performed at the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age (to exclude meningitis).

Electroencephalogram and neuroimaging are advised for children with risk factors for epilepsy or neurological abnormalities.

During acute episodes, intravenous lorazepam and midazolam are used for the termination of seizures if they last more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes.

If the episodes of febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1 mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode can be used as intermittent prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with a history of impaired vision and severe photophobia. On examination, he has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue eyes. A disorder due to deficiency in the enzyme tyrosinase is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism. 

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterised by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase further acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. 

Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. 

Other options-

Option B- Tyrosinemia type 1 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical findings include cirrhosis, liver failure, rickets, failure to thrive, peripheral neuropathy, and boiled cabbage odour. 

Option C- Tyrosinemia type 2 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability. 

Option D- Homocystinuria is caused due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Clinical findings include lens dislocation, thrombotic vascular disease, intellectual disability, and osteoporosis.

Given below is an image of a young child with OCA showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient came with complaints of fever, multiple joint pain, generalized weakness, and pruritus for a few days. His laboratory test results are given below. Which of the following combination of drugs is the most appropriate for the above condition?

HCV RNA: Positive

IgG anti-HCV: Positive
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and blood investigations showing the presence of HCV RNA and IgG anti-HCV are suggestive of chronic hepatitis C. Among the given options, the combination of sofosbuvir and velpatasvir would be the most appropriate for chronic hepatitis C. 

The goal of treatment is to eradicate HCV RNA during the therapy and to document that the virus remains undetectable for at least 12 weeks after completion of therapy. This is known as a sustained virological response at 12 weeks (SVR12). The combination of Sofosbuvir (polymerase inhibitor) and Velpatasvir (NS5A inhibitor) has now been approved as the first-line treatment of hepatitis C genotypes 1-6, irrespective of whether or not the patient has previously received any treatment or has cirrhosis. Any patient with chronic hepatitis C who has detectable HCV RNA in the serum, irrespective of ALT/AST levels, is a candidate for this treatment. 

Sofosbuvir-ribavirin combination is inferior to sofosbuvir-velpatasvir drug combination therapy. Other options are not used in hepatitis C management.

Related Pearl: Direct acting antivirals (DAA) - Drugs against Hepatitis-C virus

The directly acting antivirals used in the treatment of Hepatitis C infection include:

Mechanism of action 

Example

NS5A inhibitors (asvir)
  • Velpatasvir
  • Daclatasvir
  • Ledipasvir
  • Ombitasvir
  • Elbasvir

NS5B nucleos(t)ide polymerase inhibitor (buvir)
  • Sofosbuvir

NS5B non nucleos(t)ide polymerase inhibitor (buvir)
  • Dasabuvir
  • Beclabuvir

NS3/4A inhibitors (previr)
  • Boceprevir
  • Telaprevir
  • Simeprevir
  • Paritaprevir
  • Asunaprevir
  • Grazoprevir

 The following combinations of antiviral drugs can be used:

  • Acute, chronic hepatitis, or compensated cirrhosis:
    • Velpatasvir (NS5A Inhibitor) + Sofosbuvir (NS5B inhibitor) x 12 weeks.
  • Decompensated cirrhosis:
    • Velpatasvir (NS5A Inhibitor) + Sofosbuvir (NS5B inhibitor) + Ribavirin (syntheticnucleotide analogue) x 12 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the last 5 months. The pain is relieved after defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis of diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome is considered. Which of the following opioid drugs has been approved for treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
The opioid drug approved for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome(IBS) is eluxadoline.

Eluxadoline is an opioid agonist that acts on μ-receptors. On oral administration, it acts on gut opioid receptor and causes slow colonic movement and increased fecal fluid absorption. FDA has approved eluxadoline in patients with diarrhea-predominant IBS. The adverse effects include constipation, sphincter of Oddi spasm leading to abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and elevated pancreatic enzymes or liver enzymes. Therefore eluxadoline should not be used in patients with a history of pancreatitis, alcoholism, or sphincter of Oddi disease.

Other drugs used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS are:

  • Alosetron
  • Rifaximin
  • Loperamide

Other options:

Option B- Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral mu-opioid receptor (MOR) antagonist and has been approved for opioid-induced constipation. 

Option C- Naloxegol is a peripheral MOR antagonist. It does not cross the blood-brain barrier. It is approved in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation.

Option D- Alvimopan like methylnaltrexone and naloxegol is a peripheral MOR antagonist. It decreases intestinal transit time and improves defecation. It has been approved to shorten the time of postoperative ileus. 

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a history of bony pain, abdominal cramps, and nausea. She has previously been treated twice for renal calculi. An X-ray revealed the findings shown below. Which of the following is not a characteristic association of this condition?

choices.text: Brown tumours due to excessive osteoclast activity
Cupping and splaying of the metaphysis
Salt and pepper appearance of the skull

questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image points to a brown tumor which is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism. The feature that is not seen in this condition is the cupping and splaying of the metaphysis.

Brown tumors (Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica)

Brown tumors are cystic bone lesions that occur due to excessive osteoclast activity (Option A). Histologically, a collection of osteoclasts and fibrous tissue with accompanying necrosis and hemorrhagic liquefaction is seen. Radiographically, they are seen as multiloculated cysts that may cause the expansion of bones.

Other radiological features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • The classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism is sub-periosteal cortical resorption (Option C) on the radial side of the middle phalanges, seen especially in the second and third fingers. This feature can also be visualized in the lateral end of the clavicle and symphysis pubis. 
  • Loss of lamina dura, the thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as a thin white line
  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull (Option D) with well-marked stippling of pin head size

The given X-ray of the skull shows multiple radiolucent lytic lesions which are typical of the salt and pepper appearance of the skull seen in hyperparathyroidism. 

  • Chondrocalcinosis on the hand (triangular ligament), the knees (articular cartilage and menisci), and the symphysis pubis.
  • Osteoporosis is seen as reduced radiodensity of the bone- especially in elderly and postmenopausal women.

Note- Cupping and splaying of the metaphysis is a classical feature of rickets that occurs due to deficiency of vitamin D. Some other findings include craniotabes, broadening of long bones, genu valgum, Rachitic rosary, and Harrison's sulcus.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

   ↓/N ↑/N     ↓/N   N

 ↑: Increased,  ↓: Decreased, N: Normal

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A cross-sectional study was conducted among a group of 600 individuals. 200 individuals were diseased, and out of this, 160 were identified correctly by a screening test. Among the 400 normal individuals, 320 were identified correctly as negative for the disease. Calculate the positive likelihood ratio of the above test.
questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio of the above screening test is 4.

The positive likelihood ratio deals with the likelihood of a patient having the disease obtaining a positive test result. This is used to assess how good a diagnostic test is and helps in selecting an appropriate diagnostic test for a specific disease.

It is the ratio of the true positive rate to the false-positive rate

Positive likelihood ratio = sensitivity / (1-specificity)

In the above scenario:

  Diseased individuals Normal individuals
Test positive 160 (TP) 80  (FP)
Test negative 40   (FN) 320 (TN)

TP: True positive

FP: False positive

TN: True negative

FN: False negative

Using the above values, we get the sensitivity and specificity.

  • Sensitivity= TP/TP+FN = 160/200
  • Specificity= TN/FP+TN = 320/400

Therefore, positive likelihood ratio= sensitivity/ 1- specificity

= [160/200]/ [1-(320/400)] = 4

Note:

The negative likelihood ratio deals with the likelihood of a patient having the disease and obtaining a negative test result.

Negative likelihood ratio = (1- sensitivity) /specificity.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. She gives a history of the consumption of red wine. She was on selegiline for treatment of Parkinsonism. On examination, her BP is 200/110mmHg. Which of the following drugs is preferred for treating hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction and phentolamine is the preferred drug for treating hypertension in this patient.

Tyramine is a sympathomimetic amine. In patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (selegiline), when they consume tyramine-rich foods like cheese, aged meat, red wine, fish, etc, the amine does not undergo degradation along the intestinal walls and liver and reaches the circulations. These amines release large amounts of catecholamines in the adrenergic nerve endings.

Therefore the patients will present with hypertension, agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, etc. This will be followed by hypotension and coma.

Patients should be managed symptomatically by cooling, use of antipyretics, fluid administration, etc. This hypertensive crisis is treated with short-acting drugs like phentolamine.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • clonidine withdrawal
  • short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist with irreversible action. Short-acting drugs are used to manage hypertension in cheese reactions because long-acting drugs will worsen the hypotensive phase that follows a hypertensive crisis. It is used pre-operatively to reduce blood pressure in pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. Catecholamines act on alpha 1 and alpha 2 receptors that result in vasoconstriction. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect). So, using phentolamine is better as it is a non-selective alpha-receptor antagonist. Prazosin has been used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It can worsen hypertensive crisis by unopposed alpha stimulation. It is used in various conditions like essential hypertension, pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, etc.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

 

Drugs

Contraindications

Beta-blockers

 Labetalol, esmolol, metoprolol

Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia

Calcium channel blockers

Clevidipine, nicardipine

Advanced aortic stenosis 

D1 receptor agonist

 Fenoldopam

Caution in glaucoma

Vasodilators

 

 

Nitroglycerin

 Pericardial tamponade

Nitroprusside

 Relatively contraindicated in liver failure and renal failure 

Hydralazine

  CAD, RHD

ACE inhibitors

Enalaprilat

 History of angioedema

Alpha-blocker

Phentolamine, Urapidil

  Aortic stenosis, AV shunt

Centrally acting sympatholytics

Clonidine

 Severe AV block, sick-sinus syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea. On investigations, multiple ulcers were seen in proximal, distal duodenum and jejunum. The gastric pH was found to be 1.2 with a basal acid output of 30 mEq/hr. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is gastrinoma.

The above clinical scenario of abdominal pain, diarrhea with multiple ulcers in the proximal, distal duodenum and jejunum and the gastric ph of 1.5 with a basal acid output of 30 mEq/hr are suggestive of gastrinoma.

Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern. Gastrinoma is most commonly located in the gastrinoma triangle (Passaro's triangle) bounded by the lines connecting the:

  • cystic duct
  • the junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum
  • the junction between the neck and body of the pancreas

The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). Duodenal ulcers are the most common. Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Diagnosis: 

The gastric pH <2, basal acid output >15 mEq/hr and serum gastrin concentration more than 1000 pg/ml (normal is <100 pg/ml) confirms the diagnosis of gastrinoma. When the diagnosis is in doubt (like gastrin levels 100-1000 pg/ml), then a secretin test is performed. Secretin test is considered positive when serum gastrin levels are more than 200 pg/ml on secretin administration and confirms the diagnosis of gastrinoma.

For localization of the tumor for surgical management, CT or MRI scans should be done first. If the tumor is not localized on these scans, then somatostatin receptor scintigraphy or endoscopic ultrasound are done for better localization.

Treatment: 

Medical- The primary goal is to reduce gastric acid secretion and relieve the symptoms. Proton pump inhibitors and octreotide are given to control the acid hypersecretion. In cases of metastatic gastrinomas, systemic chemotherapy comprising of streptozocin in combination with 5-fluorouracil or doxorubicin is given.

Surgical- In pancreatic gastrinomas, enucleation with peripancreatic lymph node dissection is the procedure of choice. In duodenal gastrinomas, enucleation with the overlying mucosa is done for tumors <5 cm and enucleation with full-thickness excision of the duodenal wall is done for tumors >5 cm.

Other options:

Option A- Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. They are characterized by symptoms of hypoglycemia, low plasma glucose at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms on glucose consumption. This is known as the Whipple's triad. C peptide levels of more than 1.2 μg/ml with a glucose level of <40 mg/dl are highly suggestive of insulinoma. The gold standard for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fast.

Option B- Somatostatinoma is also a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor characterized by steatorrhea, diabetes mellitus, hypochlorhydria, and gallstones. A fasting plasma somatostatin level >160 pg/ml is indicative of somatostatinoma.

Option D- Glucagonoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and depression. The characteristic skin lesion of necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, depletion of the fat and protein stores and vitamin deficiencies are seen. A fasting glucagon level of >1000 pg/ml is considered to be diagnostic of glucagonoma. 

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Syringoma is a benign tumor of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Syringoma is a benign tumor of the sweat ducts. 

It mostly appears during adolescence, usually in females. It consists of small dermal papules, that may be yellow in color or transluscent and cystic. They have a variable size ranging from 1-5mm. They may resemble milia. 

Syringomas usually are distributed bilaterally and symmetrically. They generally affect the front of the chest, face, and neck. 

The lesions are benign and are only treated for cosmetic reasons. Diathermy and carbon dioxide laser may be performed. However, diathermy has better cosmetic results while those treated with carbon dioxide laser recur. 

Syringoma is also known as

  • Hidradenomes eruptifs
  • Syringocystadenoma
  • Syringocystoma

Option A - Sebaceous adenomas are benign tumors of the sebaceous glands. They appear as yellow, smooth, circumscribed papules or nodules. They may be present on the face, scalp, and neck. 

Option C - Melanocytic nevi are benign tumors of melanocytes. They can be congenital or acquired. They have a varied presentation from even pigmentation to an array of colors. They should be differentiated from melanomas. 

Option D - Lipomas are benign tumors of adipocytes. They are slow-growing, rubbery nodules with a firm consistency. They usually occur on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and axillae.

questions.text: A schematic representation of the development of various vessels of the head and neck is given below. Identify the marked segment from which the internal carotid artery develops?
questions.solution:
The internal carotid arteries develop from the segment marked "1" depicting the third arch artery distal to the origin of the carotid bud along with the dorsal aorta cranial to the attachment of the third arch artery.

The fate of pharyngeal arch arteries:

The first arteries to appear in the embryo are the right and left primitive aortae which are continuous with the two endocardial heart tubes. The primitive aortae consist of three parts:

  1. Ventral aorta - A portion lying ventral to the foregut. 

  2. An arched portion lying in the first pharyngeal arch.

  3. Dorsal aorta - A dorsal portion lying dorsal to the gut.

With the fusion of the two endocardial tubes, the two ventral aortae partially fuse to form the aortic sac, the unfused parts remain as the right and left horns of the sac. Successive arterial arches now appear in the second to sixth pharyngeal arches, each being connected ventrally to the right or left horn of the aortic sac and dorsally to the dorsal aorta. The first pharyngeal arch artery disappears and in adult life is represented by the maxillary artery and the second arch artery persists for some part of fetal life as the stapedial artery. The fifth arch artery also disappears leaving only the 3rd, 4th, and the 6th arch arteries connecting the dorsal and ventral aortae. The two dorsal aortae on either side grow cranially beyond the point of attachment of the first artery. 

A carotid bud develops on the 3rd arch artery which eventually forms the external carotid artery. The part of the 3rd arch artery proximal to the carotid bud forms the common carotid artery. The internal carotid artery is formed by the 3rd arch artery distal to the origin of the carotid bud along with the dorsal aorta cranial to the attachment of the 3rd arch artery.

Other options:

Option A - The segment marked '2' depicts the formation of the external carotid artery as explained above.

Option C - The segment marked '4' depicts the formation of the aortic arch. The arch of the aorta is derived from the ventral part of the aortic sac, its left horn, and the left fourth arch artery till the left dorsal aortic arch.

Option D - The segment marked '3' depicts the formation of the proximal part of the right subclavian artery. The proximal part of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right fourth arch artery. The remaining part is derived from a portion of the right dorsal aorta and the seventh intersegmental artery.

The derivatives of various aortic arches are given below:

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman from a rural area registered in the scheme shown below. Which of the following benefits would she receive under this scheme?

choices.text: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 homebased newborn care visits
Free checkup on 9th of every month

questions.solution:
The above image shows the logo of Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

PMSMA aims to improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services. This is undertaken as part of the reproductive maternal neonatal child and adolescent health (RMNCH+A) strategy. Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Other options:

Option A: A cash incentive of 5000 rupees is provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) for the first living child of the family. This is subject to fulfillment of specific conditions.

Option B: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits are provided under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative for women and newborns where assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare is provided free of cost.  It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

Option D: A cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who underwent an institutional delivery in low-performing states under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). This scheme is launched under NRHM (national rural health mission) to promote institutional delivery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed with high-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland. The patient is posted for radical parotidectomy. All of the following structures are removed except:
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid is not removed in radical parotidectomy.

Radical parotidectomy is indicated in patients with histological evidence of high-grade malignant tumors (mucoepidermoid tumor, squamous cell carcinoma) with facial nerve involvement. Low-grade malignant tumors are usually managed by superficial parotidectomy.

The structures removed in radical parotidectomy are:

  • The whole parotid gland
  • Dissection through the main trunk of the facial nerve
  • Ipsilateral masseter muscle
  • Neck node dissection of clinical, cytological and radiological lymph node metastases.

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

Location

Frequency of tumor

Submandibular

Uncommon

Sublingual

Very rare
