90%

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with foreign body sensation, irritation, and blurring of vision in his left eye for a few weeks. On examination, the finding as shown below is seen. Which of the following is the most effective treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching on the cornea from the nasal side are suggestive of pterygium. Conjunctival limbal autograft is the most effective treatment of pterygium.

In conjunctival limbal autografting, a piece of conjunctival tissue is taken from the limbus on the same side or from the other eye for grafting. This prevents recurrence. Autograft is retained with help of sutures or fibrin glue or with the patient's serum.

A pterygium is a degenerative and hyperplastic condition. The subconjunctival tissue undergoes elastotic degeneration and proliferates as vascularised tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye.

It is predominantly seen in elder males who do outdoor work. UV radiation is one of the important risk factors. Patients may be asymptomatic or present with foreign body sensations, irritation, and defective vision. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

A fully developed pterygium has a head, neck, body, and cap. Deposition of iron as Stocker line may be seen on the corneal epithelium in front of the head of the pterygium.

Asymptomatic pterygium can be left alone. Patients with early-stage pterygia are advised to use protective eyewear. If it progresses towards the pupillary area and causes excessive astigmatism or a restriction of ocular motility or causes disfigurement, it should be treated by surgical excision.

Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:

  • Post-operative therapy with mitomycin C drops to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis. 
  • Conjunctival limbal autografting
  • Amniotic membrane graft
  • Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep
  • Beta irradiation inhibits mitosis in the rapidly dividing cells of pterygium and can be used to prevent recurrences. However, it is not recommended because of its adverse effects which include scleral necrosis, endophthalmitis, and sectorial cataract formation.

questions.text: A newborn presented with severe respiratory distress soon after birth. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A newborn presenting with respiratory distress shortly after birth, along with the chest X-ray showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, is suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

Normally, the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation. CDH is due to a failure to close the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus. This malformation allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, impairing lung development and function. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia, which usually involves the left side. Mortality is predominantly due to the development of pulmonary hypoplasia.

Chest X-ray findings in congenital diaphragmatic hernia include:

  • Bowel loops in the thorax
  • Indistinct diaphragm with opacification of part of or all the hemithorax (typically left-sided)
  • Deviation of lines such as the endotracheal tube, nasogastric tube, umbilical arterial and venous catheters.

Given below is the chest radiograph of Bochdalek hernia.

Given below is the chest radiograph of Morgagni hernia.

Note: Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby. Bag and mask ventilation may increase abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. 

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not present in the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
The enzyme thiokinase is not present in the fatty acid synthase complex. The six enzymes in FAS are:

  • Ketoacyl synthase
  • Malonyl/acetyl transacylase
  • Dehydratase
  • Enoyl reductase
  • Ketoacyl reductase
  • ACP
  • Thioesterase.

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrate and palmitate is the end product.

Acetyl-CoA is carboxylated to form malonyl-CoA by ATP and acetyl-CoA carboxylase as the initial step. This enzyme requires biotin and is the regulatory enzyme in fatty acid synthesis. 

Malonyl-CoA is acted upon by the fatty acid synthase complex(FAS). FAS consists of six enzymes with an acyl carrier protein arranged in a homodimer in an "X-shape". Acyl carrier protein(ACP) contains pantothenic acid.

Thioesterase is the last enzyme in the fatty acid synthase complex. It catalyzes the final release of the newly formed fatty acid. 

Note- Thiokinase catalyzes the only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA. Acyl-CoA is the active form of fatty acid. This step uses one high-energy phosphate and forms AMP and PPi.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: Two people who were involved in a street fight were brought by the police for medical examination. As a medical officer on duty, you report the following types of injuries.  Which one of them is not regarded as a grievous type?

choices.text: Permanent loss of sight in one eye

questions.solution:
Among the given injuries, temporary disfigurement of the face is not regarded as a grievous injury.

Grievous hurt or injury are those injuries that are inflicted voluntarily to another person and comprise of any of the following eight clauses given below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation. (option A). Examples are castration, cutting away of the penis, etc.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent loss of sight of either eye. (option B)
  • Clause 3 — Permanent loss of hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth. (Option D)
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

BNS Sec 116 defines grievous hurt. Punishment for grievous hurt is defined under BNS section 117(2). The convict shall be punished by imprisonment for a term extending to 7 years and also a fine.

Other important points related to the injury are:

IPC Section

Section it deals with

Punishment

Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons.

Up to 3 years of imprisonment or fine or both

325

117(2)

Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt

Up to 7 years of imprisonment and fine

326

118(2)

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means

Imprisonment of 1 year, Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

326A

124(1)

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid

Minimum 10 years imprisonment, extended up to life imprisonment and fine

326B

Minimum 5 years imprisonment and fine

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with mildly pruritic plaques in the left axilla for 2 weeks. Wood’s lamp examination showed coral red fluorescence. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above image along with coral-red fluorescence under Wood’s lamp is suggestive of erythrasma. It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

Erythrasma is a mild, chronic, superficial infection of the skin. It affects the axillae, groins, toe webs, inter-gluteal and submammary regions. Lesions may be symptomless or show mild discomfort and itching.

The lesions may be of irregular shape with sharp margins. They may start as smooth, red patches and then become brown. The lesions are more likely to be pruritic in the tropical regions and may be asymptomatic in the temperate climate. 

Coral‐red fluorescence with Wood’s light is due to coproporphyrin III and suggests erythrasma. The fluorescence may persist after the eradication of the disease. 

Treatment is required otherwise the lesions may persist with fluctuations in severity. Treatment involves topical clotrimazole and miconazole for two weeks. For more extensive lesions, erythromycin can be administered. Relapse can occur. In these cases, long-term povidone-iodine administered topically with drying agents are given. Photodynamic therapy can also be attempted. 

Other options:

Option A: Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria and the typical lesion early in the disease is a superficial ulcer, oval, rounded, or irregularly linear in shape with a clearly defined, overhanging edge. The ulcer may later become deeper and the edge becomes rolled, raised, and avascular. It is usually seen around the umbilicus, behind the ears, genito-crural flexure, or in the clefts.

Option C: Corynebacterium tenuis can give rise to trichomycosis axillaris, a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of an adherent granular nodule which can be yellow, black, or red in color, on the hair shaft.

Option D: Bacillus anthracis causes anthrax, which upon introduction of endospores into areas of exposed skin like the face, neck, hands, or arms gives rise to a typical 'malignant pustule'. It starts as a papule that turns into a bulla on erythematous skin which ruptures to form a hemorrhagic crust surrounded by edema, erythema, and vesicles. The lesions may be single or many.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Vitiligo

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with a productive cough, low-grade fever with an evening rise in temperature over the last 3 months, and blood-tinged sputum over the last four days. An early morning sputum sample was taken for culture and inoculated into two bottles of the following medium. Identify the culture medium shown below:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is that of tuberculosis and the culture medium shown in the image is the Lowenstein-Jenson medium.

It is a selective medium used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis which causes tuberculosis. The presence of malachite green imparts a green color and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are rough, raised, irregular colonies that are creamy white, and buff-colored. (rough, tough, buff). They do not emulsify in a saline solution.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid culture media: Lowenstein–Jensen (A commonly used, egg-based, selective media).
  • Liquid culture media: Dubos' media, Middle Brook’s media. Virulent strains tend to form long serpentine cords in liquid media, while avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner.
  • Automated Culture Media: 
    • BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes
    • BacT/ALERT: A colorimetric method
    • BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Other options:

Option A: BacT Alert culture medium uses a colorimetric method for indication of mycobacterial growth, by detecting the CO2 produced during growth. An image of BacT/ALERT blood culture tubes is given below. 

Option B: Loeffler's serum slope is a medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria. Rapid growth occurs within 6-8 hours. Colonies appear at first as small, opaque discs. They increase in size on continued incubation and may acquire a yellow tint.

It is shown in the image below.

Option D: Middlebrook’s media is a liquid culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text:
Which cyclin-CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase) combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition of cell cycle?

G2 - Gap 2
M - Mitotic
questions.solution:
Cyclin B-CDK1 combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

Related Pearl: Cell Cycle Regulators and Associated Cancers

Cell cycle regulator

Proto-oncogene

Mode of activation in tumor

Associated tumor

Cyclins

CCND1 (Cyclin D1)

Translocation

Amplification

Mantle cell lymphoma, multiple myeloma

Breast and esophageal cancers

Cyclin-dependent kinase

CDK4

Amplification or point mutation

Glioblastoma, melanoma, sarcoma

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient was referred to you with features of pituitary adenoma and testicular tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you notice that the patient has a history of parathyroid adenoma. His chromosomal studies show a mutation in the CDKN1B gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CDKN1B gene : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1b gene
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, testicular tumor, and a mutation in the CDKN1B gene is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN 4).

MEN 4 is an autosomal dominant endocrine tumor syndrome. It occurs due to the germline mutation in the CDKN1B gene in chromosome 12.

MEN 4 often presents with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, or neuroendocrine cervical cancer with adrenal or renal tumors. 

The clinical presentation in MEN 4 is almost similar to that of MEN1. The difference between MEN1 and MEN4 is in the germline mutation, where MEN 1 occurs due to the mutation of the MEN1 gene.

MEN is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by tumors involving two or more endocrine glands. Depending on the chromosomal location of germline mutation, they are divided into four major forms: MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), and MEN 4. MEN 1 is the most common among the four types. 

Other Options:

Option B: MEN 3 is also known as MEN 2B. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, and marfanoid features. In contrast with MEN2A, parathyroid hyperplasia is not seen in MEN 2B.

Option C: MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma.

Option D: MEN 1 is also known as Wermer's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene. It is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 4 months-old male child was brought to the hospital with the complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. The drug used for the treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows flat to elevated, irregular, red-blue masses in the skin of the abdomen suggestive of hemangioma. Propranolol is the preferred treatment of infantile hemangioma.

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis, and inhibiting angiogenesis. Propranolol at 2 mg/kg/day has been found useful in infants younger than 6 months and children up to 5 years of age. 

Complications of infantile hemangioma include pain, functional impairment, or permanent disfigurement.

Timolol is also used in the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

Other options:

Options B, C, D: Bisoprolol, acebutolol, and atenolol are cardioselective beta-blockers that are not used in the treatment of hemangioma.

questions.text: An oral antihypertensive drug X is prescribed to a patient. The drug X given is 200mg twice a day. The bioavailability of the drug X is 0.6 and the clearance is 50mL/min. What is the steady-state concentration of the drug X?
questions.solution:
Steady state concentration (Css) for this drug is 3.33mg/L.

Steady state concentration (Css) = Bioavailability x dosing rate/ clearance 

Dosing rate= 200mg twice a day = 200mg/12hr = 16.6667mg/hr

Bioavailability= 0.6

Clearance = 50 mL/min

Clearance = 50 x 60 mL/hr = 3000 mL/hr = 3L/h (converted to L/h)

Css = 0.6 x (16.6667mg/hr) / (3L/hr) = 10/3 = 3.33 mg/L 

Steady state concentration is the amount of drug administered that is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents for a routine evaluation. A Pap smear is done which reveals a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL). Which of the following management options is suitable for this patient?
questions.solution:
The management option that is suitable for this patient is observation and follow-up. 

The mild dysplasia seen in LSIL occurs usually due to infection. This should be treated and the patient should be followed up every 3-6 months. 

According to the Federation of Obstetric and Gynecological Societies of India (FOGSI) criteria, atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASCUS) or LSIL in women aged less than 30 years should ideally have their cytology repeated annually for two years. If it is negative for intraepithelial lesion or malignancy, then cytology should be repeated at 3 years followed by a return to routine screening based on age-specific modality.

However, within the two years of repeat cytology, if it is ASCUS, then colposcopy with or without biopsy should be done. If normal, then cytology should be repeated at 1 year. If abnormal, then protocol states that FOGSI cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) management good clinical practice recommendations (GCPR) should be followed. 

LSIL should be treated if 

  • It persists for 1 year
  • Poor compliance
  • Progression to high grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL)

CIN is used to grade cervical epithelial dysplasia. It is graded as follows:

  • Mild dysplasia or CIN is described as LSIL according to the Bethseda classification. 
  • Moderate dysplasia or CIN - II 
  • Severe dysplasia or CIN - III is described as carcinoma in situ.

The following image shows the spectrum of epithelial dysplasia.

Other options

Option A - Cryosurgery is performed when small lesions are present. It destroys malignant cells by causing crystallization of intracellular fluid. 

Option B - Laser ablation is performed when CIN extends up to the vaginal vault. It uses heat to kill the cells. 

Option D - Cone biopsy is a diagnostic and therapeutic modality. It can determine if the lesion is endocervical. It can cause bleeding, infection, cervical stenosis, and an incompetent os.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: An elderly patient who is a known case of coronary artery disease presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. His blood pressure was 80/50mmHg. Initial medical management with intravenous fluids and antibiotics is done. Ultrasound reveals a thickened, hyperemic gallbladder surrounded by pericholecystic fluid with gallstones. He is medically unfit for surgery. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous cholecystostomy is the next step in the management of this patient. 

The given clinical scenario along with the ultrasound findings of thickened, hyperemic gallbladder surrounded by pericholecystic fluid with gallstones point to a diagnosis of acute calculous cholecystitis. The patient is a known case of coronary artery disease associated with hypotension. Thus, the patient is medically unfit for surgery due to medical co-morbidities.

Acute calculous cholecystitis is usually due to the presence of gallstones that causes obstruction of the cystic duct leading to inflammation, distension and edema of the gallbladder. Clinical features of acute calculous cholecystitis are:

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever
  • Positive Murphy's sign(right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation)
  • Leukocytosis

Diagnosis: An ultrasound scan is sensitive in acute cholecystitis and demonstrates a distended gallbladder with thickened wall, pericholecystic fluid, presence of gallstone, and the sonographic Murphy's sign. CT scan also demonstrates similar findings as in ultrasound. Hepatobiliary Iminidiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan shows obstruction of the cystic duct which definitively diagnoses acute cholecystitis.  

Treatment:

The first-line treatment would be medical conservative management to subside the symptoms. The conservative management includes nil per mouth with intravenous fluid administration, administration of analgesics and antibiotics. 

Since this patient has co-morbid conditions like coronary artery disease, cholecystectomy which is the definitive procedure is not advised as it increases the operative risks. A percutaneous cholecystostomy tube under ultrasound guidance is placed as it is a temporary measure for draining the infected bile. The cholecystostomy tube can be removed approximately 4 weeks after the resolution of the symptoms and a delayed cholecystectomy procedure can be done after 6-8 weeks of symptom resolution.

Other options:

Option A: Continuation of the conservative treatment is not advisable as the underlying condition has to be treated first.

Option B: Elective cholecystectomy within the next 72 hours after the initial medical treatment and resuscitation are preferred in patients who are fit for the surgery.

Option C: Delayed cholecystectomy is done in patients who are initially unstable so that symptoms can be resolved. Cholecystectomy is performed 6 weeks later.

questions.text: At which angle would you perform a mediolateral episiotomy in a primigravida?
questions.solution:
The mediolateral episiotomy is directed at an angle of 60 degrees. 

The mediolateral episiotomy incision starts in the midline at the fourchette and is directed at an angle 60 degrees from the midline. This 60-degree angle takes into consideration a distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning and ultimately yields an incision that is 45 degrees from the midline following delivery. 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the primary health center to avail of a contraceptive provided under a new government program. She does not want to take daily pills. She was started on the contraceptive shown in the image below.  Which of the following drugs is used in this?
questions.solution:
Injectable contraceptive medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) is introduced under the Antara program.

The dosage is 150 mg I.M every 3 months. This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30 degree centigrade).

Mechanism of action:

  • Inhibition of ovulation
  • Cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration
  • Endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken: 

  • Anytime after regular menstruation, or 
  • After 6 weeks of delivery, or 
  • Immediately after abortion

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
  • Stroke or severe diabetes
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for rapid return to fertility

Disadvantages

  • Menstrual irregularities: Light / heavy bleeding or amenorrhoea
  • Slight weight gain
  • No protection against HIV/STDs 
  • A slight loss in BMD during the first 2 years of use

Note:

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were recently launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea. He is a chronic smoker. On evaluation, a chest x-ray revealed a mass in his right lung and a biopsy of the mass revealed the following picture. Blood examination revealed leukocytosis with no tumor markers. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is large cell carcinoma of the lung.

The given clinical features, with the absence of tumor markers, leukocytosis, and the histopathological image showing large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate cytoplasm point to the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor. Typical cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer are absent. This type of lung cancer does not express any of the tumor markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63). On microscopy, the features described above are observed.

Tumor-related leukocytosis is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with large cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option A - Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor. Histopathological examination shows various patterns, including acinar, papillary, lepidic, micropapillary, and solid. A histopathological image of adenocarcinoma of the lung showing glandular differentiation is given below:


Option B - Small cell carcinomas are highly malignant tumors with a strong association with cigarette smoking. Histopathological examination shows relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin in a salt-and-pepper pattern, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.

Azzopardi effect is the basophilic staining of vessel walls due to DNA residue deposited from necrotic tumor cells, as seen below:


Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor associated with smoking. Histopathological examination is characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization is seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is a high mitotic activity in poorly differentiated tumors.

The image given below shows squamous pearls seen in squamous cell carcinomas.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is complaining of a nagging headache after undergoing a Caesarian section under spinal anesthesia. The headache is occipital in nature, worsens on standing, and is relieved by lying flat. What is the definitive management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH). The definitive treatment for post-dural puncture headache is an epidural blood patch. 

PDPH can occur after spinal or epidural anesthesia due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. It may also occur due to compensatory, painful intracranial vasodilation to offset the reduction in intracranial pressure. The headache is typically frontal or occipital in distribution and is associated with nausea, neck stiffness, and lower back pain. Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. 

An epidural blood patch is the definitive management. It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms. 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at the same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture. It acts by stopping the CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation. Most patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection (1 to 2 days after the first). A prophylactic epidural patch is not recommended.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain. He gives a history of weight loss for 3 months. Barium enema shows the following picture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is this patient is carcinoma colon.

The above clinical scenario of abdominal pain with weight loss and given image showing the 'apple core appearance' in barium enema which is characteristic of carcinoma colon. 

Colon carcinoma typically arises in patients above the age group of 50 years. It arises from the adenomatous polyps after a mutation sequence of adenoma-carcinoma influenced by environmental factors. Most colon cancers occur in the left colon.

The clinical features of colon carcinoma include a change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding in cases of left-sided colon tumors and iron deficiency anemia or a mass in proximal lesions of the colon.

Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice in suspected colorectal carcinoma. Double-contrast barium enema shows a constant irregular filling defect known as the apple core appearance. Computed tomography (CT) virtual colonoscopy has replaced barium enema as it is highly sensitive. Spiral CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis is now the standard means for staging colon cancer. 

Other options:

Option B- On barium enema, ileocecal tuberculosis shows narrowing of the terminal ileum, thickening and gaping of the ileocecal valve, thickening and hypermotility of the caecum.

Below is the barium enema showing ileocecal tuberculosis with the yellow arrow indicating the shrunken caecum, the red arrow indicating stricturing and narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction and the blue arrow indicating proximal ileal dilatation.

Option C- Barium enema radiograph of diverticulosis shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth as shown below.

Option D- Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

questions.text: A woman had a last menstrual period (LMP) of 13/2/2021. Calculate the expected date of delivery according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.solution:
As per Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this woman is November 20, 2021.

Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the last menstrual period (LMP). The LMP is the 1st day of the last menstrual period. Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. 

It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:

  • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
  • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman who is on an MAO inhibitor for major depression for 6 months underwent hernia surgery. Post-operatively the nurse administered an analgesic for the pain. After some time, the patient developed fever, hypotension, rigidity, restlessness, and delirium. Which of the following is unlikely to have caused her symptoms?

MAO: Monoamine oxidase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. Buprenorphine is unlikely to have caused her symptoms. 

Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and an antagonist at δ and κ receptors. It is used as an analgesic and in the management of opioid dependence. It does not have an effect on the neuronal uptake of serotonin so is not implicated in causing serotonin syndrome. 

Serotonin is metabolised by monoamine oxidases and MAO inhibition increases serotonin stores. Opioids such as meperidine, tramadol, fentanyl and dextromethorphan block the neuronal reuptake of serotonin. Therefore, combining MAO inhibitors with these opioids causes serotonin syndrome.

Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include: 

  • Hypotension, flushing
  • Extreme agitation, hyperreflexia
  • Hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity
  • Delirium, myoclonus, status epilepticus, and death. 

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Meperidine (pethidine) is a mu-opioid receptor (MOR) agonist. It has a strong analgesic effect on the central nervous system. It is mainly used as an analgesic but can also be used in post-anesthetic shivering. It has a greater ability to enter the CNS and produce analgesia at lower systemic concentrations compared to morphine. Therefore, constipation, urinary retention, and nausea are less frequent compared to morphine.

Meperdine can cross the placenta and cause significant respiratory depression in the fetus. In patients or addicts who are tolerant to the depressant effects of meperidine, large doses repeated at short intervals may produce an excitatory syndrome that includes hallucinations, tremors, muscle twitches, etc.

Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that is a MOR agonist. It is a centrally-acting analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain. 

Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid and MOR agonist. Fentanyl and sufentanil are commonly used during anesthesia because of their relatively short time of action, cardiovascular safety, and capacity to significantly reduce the dosing requirement for the volatile agents.

questions.text: A sample of hair was examined under polarizing microscopy and showed a typical tiger tail pattern. Which of the following statements is false regarding the associated condition?

choices.text: Collodion membrane often seen at birth
Brittle hair and photosensitivity are seen

questions.solution:
Tiger tail pattern under polarising microscopy is characteristic of trichothiodystrophy (TTD). There is no associated increased risk of skin cancer for most patients with TTD.

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD) is a group of neurocutaneous genodermatoses. It is inherited as autosomal recessive conditions, some of which are associated with defective DNA repair. It is not associated with a risk of skin cancer.

Newborns with photosensitive TTD are generally born premature and have a collodion membrane (presence of a taut, parchment-like membrane over the whole body). 

TTD is associated with a wide range of manifestations like brittle hair, intellectual impairment, elfin face, photosensitivity, photophobia, cataracts, dental anomalies, otosclerosis, and neurological features. Temperature-dependent hair loss can also be seen at the time of febrile illness. 

On polarizing microscopy, alternating light and dark bands called tiger tail banding are seen. This occurs due to a deficiency of cysteine in the hair. Genetic testing may be required to confirm the diagnosis. 

Management of TTD is based on controlling symptoms and clinical manifestations. This includes emollients to moisten dry skin, surgical correction of cataracts, nutritional support, and physical, occupational, and speech therapies. Strict sun avoidance is advised for photosensitive patients.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding Interleukin- 1:

choices.text: Its production is stimulated by prostaglandins
Induces growth of all hematopoietic cells
Induces the maturation of IL-2 producing lymphocytes

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding IL-1 is that induces the maturation of IL-2 producing lymphocytes.

The Interleukin-1 family (IL-1 family) is a group cytokines, which plays a central role in the regulation of immune and inflammatory responses to infections or sterile insults.

IL-1 is a stable polypeptide that occurs in two molecular forms, IL-1α and IL-1β. 

It is principally secreted by macrophages and monocytes but is also expressed in the thymus, spleen, lymph nodes, Peyer’s patches, and bone marrow. In non-lymphoid organs, IL-1α and IL-1β are expressed in tissue macrophages in the lung, digestive tract, and liver.

Its production is stimulated by antigens, toxins, injury, and inflammatory processes. Production of IL-1 is inhibited by cyclosporin-A, corticosteroids, and prostaglandins.

It stimulates T cells for the production of IL-2 and in addition, also stimulates B cell proliferation and antibody synthesis, neutrophil chemotaxis, and phagocytosis.

IL1 is an important endogenous pyrogen. Along with the tumor necrosis factor (TNF), it is responsible for many of the hematological changes in septic shock and inflammation in bacterial meningitis. While cytokine inhibitors such as dexamethasone are protective against the sequelae of such excessive meningeal inflammation, at the same time, IL 1 has a beneficial effect in severe infections in immunocompromised hosts.

Other options:

IL-3 can induce the growth of all types of hematopoietic cells. Hence, it is called a multi-CSF (colony-stimulating factor).

IL-2 is responsible for the conversion of null cells (LGL) into lymphokine-activated killer cells (LAK) which can destroy NK-resistant tumor cells.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the outpatient department with fever and rash as shown below for the past 2 days. The rash was pleomorphic and first appeared on the trunk.  What is the secondary attack rate of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a pleomorphic rash are suggestive of chickenpox or varicella infection. The secondary attack rate of varicella infection is approximately 85 % with a range of 61-100%. 

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of susceptible close contacts). The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. 

Varicella or chickenpox is a highly infectious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The mode of transmission from person to person is by droplet infection or by droplet nuclei. This virus can cross the placental barrier and cause congenital varicella.

The incubation period is usually 14 -16 days. The clinical course can be divided into 2 stages. The pre-eruptive stage is marked by sudden onset of mild to moderate fever, back pain, shivering, and malaise. The eruptive stage is characterized by a rash that appears on the day of fever. They first appear on the trunk and then on the face, arms and legs. It advances quickly through all stages of macule, papule, vesicle, and scab. Rash exhibits a characteristic feature called pleomorphism because all the above stages of rash may be seen simultaneously at one time. 

Most cases of Chickenpox are mild and self-limiting. Oral acyclovir 800 mg five times daily or valacyclovir 1 gm three times daily or famciclovir 250 mg three times daily for 5 - 7 days is used for the treatment of acute infection. 

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Secondary attack rate of viral infections

Viral infection  Secondary attack rate 
Chickenpox ≈85% (61%–100%)
Measles ≥90%
Mumps 86%
Rubella 90%
Erythema infectiosum 10-60%
Infectious mononucleosis 10-20%

questions.text: A study was conducted to find the factors that regulate stomach emptying. Which of the following factors are less of a trigger on enterogastric inhibitory reflex causing inhibition in stomach emptying?
questions.solution:
Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are sensitive to the presence of acidic chyme in the duodenum, not alkaline. 

As the pH of the chyme fall in the duodenum, the enterogastric inhibitory reflexes block the further release of acidic stomach contents into the duodenum. This continues until the duodenal chyme gets neutralized by pancreatic acid and other secretions.

When the food enters the duodenum, multiple reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall which pass back to the stomach. These reflexes slow or stop the stomach emptying if the volume of the chyme in the duodenum becomes too much. These reflexes are called enterogastric reflexes.

This enterogastric inhibitory reflex can be initiated by the following triggers:

  • Presence of irritants and acids in duodenal chyme (most sensitive factor)
  • Amount of chyme
  • Distension of duodenum 
  • Rapid entry of hypertonic or hypotonic fluids into the duodenum
  • Presence of breakdown products of protein digestion and sometimes fat
  • The osmolality of the chyme

Enterogastric reflexes are mediated by:

  • Enteric nervous system from the gut wall
  • Extrinsic nerves to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia and back through the sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach
  • Vagus nerves

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of easy fatiguability. Her blood examination showed mild anemia with target cells. Hemoglobin electrophoresis showed HbA2 levels of 6% with normal HbF and the Mentzer index was 6. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is β Thalassemia minor.

The presence of mild anemia, peripheral smear showing target cells with 6% HbA2, and normal HbF, with a Mentzer index of 6 indicate that this is a case of thalassemia minor.

β Thalassemia minor is a clinical syndrome caused due to heterozygous expression of one normal (β) gene and one abnormal β-thalassemia(β0/+) gene. It can either be present as β+/β or as β0/β. This occurs due to point mutations of the β thalassemia gene on chromosome 11. The predominant mechanisms are:

  • Splicing mutations are the most common cause of β+ thalassemia
  • Promoter region mutations are associated with β+ thalassemia
  • Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause of β0 thalassemia.

These mutations cause a diminished synthesis of β globin chains leading to anemia by decreased synthesis of normal HbA (α2β2) and decreased survival of red cells and their precursors due to imbalance in α and β globin synthesis and elevated γ and δ chain synthesis leading to increased HbF and HbA2 respectively.

β Thalassemia minor is more common clinically than other forms. These patients are usually asymptomatic or present with symptoms of mild anemia. Peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic, microcytic red cells with basophilic stippling, and target cells as shown in the image.

Diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis that reveals typical raised levels of HbA2 (α2δ2) ranging between 4-8% with normal HbF (α2γ2) levels. The Mentzer index of <12 is seen in thalassemia minor syndrome.

Thalassemia minor seldom requires treatment and if indicated is usually in patients after surgery, following childbirth, or to manage complications. Blood transfusions are the preferred modality of treatment.

β Thalassemia major (option C) is a clinical syndrome caused due to homozygous expression of abnormal abnormal β-thalassemia genes in the form of β+/β+, β+/β0, or β0/β0. The etiology is similar as described above. There is the complete absence or only minimal synthesis of the β globin chain. The predominant type of hemoglobin is HbF with very low HbA and normal to mildly increased HbA2.

Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked anisocytosis and poikilocytosis, microcytosis, and hypochromia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. The reticulocyte count is elevated. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.

The patients usually present with severe transfusion-dependent anemia and do not survive without them. Extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences over the face leading to the characteristic 'chipmunk facies.'

β-thalassemia intermedia is a third genetically heterogeneous β-thalassemia variant of moderate severity. This category includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β+/β0-thalassemia. The Mentzer index is 12-14 in thalassemia intermedia.

Other options:

Option A - Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of microcytic anemia. It is characterized by the presence of microcytic hypochromic red cells with pencil cells. It can be differentiated from β Thalassemia minor by examining the blood smear and serum levels of iron, total iron-binding capacity, and serum ferritin. A definitive differentiation can be made in the favour of iron deficiency anemia when the Mentzer index is >14. 

Option B - α Thalassemia trait is caused by the deletion of two α-globin genes from a single chromosome (α/α,−/−) or the deletion of one α-globin gene from each of the two chromosomes (α/−, α/−). Patients present with symptoms similar to β thalassemia minor but there are normal or low HbA2 levels.

Note:

Mentzer index is defined as mean corpuscular volume per red cell count, i.e. MCV/RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron deficiency anemia and thalassemia trait as follows:

  • >14: Iron deficiency anemia
  • 12-14: Intermediate
  • <12 Thalassemia trait 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:
