questions.text: According to the POCSO act, sexual harassment includes:

choices.text: Making a child to exhibit his/her body
Act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration
Sexual assault by a police officer

questions.solution:
According to POCSO act sexual harassment includes making a child exhibit his/her body.

The POCSO Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offences which include:

  • Sexual harassment: A person is said to commit sexual harassment upon a child when such person with sexual intent,
    • Carries out any act with sexual connotations
    • Makes a child exhibit his/her body
    • Shows any object to a child in any form/media for pornographic purposes.
    • Repeatedly or constantly watches or contacts a child through any media.
    • Threatens to use in any form of media, a real or fabricated depiction through any mode, of any part of the body of a child. 
  • Sexual assault
    • Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • Aggravated sexual assault
    • Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated.
  • Penetrative sexual assault
    • An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration.
  • Aggravated penetrative sexual assault
    • Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated.
  • Pornography - Using a child in any form of media for purposes of sexual gratification. 

The term aggravated is used for those assaults done: 

  • By a person in a position of trust or authority such as a police officer, security force, relative, or hospital staff.
  • In the course of communal violence.
  • On mentally & physically disabled.
  • Gang sexual assault.
  • Using deadly weapons.
  • Causing grievous hurt
  • On child < 12 years.

Other options - 

Option B - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration is a sexual assault according to POCSO.

Option D - Sexual assault done by a police officer is an aggravated sexual assault according to POCSO. 

Option C - Gang penetrative sexual assault is defined as aggravated penetrative assault according to POCSO.

The International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression is a United Nations observance each 4th June. This day affirms the UN's commitment to protect the rights of children.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in swallowing, a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat, and a burning sensation in his chest over the past month. A barium swallow study is performed, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient presenting with food impaction and dysphagia and barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is diagnosed based on the combination of typical esophageal symptoms and esophageal mucosal biopsies demonstrating squamous epithelial eosinophil-predominant inflammation.

Symptoms:

  • Adults: Food impaction, dysphagia, vomiting, and GERD-like symptoms
  • Children: Feeding intolerance and GERD-like symptoms
  • Patients are usually atopic and may also have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or modest peripheral eosinophilia.

Diagnosis:

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis. Fluoroscopy/barium studies show a small-caliber esophagus, transient or fixed circular rings, or a benign stricture. The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of > 15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

Treatment:

Patients typically undergo a trial of PPI therapy to exclude GERD. 30–50% of cases respond to PPI therapy.

Children have been effectively treated with allergy testing combining skin prick and atopy patch testing. Both adults and children responded to empiric elimination of common food allergies (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, and seafood) followed by systematic reintroduction.

Swallowed, topical glucocorticoids like fluticasone propionate or budesonide are highly effective but have high rates of recurrence after discontinuing therapy. Systemic glucocorticoids are reserved for severely afflicted patients refractory to less morbid treatments.

Esophageal dilation is very effective at relieving dysphagia in patients with fibro stenosis but is approached conservatively because of the risk of deep, esophageal mural laceration or perforation in the stiff-walled esophagus.

The below image shows the feline esophagus seen on esophageal endoscopy.

Other options:

Options B - Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles and barium swallow study shows corkscrew appearance.

Option C - Achalasia cardia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing. It presents with the characteristic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. On barium swallow, bird-beak appearance of the esophagus is seen in achalasia. Esophageal manometry is the "gold standard" investigation for achalasia.

Option D - Zenker's diverticulum is a pseudodiverticulum resulting from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus. Barium swallow study is used for the diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male patient came with complaints of wheezing, shortness of breath, and cough for the past 3 weeks. The cough is productive, with brown mucus plugs. He is a known case of bronchial asthma since childhood. Auscultation reveals widespread expiratory wheeze. Chest x-ray of the patient had the characteristic finding shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs can be given in this condition?

Laboratory findings:

  • IgE >1000 ng/mL
  • Peripheral blood eosinophilia
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of cough, shortness of breath, x-ray showing the finger-in-glove appearance with peripheral eosinophilia, and IgE more than 1000 ng/mL is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). Among the given options omalizumab can be used for ABPA.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE.

Low-dose glucocorticoids (prednisolone 7.5–10 mg) is considered for the prevention of progressive lung damage in ABPA and suppression of the immunopathological responses. Itraconazole 400 mg/day can be used to facilitate a reduction in oral glucocorticoid.  

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with long-standing asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The condition is diagnosed in younger patients usually before 40 years of age. The patient typically presents with atopic symptoms. Sometimes, an expectorant cough with orange mucus plugs may be seen.

Radiographic findings in ABPA:

  • Lobar collapse
  • Non-segmental areas of opacities commonly in the upper lobe
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus termed as finger-in-glove appearance 
  • Pulmonary cavitation is seen occasionally

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of

  • Serum IgE >1000 ng/mL
  • Positive skin prick test in response to Aspergillus fumigatus extract
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

questions.text: The risk of which complication of suction evacuation is reduced by the usage of these plastic instruments?
questions.solution:
Karman’s type suction cannulas made of plastic, reduce the risk of uterine perforation during suction evacuation procedures.

There are different sizes of the Karman's suction cannula. The size to be used depends on the duration of the pregnancy in weeks. Size 4-7 mm can be used for 4-6 week period of gestation, size 5-10 mm can be used for 7-9 weeks, and 8-12 mm can be used for 9-12 weeks. The plastic cannula allows visualization of the products being evacuated.

Suction evacuation is a procedure by means of which products of conception are sucked out of the uterus with a cannula attached to a suction apparatus. 

Indications:  

  • 1st-trimester medical termination of pregnancy 
  • Inevitable abortion 
  • Recent incomplete abortion 
  • Hydatidiform mole 

Procedure: 

  1. Vaginal examination is done to assess the size and position of the uterus and the state of the cervix
  2. Posterior vaginal speculum held by an assistant
  3. Grasp the anterior lip of the cervix with an Allis forceps
  4. Introduce a uterine sound to determine the length of the cavity and position of the uterus
  5. Dilate the cervix if required until one size less than that of the suction cannula
  6. Administer intravenous methergine 0.2mg
  7. Insert suction cannula with the tip in the middle of the uterine cavity
  8. Increase the pressure to 400-600mmHg. Move the cannula up and down and rotate it 360 degrees with the pressure on. 
  9. Inspect the suction bottle of products of conception and blood loss.
  10. Regulate the suction with a finger over the hole at the base of the cannula
  11. Break the vacuum before withdrawing the cannula
  12. Curette the uterus at the end of the suction and reintroduce the cannula to remove remnants. 

Suction is stopped when no more material is sucked out, there is gripping of the cannula by the uterus, a grating sensation, or appearance of bubbles in the cannula. 

Complications of suction evacuation:

Immediate:

  • Excessive hemorrhage due to incomplete evacuation or atonic uterus.
  • Injury due to cervical lacerations of varying degree which may lead to the formation of a broad ligament hematoma and uterine perforation. 
  • Shock due to excessive blood loss, anesthesia complications, or cervical shock—vasovagal syncope due to cervical stimulation. 
  • Perforation—injury to major blood vessels, bowel or bladder
  • Sepsis—endometritis, myometritis, pelvic peritonitis. 
  • Hematometra 
  • Increased morbidity
  • Continuation of pregnancy (failure) – 1%.

Late: 

  • Pelvic inflammation 
  • Infertility 
  • Cervical incompetence 
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Subsequent pregnancy risks- preterm labor, ectopic pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented with complaints of indigestion, dysphagia, and nausea for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed rugal flattening in the gastric antrum and a biopsy revealed the following on histopathological examination. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?

choices.text: Loss of function in APC gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and biopsy findings are suggestive of the diagnosis as diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma is caused due to loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene, which encodes for E-cadherin.

The biopsy specimen shows signet ring cells. This along with the presence of dysphagia, dyspepsia, nausea, anemia, and endoscopic findings of loss of rugal folds is suggestive of the diagnosis as diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma

Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy of the stomach and constitutes more than 90% of all gastric cancers. Based on the gross appearance, the gastric adenocarcinoma is classified into two types:

  • Diffuse type, which is characterized by infiltrates and thickening of the gastric wall.
  • Intestinal type, which is characterized by bulky masses or an ulcerated infiltrative tumor

Diffuse adenocarcinoma:

In diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma, the wall of the stomach is thickened and firm. When the large areas of the stomach are involved, diffuse rugal flattening and a rigid, thickened wall may impart a leather bottle appearance to which the term linitis plastica. A barium swallow image of linitis plastica is given below.

There are no identified precursor lesions for this subtype and the prevalence is the same in men and women.

Majority of the gastric cancers are not hereditary. However, in some cases with a family history, the condition is usually associated with loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene, which encodes for E-cadherin. The loss of E-cadherin plays a key role in the pathogenesis of diffuse gastric cancer. The invading tumor cells induce an extensive desmoplastic reaction that stiffens the gastric wall. Signet ring cells are seen on biopsy, they are named so because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumor cells.

Intestinal-type gastric cancer:

This subtype develops from precursor lesions including flat dysplasia and adenomas. The mean age of presentation is 55 years, and twice as common in men compared to women. Loss of function in the APC gene (Option C) and gain of function in the β-catenin gene are involved in the development of intestinal-type gastric cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Translocation (11;18) is associated with extranodal gastric MALToma. Patients generally present with dyspepsia, epigastric pain, hematemesis, and weight loss. Histologically, the diagnostic feature is the infiltration of neoplastic lymphocytes into the gastric glands to form lymphoepithelial lesions as shown below.

Option B: Excessive secretion of TGF-α is seen in Ménétrier's disease. It is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and irregular enlargement of gastric rugae in the fundus and body as shown below. The antrum is spared.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema. Microscopically, there is hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of Gastric Adenocarcinoma

Intestinal type

Diffuse type

Male-to-female ratio, 2:1

Equal frequency in males and females

Bulky masses

Diffusely infiltrative growth

Glandular structures

Signet-ring cells

Increased signaling via WNT pathway

Loss of E-cadherin

Precursor lesions are flat dysplasia and adenomas.

No identified precursor lesions

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has been complaining of unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now comes with complaints of blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. Visual field examination shows a pale optic disc. Which of the following is the most probable pathophysiology seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical picture is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) with polymyalgia rheumatica which is most commonly associated with anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).

AION is due to the interference in the circulation of the posterior ciliary artery supplying the anterior part of the optic nerve.

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION):

The two types are as follows:

  • Arteritic AION: caused by giant-cell arteritis
  • Non-arteritic AION (NAAION): most common

Clinical features:

Features

AAION

NAAION

Age

>60 years

<60 years

Sex

F > M

F = M

Headache

Jaw claudication

Present

Absent

Visual loss

Marked

Less marked

Optic disc

Pale disc edema

Hyperemic disc edema with flame-shaped hemorrhages

C-reactive proteins

Raised

Normal

ESR

Highly raised

(> 40 mm in the first hour)

Raised

(20 - 40 mm in the first hour)

Fluorescein angiogram

Disc and

choroidal filling delay

Only disc delay

Treatment

Corticosteroids

Levodopa–carbidopa combination for 3 weeks and then double dose for 1 month

The image given below shows pale chalky white optic disc edema of arteritic AION.

In GCA with visual changes, corticosteroid therapy should be started as soon as possible. An intravenous loading dose of 200 mg hydrocortisone or 500 mg methylprednisolone administered slowly over one hour is recommended. It is followed by high doses of oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day) given daily for the first week. A maintenance dose of 5–15 mg is continued for at least 6–12 months.

Other Options: 

Option A: Central retinal artery occlusion presents as a sudden painless loss of vision. It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot as shown below.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion also causes painless loss of vision, although not as rapidly as CRAO. Fundoscopy demonstrates tortuous engorged veins and retinal hemorrhages as shown below.

Option D: Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy involves the small pial vessels supplying the intraorbital portion of the optic nerve. Although it is associated with vasculitides like giant cell arteritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, it doesn't affect the fundus. There is no edema or hemorrhage on fundoscopy.

The image below shows a normal fundus in posterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. A chest X-ray was done as shown below. Which of the following subtypes of this condition causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the X-ray showing a snowman appearance of the heart is suggestive of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC). The infracardiac type causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction.

In the infracardiac variety of TAPVC, the common pulmonary vein drains to the portal vein instead of joining the left atrium. The pulmonary vein gets obstructed as it enters the diaphragm through the esophageal orifice.

TAPVC is a congenital cardiac malformation where pulmonary veins return to the right atrium or systemic venous circulation instead of draining directly to the left atrium.

According to the site of anomalous connection, the TAPVC can be divided into four subtypes:

  1. Supracradiac (Most common)
  2. Cardiac
  3. Infracardiac
  4. Mixed

Percentage of obstruction in different types of TAPVC:

Type of TAPVC  % with significant obstruction 
Infracardiac 95-100
Supracardiac 40-75
Cardiac 5-10
Mixed -

Neonates with severe obstruction to pulmonary venous return (infracardiac group) present with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. Murmurs may be absent on cardiac examination.

Children with mild or no obstruction to pulmonary venous return (supracardiac or cardiac) develops heart failure due to a fall in pulmonary vascular resistance. They are associated with systolic murmurs.

In the supracardiac variety, the anomalous pulmonary veins enter the innominate vein and persistent left super vena cava. As a result, a large supracardiac shadow can be seen with normal cardiac shadow and gives a characteristic pattern of snowman appearance/ figure of 8 in the chest.

The image given below shows x-ray findings seen in the supracardiac variety of TAPVC.


A 2D echocardiography and doppler are used for the diagnosis of TAPVC where it fails to demonstrate draining of pulmonary vein to the left atrium. The right atrium and right ventricle are often enlarged. ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

TAPVC is treated by emergent surgical correction. If surgery cannot be performed urgently, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation may be required to maintain oxygenation.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: Given below is an image depicting one of the mechanisms by which secretions are poured out of cells. Which of the following is an example of the glands that utilize this mechanism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the apical part of the cells being shed off to discharge the secretion, which is the mechanism of apocrine secretion. This mechanism is seen in axillary sweat glands.

Exocrine glands can be classified into three subtypes by the manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells.

Apocrine - In these glands, the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion. Examples of apocrine glands are :

  • Secretion of milk fat by mammary glands
  •  Atypical sweat glands in the axilla, perianal region, periumbilical skin, mons pubis, etc.

Apocrine glands are large glands found in the dermis or subcutaneous fat. They are a type of sweat gland. It consists of a basal secretory coil followed by a straight duct that opens into the pilary canal above the duct of the sebaceous gland. In hairless skin, it directly opens onto the skin surface. 

Ceruminous glands of the external auditory meatus are modified apocrine glands

Each coil is lined by cuboidal cells with its apex projecting into the lumen and the base in contact with myoepithelial cells. These cells contain vacuoles, vesicles, and dense granules of varying sizes and pour their secretions as described above.

Apocrine activity is minimal before puberty, after which it is androgen-dependent and responsive to emotional stimuli. It is controlled by adrenergic nerves and is sensitive to adrenaline and noradrenaline.

The secretion is initially sterile and odorless, but it undergoes bacterial decomposition to generate odorous and musky compounds. Obstruction of apocrine sweat ducts and associated upper hair follicles in the axillae, breast areolae, and pubic region, mainly in women, is thought to cause Fox–Fordyce disease. It is also implicated in the causation of a painful, occasionally debilitating condition called hidradenitis suppurativa.

The given image shows an illustration of apocrine secretion.

Merocrine is the most common secretory mechanism. In this subtype, the secretions are initially packed into membrane-bound vesicles, shifted to the cell surface, and poured out by exocytosis. The cell remains intact. The stimulus for secretion is predominantly by raised intracellular calcium. An example of the merocrine gland is the simple sweat glands of the skin. An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

In holocrine glands, the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion, and the secretion is poured commonly into an adjacent hair follicle. It is typically seen in sebaceous glands. A few examples of sebaceous glands are:

  • Montgomery's glands of nipples
  • The inner surface of prepuce, clitoris, and labia minora
  • Meibomian glands - palpebral tarsal glands

An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

Related Pearl: Comparison between Types of Sweat Glands

Feature

Apocrine sweat gland

Eccrine sweat gland

Activity

Active at puberty

Throughout life

Opening on the surface

Around hair shaft

Through sweat pores

Function

Provides peculiar odour

Maintains temperature

Nervous control

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are adrenergic

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are cholinergic

Secretions

Viscid with lipids and proteins

Watery with salts

Related Pearl: Fox-Fordyce disease

Fox Fordyce disease, also known as Apocrine Miliaria, is characterized by intensely pruritic, white pearly papules in apocrine areas. It most commonly involves axilla, then areolae. It is commonly seen in women (90%).

The condition occurs as a result of apocrine sweat duct occlusion by aggregates of epithelial cells of the apocrine or apoeccrine secretory cells. The earliest pathological sign is a small vesicle in the apocrine duct.

Later, the apocrine glands are seen to be enlarged, and as a consequence of repeated inflammatory events, perifollicular xanthomatosis with perifollicular foam cells expressing CD68 may develop.

Treatment:

First-line

  • Topical or intralesional steroids
  • Topical clindamycin lotion
  • Topical retinoids

Second line

  • Ultraviolet light
  • Oral retinoids

Third line

  • Surgery

This should not be confused with Fordyce spots or Fordyce disease which is due to ectopic sebaceous glands.

Image: Fox-Fordyce disease of the axilla

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lethargy, increased thirst, and increased frequency of urination. On examination, his BMI was 19 kg/m2 and laboratory investigation showed low levels of C-peptide, raised blood glucose, and absent ketone bodies. Anti-GAD antibodies were positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Anti-GAD: Antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 32-year-old, thin-built male, presenting with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy with laboratory investigation showing low C-peptide, and positive anti-GAD antibodies is suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). 

LADA is adult-onset diabetes with features of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM). They phenotypically appear as type 2 but have autoantibodies like anti-GAD in favor of type 1. The general characteristics of LADA include:

  • Age of onset more than 30 years
  • Family history of autoimmunity
  • Low or normal body mass index
  • Low C-peptide levels
  • Anti-GAD antibodies positive
  • Do not present with ketoacidosis initially due to the slow progression of beta-cell destruction

The diagnosis can be made based on three criteria as given by The Immunology of Diabetes Society:

  • Adult age of onset (>30 years of age),
  • Positive circulating autoantibodies, and
  • No need for insulin treatment initially for several months after diagnosis

Initially, they don't require insulin but are more likely to be on insulin treatment within 5 years of onset. 

Other options:

Option A: Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes patients are usually middle-aged men who are overweight and have a positive family history of diabetes. They have features similar to classic type 2 diabetes but often present with severe hyperglycemia and severe ketosis as in type 1 diabetes. Autoantibodies against beta-cells are negative in these patients. 

Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that occurs in patients less than 25 years of age. This is due to beta-cell dysfunction that impairs insulin secretion. The patients are non-ketotic and do not have pancreatic autoantibodies.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus most commonly develops before 20 years of age with most of them having evidence of islet-directed autoimmunity. Most of the patients present with hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. There is increased lipolysis and ketone body production which results in muscle wasting, polyphagia, fatigue, and weakness.
In LADA, the destruction of islet cells proceeds at a much slower speed. This is why they present later, and may not require insulin treatment initially (unlike Type 1 DM). 

Related Pearl: Comparative Features between MODY and Type 2 DM

MODY

Predominantly young (< 25 years)

No insulin resistance

Vertical transmission through successive generations is not essential for diagnosis

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with episodes of intermittent right upper abdominal pain for the past few months. She underwent cholecystectomy a year back. Investigations showed elevated AST and ALT levels and imaging revealed a dilated common bile duct with prolonged biliary drainage time. What is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?

AST - Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT - Alanine aminotransferase
HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid
ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters is the gold standard for its diagnosis.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is characterized by abdominal pain, biliary or pancreatic duct dilatation due to abnormal function of the sphincter of Oddi.

Clinical types include biliary and pancreatic SOD.

Biliary type presents with biliary pain, raised liver enzymes, and/or dilation of the bile duct and/or evidence of delayed emptying on biliary imaging. It should be excluded in patients with post-cholecystectomy syndrome. Pancreatic SOD presents as recurrent episodes of unexplained acute pancreatitis.

CT and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can demonstrate dilatation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. MRCP with intravenous secretin injection demonstrates dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to increased sphincter pressures. Endoscopic ultrasound can also be used. HIDA scan will show delayed biliary transit.

The gold standard investigation is ERCP with manometry and is indicated in disabling pain, when noninvasive investigations fail to demonstrate structural abnormalities and when conservative therapy fails. Basal sphincter pressure higher than 40 mm Hg is suggestive of SOD.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. It involves the use of a side-viewing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It can be a therapeutic and diagnostic modality specifically for viewing the distal biliary tree. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.  

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A 15-year old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. An X-ray of his left hip joint is shown below. What is the sign seen?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). The radiograph shows the Trethowan's sign. 

The Klein line is a line drawn along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Option B: Catterall's sign is seen in Perthes disease.

Option C: Alli's sign is seen in DDH.

Option D: Dagger sign is seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever for 3 days associated with chills and rigors. His temperature is 102°F. Cardiac auscultation shows a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region. His past history is significant for prosthetic valve surgery 2 years back. Which of the following organism is the most likely cause for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.

Fever plus a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region with a history of prosthetic valve surgery is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis as the likely diagnosis. 

Clinical features of infective endocarditis include:

  • Fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain, and arthralgias
  • Cardiac murmurs, mycotic aneurysm, heart failure
  • Splenomegaly, splenic infarction, renal infarction, glomerulonephritis
  • Stroke, Meningitis
  • Vertebral osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and abscesses

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding.
  • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules are usually found on the distal pads of the digits as shown below.

 

  • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles as shown below.

 

  • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers as shown below.

Other options-

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing infective endocarditis overall.

Option C: Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoS) is the most common group of organisms causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery).

Option D: HACEK organisms cause subacute infective endocarditis.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

Streptococci

Staphylococcus aureus

Staphylococcus aureus

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)*

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

*Streptococci includes Viridans streptococci (VGS), Streptococcus gallolyticus (previously Streptococcus bovis biotype 1) and other non-groupable and groupable streptococci

 

Microorganism

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in a saturated solution of salt. What is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection with Hymenolepis nana. 

The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution.

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest tapeworm. Man is the host. The patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with eggs of these organisms. The adult work resides in the small intestine.

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. They are usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may be present due to an allergic response. A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

Other options:

Option A- The fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are bile stained and float in a saturated solution of water. They are round or oval in shape. The egg is surrounded by a thick smooth translucent shell having a coarsely mamillated translucent coat. In the middle of the egg, there is a large unsegmented ovum. It covers the entire area of the egg, except for the poles.

Unfertilized eggs do not float in salt solution. They are long, narrow, and elliptical in shape. They have thinner shell with irregular albumin coating and small atrophied ovum.

The left image is unfertilized egg, while the right is the fertilized egg of Ascaris.

Option B- The eggs of the Ancylostoma duodenale are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane and a segmented ovum containing 4-8 blastomeres. The space between the hyaline shell and the ovum is clear. 

The image given below shows the egg of Ancylostoma sp.

Option D- Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. They are barrel-shaped, with a mucus plug on either end. 

The image given below shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with metabolic syndrome. Presence of which of the following additional symptoms in this patient constitutes a component of Syndrome Z?
questions.solution:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on the NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
  • Hypertension: Blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

Note: 

NCEP: ATP III - National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presented with a mobile, painless mass in the lower, outer aspect of her right breast. It first appeared 4 months ago. A histopathological image of the mass is given below. Which of the following best describes the microscopic features?

BM - Basement membrane

choices.text: Bulbous protrusions extending into cystic space covered by epithelium
Delicate myxoid stroma with slit-like spaces lined by epithelium
Clonal epithelial cell proliferation limited to ducts and lobules by the BM
Solid sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and histopathology of the breast, are most likely suggestive of fibroadenoma. Microscopy of fibroadenoma reveals delicate myxoid stroma with slit-like spaces lined by epithelium.

Fibroadenomas are commonly occurring benign tumors of the breast. They generally occur in women who are in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life. In response to endogenous hormones, they may grow (pregnancy) or shrink in size (menopause). 

They may be multiple fibroadenomas and may occur bilaterally. 

Morphology: 

Gross: They are well-circumscribed and rubbery with grey-white nodules that bulge above the surrounding tissue. 

Microscopy: They have a delicate myxoid stroma resembling normal interlobular stroma with slit-like spaces lined by epithelium. Pericanalicular pattern shows epithelium surrounded by stroma while the intracanalicular pattern has compressed epithelium.

Other options: 

Option A - Bulbous protrusions extending into cystic space covered by epithelium are seen in phyllodes tumor of the breast. The bulbous protrusions occur due to nodules of proliferating stroma. They also arise from the intralobular stroma but are not as common. They are generally present in the 6th decade. They have higher cellularity, higher mitotic figures, nuclear pleomorphism, stromal overgrowth, and infiltrative borders. 

Option C - Clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the basement membrne is seen in ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). It can be detected by mammography and is curative with surgical excision and radiation. There are many subtypes of DCIS including but not limited to comedo, cribriform, micropapillary, papillary.

Option D - Solid sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli are sen in medullary carcinoma of the breast. It is a subtype of invasive breast cancer. Due to minimal desmoplasia, they are softer than the other carcinomas.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with recurrent abscesses and also suffers from fractures after trivial trauma. His mother gives a history of skin rashes over the face and scalp, and prolonged hospital stays at birth due to pneumonia. Blood investigations show IgE levels of 2500U/mL and peripheral eosinophilia. Which of the following statements are false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent abscesses and fractures from minor trauma with a history of rashes over the scalp and face and raised IgE levels most likely has Job syndrome (Hyper IgE syndrome). Cold abscesses are seen in this condition, hence option C is false.

Job syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency syndrome occurring due to mutations in the STAT3 gene. It is inherited more commonly in an autosomal dominant manner. Some cases are also inherited in an autosomal recessive manner which is characterized by the absence of dysmorphic facial features.

Mutation of STAT3 gene leads to overproduction of IgE without modulation. Loss of modulation is due to the absence of anti-inflammatory cytokines IL-6, IL-10, and IFN-gamma. Lack of IL-6 leads to deficiency of CD4 + Th17 cells that make them susceptible to various infections seen in Job syndrome.

It usually presents as a triad of atopic dermatitis, recurrent skin staphylococcal infections, and recurrent pulmonary infections that occur early in childhood. The eczematoid rash affects the scalp and face that gets superinfected with Staphylococcus aureus and form cold abscesses. Candida infections are common. Recurrent staphylococcal pneumonia with pneumatocoeles is also commonly seen. Other non-immunological features are:

  • Dysmorphic facial features that appear in early adolescence and are absent in the autosomal recessive form
  • Craniosynostosis
  • Arnold-Chiari type 1
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • Scoliosis
  • Pathological fractures
  • Retention of primary teeth
  • Vascular complications
  • Ocular complications

Diagnosis is based on measurements of serum IgE levels >2000U/mL in adjunct with the clinical features. It is associated with peripheral blood eosinophilia.

The most effective treatment, for this condition, is the long-term, sometimes continuous, use of antibiotics. Interferon-gamma has shown no clinical benefit.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient came with complaints of exertional breathlessness and fatigue for a few months. She gives a history of radiotherapy for carcinoma breast 6 months back. On examination,  bilateral lower limb pitting edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign were present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman presenting post-irradiation with progressive exertional dyspnea, bilateral lower extremity oedema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign is suggestive of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterised by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction.

Most of the cases are due to the infiltration of abnormal substances between myocytes like amyloidosis, abnormal metabolic products within myocytes as seen in hemochromatosis/Fabry's disease, or fibrotic injury like radiation/scleroderma.  

They often present with right-sided heart symptoms like oedema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign 

Kussmaul's sign is a paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration. It is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy and is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, during inspiration, the JVP falls due to negative intrathoracic pressure. When there is an impairment in the expansion of the right ventricle or a rise in the right atrial pressure, there is a back pressure of blood in the jugular veins. This causes a paradoxical rise in the JVP during inspiration instead of a fall.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy presents with symptoms and signs of left heart failure or biventricular heart failure. Patients show cardiomegaly, and a third heart sound can be auscultated. The most frequent causes are alcoholism, myocarditis, chemotherapy, and endocrinopathies. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Examination reveals bisferiens carotid pulse. A fourth heart sound and variable systolic murmur can be auscultated. It is an inherited autosomal disease with variable penetrance. They are caused by mutation of the gene encoding for myosin heavy chains or proteins regulating calcium handling. The echocardiogram is the diagnostic tool. Any area of left ventricle thickness more than 1.5 cm confirms the disease.

Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents as acute anterior myocardial infarction, with acute chest pain or shortness of breath. It occurs soon after a high catecholamine surge and is seen predominantly in postmenopausal women.  Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronaries. The LV appears as a round ampulla, resembling the Japanese octopus pot called the takotsubo pot. Imaging reveals apical left ventricular ballooning due to myocardial stunning. 

The image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: The following sign is seen in a patient with spinal cord injury. What is the most likely level of lesion in the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Beevor’s sign indicating a spinal cord lesion at the level T10-T12.

Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man injured his back in a road traffic accident. On examination, it is found that he has a loss of proprioception and vibration sense in both lower limbs. Which of the following is true about the type of nerve fibers that are damaged in this patient?

choices.text: Small diameter, unmyelinated, low conduction velocity
Medium sized, myelinated, high conduction velocity
Large diameter, unmyelinated, low conduction velocity
Large diameter, myelinated, high conduction velocity

questions.solution:
The sensations of proprioception and vibration are carried by A-alpha nerve fibers. These are nerve fibers with large axonal diameter, myelinated, and have high conduction velocity. These are carried along the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

Other options:

Option A- Type C fibers are small diameter unmyelinated fibers with low conduction velocity. They carry pain sensation.

Option B- Type A beta, gamma, and delta fibers are medium-sized myelinated fibers. They carry touch and pressure sensations and supply muscle spindles.

Option C- Large diameter nerve fibers are myelinated, both these factors contribute to high conduction velocity.

questions.text: An unclaimed dead body was brought for forensic examination. Postmortem examination reveals a complete fusion of the joint shown with the arrow mark in the below image. What would be the approximate age of this person?
questions.solution:
The arrow points to the manubrio-sternal joint which fuses in old age usually above 50 years of age.

The sternum is formed from the fusion of the manubrium, the body, and the xiphoid process. The fusion of the 4 pieces of the body of the sternum occurs from below upwards, followed by its fusion to the xiphoid process and then the fusion of manubrium to the fused sternum.

Joints 

Age of fusion
Fusion of manubrium with body

Usually above 50 years 
Fusion of body segments  14-25 years from below upwards
Fusion of xiphoid process with body 40-45 years

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient was posted for surgery under general anesthesia. He is a known case of type 1 diabetes and is on regular treatment with insulin detemir subcutaneously. What would you advise the patient regarding the dose of insulin that can be taken on the day of surgery?
questions.solution:
The dose of long-acting insulin that can be taken on the day of surgery in patients with type 1 diabetes is usually one-third the normal dose.

In the given clinical scenario, the patient is on insulin detemir which is a long-acting formulation of insulin. In a patient with type 1 diabetes on a long-acting formulation, the usual recommendation is to take one-third of the normal dose of long-acting insulin on the day of the surgery.

Other options:

Option A - The dose of all short-acting (e.g., regular) insulin is skipped on the day of the surgery.

Option C - One-half dose of insulin is taken in patients with type 2 diabetes on long-acting insulin or combination on the day of surgery.

Option D - A normal dose of insulin is recommended if the patient is on an insulin pump.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior 

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  1. Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 
  2. Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  3. Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  4. Thyroid medications

  6. Heartburn or reflux medications
  7. Narcotic medications

  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
questions.solution:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells. 

Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells.

Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed.

Below is an image showing Korner's septum -

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with sudden onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless, like rice water, and had an inoffensive sweetish odor. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent.

TCBS - Thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose

choices.text: Can cause metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia
Produces greyish black colonies on TCBS medium

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera and the causative agent is Vibrio cholerae. They produce large yellow convex colonies on the TCBS medium.

The cells of Vibrio cholerae are gram-negative and typically comma-shaped. They show darting motility, with a single sheathed polar flagellum. They are aerobic and produce large yellow convex colonies on the thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) medium.

They are late lactose fermenters, producing pink colonies on MacConkey agar after prolonged incubation. They are aerobic. Special media for transporting and cultivating vibrio species are:

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary-Blair medium
  • Autoclaved seawater
  • Enrichment media like Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water 
  • Plating media:
    • Alkaline bile salt agar
    • Monsur's gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTA)
    • Thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose agar (colonies shown in the image below)

Vibrio colonies may be identified by the 'string test', where a loopful of the growth is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The suspension loses its turbidity, becomes mucoid, and forms a 'string' when the loop is drawn away slowly in a positive test.

The cholera toxin disrupts the zona occludens. It activates cellular adenylate cyclase leading to the accumulation of cAMP. It consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The active A subunit enters the enterocyte and dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links the biologically active A1 to the B subunit.

A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. This leads to watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate. This results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.

Oral administration of fluid containing glucose and electrolytes is a highly effective, economical method of treating cholera. 

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

>16 hrs incubation period

questions.text: A young man came with complaints of redness and watering of the left eye for 2 days. On examination, he had decreased corneal sensation and the fluorescein staining shows the following finding. What is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of decreased corneal sensation and fluorescein stain showing dendritic ulcer are suggestive of Viral keratitis and the most likely causative agent is the Herpes simplex virus.

Keratitis is the inflammation of the cornea characterized by corneal edema, cellular infiltration, and ciliary congestion. Herpes simplex causes epithelial keratitis and in severe forms, dendritic ulcers develop. Most of the patients present with redness, photophobia, watering, and blurred vision. On examination, visual acuity and corneal sensation are reduced. Follicular conjunctivitis and blepharitis may develop but are usually mild. Clinical reactivation occurs due to multiple stress factors and causes recurrent infections.

The fluorescein-stained image under slit-lamp examination shows dendritic ulcers, a pathognomic feature of epithelial keratitis. They are mostly treated with acyclovir 3% ointment or ganciclovir 0.15% gel.

Other options:

Option A- Aspergillus fumigatus is a common agent of mycotic corneal ulcers. The slough is usually dry on examination, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation. Thick, immobile, hypopyon due to direct invasion of fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber can be seen. Satellite lesions may be present. Below is an image showing a fungal ulcer with a dry feathery border and hypopyon.

Local natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B are effective against aspergillus and fusarium.

Option C: Acanthamoeba keratitis is a protozoal corneal infection seen in soft contact lens users and individuals who swim or bathe in contaminated water. Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as a ring lesion or ring stromal infiltrate as shown below. They are treated with topical polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% and propamidine isethionate 0.1%.

 

Option D- Staphylococcus aureus is a common gram-positive and coagulase-positive organism causing bacterial keratitis. Stromal edema, folds in the Descemet membrane, and anterior uveitis are often seen.

An image of a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon is shown below.

They are usually treated with antibiotics like cefuroxime, vancomycin, or teicoplanin.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficient in this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency. 
Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, and night blindness. Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities, perianal, perigenital, and perioral regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A- Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. The lesion in the neck is characteristic of Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

 

Option C- Deficiency of riboflavin can present as anemia, corneal vascularization, mucocutaneous lesions, and personality changes. Milk and other dairy products are important dietary sources.

Option D- Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

Related Pearl: Metals as cofactors and prosthetic groups in enzymes

  • ALA dehydratase

questions.text: In developing countries like India, most children would have acquired their first episode of rotavirus diarrhea before the age of:
questions.solution:
In developing countries, 75% of the children acquire their episode of first rotavirus diarrhea before the age of 12 months. In developed countries, the first episode is delayed until the age of 2-5 years.

Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is most often seen in children aged 6-24 months.

Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe, dehydrating diarrhea in children aged <5 years globally. 

The universal occurrence of rotavirus infections shows the clean water supply and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on virus transmission. In tropical areas, rotavirus diarrhea occurs throughout the year.

Transmission primarily occurs through the fecal-oral route, person-to-person contact, or indirectly through fomites. Infected individuals shed very high concentrations of the virus (>1012 particles/gram) for many days in their stool and vomit.

Note: Bacterial pathogens causing acute diarrhoeal disease in children are enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), campylobacter jejuni, shigella, and vibrio cholerae 01.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).

choices.text: Cervical rib is one of the cause
Operative management is indicated in all cases
Adson and Halsted tests are provocative tests

questions.solution:
Operative management is not indicated in all cases of thoracic outlet syndrome. The indications of surgery are:

  • Failure of conservative management
  • Progressive neurologic symptoms
  • Prolonged ulnar or median nerve conduction velocities
  • Occlusion of the subclavian artery
  • Thrombosis of the axillary or subclavian vein

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to compression of the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicles, the first rib, and scalene muscles. 

The causes of TOS vary and can include abrupt movements, hypertrophy of the neck musculature, and anatomical variations in which the brachial plexus roots pass-through this musculature, cervical rib, edema, pregnancy, repeated overhead motions, or abnormal posture.

The neurological manifestations are more commonly seen in individuals with TOS. Patients typically experience upper limb pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness that is exacerbated by shoulder or neck movement. The compression of the subclavian artery leads to fatigue, weakness, coldness, upper extremity claudication, thrombosis, and paresthesia. Venous TOS, also known as Paget-Schroetter syndrome is characterized by edema, venous distension or effort thrombosis.

Generally, TOS is diagnosed clinically. CT, MRI, chest and cervical spine films can be done to identify the pathology. Doppler and vascular imaging can be done to determine the degree of vascular impairment. 

It can be diagnosed with nerve conduction studies to localize the area of slow nerve conduciton. The provocative tests for thoracic outlet syndrome include clinical maneuvers like the Adson test, Halsted test, Wright test, and Roos test.

Several treatment options are available like physical therapy and thrombolytic therapy.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female patient underwent breast conservation surgery due to a 4x4 cm lump in her right breast. The histopathology report showed high nuclear grade DCIS with necrosis and 5 mm margin clearance. Immunohistochemistry showed ER-negativity. What is the next best step in management?

DCIS- Ductal carcinoma-in-situ

ER- Estrogen receptor
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management would be total mastectomy according to the Van Nuys prognostic index (VNPI).

Van Nuys prognostic score for this patient is:

  • The size of the tumor is given as 4x4 cm (score 2)
  • 5 mm margin clearance (score 2)
  • High nuclear grade with necrosis (score 3) 
  • The age of the patient is 38 years (score 3)

The total score is 10 and hence total mastectomy is indicated after breast conservation surgery.

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is more common than lobular carcinoma in-situ. Histologically, DCIS is due to the proliferation of epithelium that lines the minor ducts resulting in papillary growth within the duct lumina. There are 4 morphological types of DCIS namely papillary, cribriform, solid, and comedo. 

Van Nuys system classifies ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on the following parameters:

  • Patient's age
  • Tumor size
  • Margin width
  • Nuclear grade 
  • Presence of microcalcification

In 2002, the Van Nuys Prognostic index was modified as the University of Southern California/VNPI (USC/VNPI).

Scoring system for USC/VNPI:

Parameters Score 1 Score 2 Score 3
Size(mm) ≤15 16-40 ≥41
Margin(mm) ≥10 1 - 9 <1
Class low or intermediate nuclear grade without necrosis low or intermediate nuclear grade with necrosis

high nuclear grade with or without necrosis.
Age(years >60 40-60 <40

The current recommendations for the management of DCIS according to this index are:

  • Excision alone for scores 4, 5, and 6
  • Excision plus radiotherapy for scores 7, 8, and 9
  • Mastectomy for scores 10, 11, and 12

Note: The type of microcalcification seen on imaging determines the nuclear grade of DCIS. While the linear branching type of microcalcification is associated with high nuclear grade, the fine granular type is associated with low nuclear grade.

Other options:

Option B: Adjuvant chemotherapy is not indicated in the treatment of DCIS

Option C: Adjuvant radiotherapy is indicated in DCIS patients with Van Nuys prognostic scores 7, 8, and 9.

Option D: Adjuvant tamoxifen therapy is indicated in DCIS patients with estrogen receptor-positive.

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and perianal itching. The mother said she noticed a white thread like structure in the child's clothes. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perianal pruritis at night time, excoriation of the skin around the anus is suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. 

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. They are oviparous. Man acquires infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. 

At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus and lays its sticky eggs on the perianal skin. This leads to pruritus and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

Since pinworms are rarely released in feces, fecal examination is not useful in the diagnosis. The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane is attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass side and examined microscopically.The image given below shows the NIH swab.

 

 

Another method of demonstrating eggs is the scotch tape method. Here, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides, and transferred to a glass slide. A drop of toluene is added and examined under the microscope.The below image shows the scotch tape method.

 

The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

Frequent hand washing, fingernail cleaning, regular bathing, and frequent washing of night clothes, and bed linen should be done. Infection can be treated with pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, or mebendazole as single-dose therapy.

Other options:

Option B: Ascaris lumbricoides causes infection when the egg containing the infective rhabditiform larva is swallowed. The eggs hatch in the duodenum to release the rhabditiform larvae, which then migrate to the liver via the portal vein, heart, and then to the lungs, pass up the respiratory tract, and are swallowed. They finally develop into adults in the small intestine. Here, the gravid females lay eggs, which are shed via the feces, and the cycle repeats. Definitive diagnosis is by demonstration of eggs in feces. The life cycle is shown below.

 

Option C: Ancylostoma duodenale or hookworm infects a person by direct penetration of the skin by filariform larvae. They develop into adult worms in the small intestine. Segmented eggs are passed in feces and these develop into filariform larva in the soil. They can cause severe local itching, cutaneous larva migrans, and respiratory symptoms. Adult hookworm disease is characterized by anemia, epigastric pain, dyspepsia, vomiting, and reddish black stools. Diagnosis is by demonstration of eggs or larvae in feces. The life cycle is shown below.

Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis infection is by direct penetration of the skin by the filariform larva or by autoinfection. The larvae enter lay eggs in the small intestine mucosa. The eggs hatch and release rhabditiform larvae which pass through feces into the soil and start another cycle. External autoinfection occurs when the larvae penetrate the perianal skin. Internal autoinfection occurs in immunocompromised patients. Here, the larvae mature to the infective form in the bowel itself. Diagnosis is by demonstration of rhabditiform larvae in feces.
