questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida woman at 34 weeks of gestation is reported to have an amniotic fluid index of 4 cm. Which of the following fetal anomaly can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index(AFI) of 4 cm is suggestive of oligohydramnios which can be associated with renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios is a condition where there is decreased production of amniotic fluid. Sonographically, it is defined when the single deepest pocket of liquor is <2 cm or when the amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm (less than 5 percentile).

The fetus begins producing urine between 8 - 11 weeks of gestation. However, it does not become a major part of the composition of amniotic fluid until the second trimester. For this reason, fetuses with kidney abnormalities do not become evident until after 18 weeks of gestation. 

Causes of Oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities: Amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta)
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal Anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • The infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia (mermaid syndrome).
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Consequently, polyhydramnios is defined as a deepest vertical pocket of more than 8 cm or an AFI of more than 24 cm. There are various mechanisms that can lead to polyhydramnios such as: 

  • Maternal causes
    • Diabetes(Overt diabetes/Gestational diabetes)
    • Cardiac diseases
    • Renal Diseases
  • Fetal causes
    • Neural tube defects
    • Anencephaly
    • Cleft lip/palate, micrognathia
    • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
    • Esophageal and duodenal atresia
    • Aneuploidy
    • Hydrops fetalis due to Rh alloimmunization, nonimmune hydrops, cardiothoracic anomalies, fetal cirrhosis and fetal TORCH infections, parvovirus B19 infection
    • Twin pregnancy, Twin to Twin transfusion syndrome
    • Bartter syndrome
    • Sacrococcygeal teratoma
    • High-output cardiac states
  • Placental causes
    • Chorangioma of placenta
       

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

questions.text: A child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek, which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. The image is showing the classical slapped cheek appearance. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations:

Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 1-2 weeks. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later, the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 

Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and paleness with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. 

Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent Parvovirus B19 infection in immunocompromised patients can cause chronic suppression of bone marrow and chronic anaemia, leading to pure red cell aplasia.

Maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

The diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made clinically and does not require investigations routinely. Detection of viral DNA in the blood by PCR or nucleic acid hybridisation may be done for immunocompromised cases or prenatal diagnosis of infection.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own. IVIG may be given to immunocompromised children.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with constant dribbling of urine. She has a history of prolonged labour in her previous pregnancy. She feels uncomfortable because her underwear is constantly wet.  Examination reveals excoriation of the genital area. Methylene blue - 3 swab test reveals staining of the middle swab. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is vesicovaginal fistula. 

Vesicovaginal fistula is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. 

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area. 

Per speculum examination must be performed to determine the extent of local tissue involvement and the number of fistulas. 

Investigations to be performed include

  • Urine culture and treatment of infection if required
  • Ultrasound of the kidney, ureter, and bladder
  • Intravenous pyelography
  • Cystoscopy with indigo carmine excretion test
  • Ureteric catheterization
  • The methylene blue-3 swab test confirms the VVF but also differentiates it from ureterovaginal and urethrovaginal fistula. Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  
    • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
    • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, as seen in the vesicovaginal fistula
    • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

Vesicovaginal fistula is treated surgically. It can be attempted after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside and clear the infection. After this, the Latzko procedure can be performed. Here, the vaginal epithelium around the fistula is removed and the edges are approximated. The Chassar Moir technique can also be attempted. Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured to two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 

Other options: 

Option A - Vesicouterine fistula is very rare and generally occurs after operative surgeries on the uterus. The patient is continent but has cyclical hematuria as the menstrual blood and urine mix. 

Option B - Ureteric fistula occur when there is direct injury to the ureter in the pelvis during gynecological procedures. In these cases, the women leak urine into the peritoneal cavity leading to abdominal symptoms of nausea, vomiting, distension, and ileus. 

Option D - Urethrovaginal fistula occurs when there's damage during obstetric surgeries. Here, the patient would be normally continent and dry but has dribbling urine from the vagina during or after micturition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a  3 months history of amenorrhea, headache,  vomiting, loss of libido, and galactorrhea. On examination, her vitals are within range but her eye examination shows bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following drug is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of prolactinoma of the pituitary. Among the given options, cabergoline is the preferred drug for this patient.

Prolactinoma: Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumor
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. The mainstay of treatment is medical management. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. 

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. It effectively suppresses prolactin secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or along with somatostatin analogs.

Another drug used in prolactinoma is bromocriptine. It is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline. The adverse effects of bromocriptine include hypotension and nausea.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman came with complaints of irregular postmenopausal bleeding, breast tenderness, and abdominal pain. Abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed an adnexal mass. A biopsy from the mass revealed the following picture. Which of the following statement is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Inhibin B is used as its tumor marker
Coffee bean nuclei are seen on microscopy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of the diagnosis as granulosa cell tumor. Activating mutations of the KIT gene are seen in patients with dysgerminoma and not seen in granulosa cell tumors.

The biopsy image given shows small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles known as Call-Exner bodies. The presence of such findings is diagnostic of granulosa cell tumors.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells that resemble the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The most common driver mutations found are in the FOXL2 gene, which encodes a transcription factor important for granulosa cell development.

It most commonly presents in adult women aged over 55years (postmenopausal women) and occurs less commonly in pre-pubertal girls. The clinical presentation varies as follows:

  • In prepubertal girls estrogen secreted from the granulosa cell tumor results in pseudo-precocious puberty. There is hypertrophy of the breasts and myohyperplasia of the uterus.
  • In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, postmenopausal irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. Abdominal pain and distension can occur due to enlarging tumor.
  • Occasionally, granulosa cell tumors produce androgens, masculinizing the patient

Gross examination: These are usually unilateral tumors. The cut section is soft and has a yellowish appearance due to intracellular lipids.

Microscopic examination: Call- Exner bodies which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles are diagnostic. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen. These are small, cuboidal to polygonal cells that grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. Occasionally a thecoma component may be present as clusters or sheets of cuboidal to polygonal cells.

Detection and measurement of inhibin B are useful in diagnosing granulosa cell tumors and behave as a tumor marker. Measurement of inhibin B is more accurate than inhibin A.

Given below is a histopathological image depicting the Call-Exner bodies:

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary

Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: In a village of 2000 people, you diagnosed a 10-year-old boy having diarrhea with cholera. 19 more similar cases occurred in the same village, out of which 5 succumbed to death. Which of the following parameters can be used to assess the killing power of the causative agent in the given outbreak?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate represents the killing power of the disease.

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

The case-fatality rate is thus the proportion of people with a particular disease who die from that disease. It is a measure of the severity of the disease, and the deadliness of an outbreak, and may be used to evaluate any public health measures implemented. It is closely related to the virulence of the agent.

Due to changes in the agent, host, and environmental factors in different epidemics, the case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics. It is typically used in acute infectious diseases. Eg: Food poisoning, measles, cholera, etc. 

Other options:

Option B: Proportional mortality rate is used to know the proportion of total death due to any particular cause. It does not indicate the risk of contracting or dying from the disease.

 

Option C: Crude death rate measures the rate at which the death is occurring from different causes in a given population, during a specified period. 

Crude death rate = number of deaths during the year X 1000/ Mid-year population

Option D: Specific death rate is used to identify particular groups or groups "at-risk" for preventive action. They help in comparison between different causes of death within the same population. 

Specific death rate due to cancer = Number of death from cancer during a calendar year X 1000/ Mid-year population

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: A study was conducted among the postgraduate students in a medical college to find out the time taken by them to complete various tasks in different clinical departments. Which management technique is being applied for this analysis?
questions.solution:
The management technique that is being applied for the above study is work sampling.

Work sampling is a quantitative management technique.

Work sampling refers to systematic observation and recording of the activities of one or more individuals. It is done at predetermined or random intervals. It mainly includes analyzing the type of activities performed and the time needed to perform the same.

These studies have been done on doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and laboratory technicians. This technique can find the appropriateness of the current staff, job description, and training. This may standardize the methods of performing activities and determine the manpower needed in an organization.

Management is the purposeful and effective use of resources such as manpower, materials, and finances for the fulfillment of a pre-determined objective. They consist of four basic activities: planning, organizing, communicating, and monitoring.

Management techniques are of two types:

Quantitative methods

Methods based on behavioral sciences
  • Cost-Benefit analysis
  • Cost-Effective analysis
  • Cost-Accounting
  • Input-Output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis
    • Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)
    • Critical Path Method (CPM)
  • Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making
  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Other options:

Option A: Cost-effective analysis is a management technique in which the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in terms of the results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).

Option C- Critical pathway method is a type of network analysis technique. The longest path in the network is called the critical path. If any delay in activity along the critical pathway, the entire study will be delayed.

Option D- Input-output analysis is an economic technique to analyze the amount of input needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities that consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time). Output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: An anesthetist while intubating a patient, decided to use a new type of muscle relaxant known as gantacurium. Which of the following is true regarding the metabolism of this new drug?
questions.solution:
Gantacurium is metabolized by inactive cysteine adduct formation.

Gantacurium is a novel non-depolarizing muscle relaxant. It belongs to a class of drugs called chlorofumarates. It is an ultra-short acting muscle relaxant with onset within 1-2 minutes and lasting for 5-10 minutes. 

It undergoes non-enzymatic degradation by two mechanisms:

  • Inactive cysteine adduct formation - a rapid process
  • Ester hydrolysis - a slow process

The formation of cysteine adducts alters the structure of gantacurium such that it can no longer interact with post-junctional acetylcholine receptors. As a result, the inactivated compounds of gantacurium have no neuromuscular properties. 

Administration of gantacurium at doses three to four times higher than the effective dose(ED95) is attributed to the release of histamine and its subsequent side effects. Reversal of gantacurium induced neuromuscular-blockade can be accelerated by the administration of exogenous cysteine as well as edrophonium.

Other options:

Option A: Cisatracurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that undergoes Hofmann elimination.

Option C: Pancuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that undergoes hepatic metabolism.

Option D: Mivacurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase.

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: A 42-year-old asymptomatic woman is diagnosed with COVID 19 infection. Her CT chest is unremarkable. She was incidentally diagnosed with gall stones 2 months back and wishes to get an elective surgery done. As per the American Society of Anesthesiologists, how long is the suggested wait time for elective surgeries after diagnosis of COVID 19?
questions.solution:
For asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic COVID 19 positive patients, elective surgeries can be planned 4 weeks from the date of diagnosis of COVID-19.

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) recommended waiting time for elective surgery from the date of diagnosis of COVID-19 infection are as follows:  

  • 4 weeks for an asymptomatic patient or recovery from only mild, non-respiratory symptoms
  • 6 weeks for symptomatic patients with cough/dyspnea not requiring hospitalization
  • 8 to 10 weeks for symptomatic patients who required hospitalization and/or diabetic patients and/or immunocompromised
  • 12 weeks for patients that had to be admitted to the ICU due to COVID 19  

The American College of Surgeons recommends non-operative management, if feasible and safe for the patient in surgical emergencies in a COVID-19 positive patient or is at high clinical suspicion of COVID-19.

If the surgery is required in such patients, then proper personal protective equipment should be utilized and precautions to be taken to protect the health care team.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with excessive bleeding during her menstrual cycles for the last year. Laboratory evaluation reveals iron deficiency anemia. Abdominal examination reveals an enlarged uterus corresponding to 14 weeks with an irregular contour.  Her ultrasound is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with menorrhagia, iron deficiency anemia, and the irregular, enlarged uterus is uterine leiomyoma.

The image shows an ultrasound with a large fibroid within the uterine cavity. 

Leiomyoma or fibroid uterus are slow-growing, benign tumors of the uterus that affect women of reproductive age. They occur due to smooth muscle proliferation in response to estrogen and progesterone produced by the body. 

Conditions with hormone excess such as reproductive age group, hyperestrogenism, pregnancy, and oral contraceptives are associated with increased growth of fibroids. 

Fibroids are formed in the intramural (interstitial), submucous, and subserous parts of the uterus. They can also form in the extrauterine structures such as round ligament, uterosacral ligament, vagina, and vulva. 

Patients usually present with menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, infertility, recurrent abortions, pain, pressure symptoms, abdominal mass, and vaginal discharge. However, many women are asymptomatic. 

Fibroids can undergo secondary changes such as atrophy, calcareous degeneration, and red degeneration. 

Other options: 

Option A - Endometrial carcinoma is unlikely to cause irregular uterine contour. In addition, it usually occurs in older women and presents as post-menopausal bleeding. 

Option B - Pregnant uterus would also be enlarged, but it would be soft, and round. She would also have a history of amenorrhea. In addition, an ultrasound will reveal the fetal anatomy. 

Option D - Uterine adenomyosis is a condition seen frequently in elderly women (Age > 40 years), which is characterized by endometrial islands in the wall of the uterus. It is similar in presentation to fibroids except that in adenomyosis, the uterus would be uniformly enlarged and would not be more than 12 to 14 weeks gestation in size. 

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: Which of the following is not a draining tributary of the azygos system of veins?
questions.solution:
1st right posterior intercostal vein is not a draining tributary of the azygos system of veins. 1st right posterior intercostal vein drains to the right brachiocephalic vein. 

The azygos system of veins drains the thoracic wall and the upper lumbar region. It forms a connecting channel between the superior and inferior venae cavae. It occupies the upper part of the posterior abdominal wall and the posterior mediastinum. It also connects the portal, caval system, and vertebral venous systems.

It is formed by the union of the lumbar azygos, right subcostal and right ascending lumbar veins. It enters the thorax by passing through the aortic opening in the diaphragm. It ascends up to the 4th thoracic vertebra, arching forward over the root of the right lung, and ends by joining the posterior aspect of the superior vena cava before piercing the pericardium. 

Tributaries of the azygous system of veins:

  • The right superior intercostal vein (Option A) is formed by the union of the 2,3 and 4th posterior intercostal veins.
  • 5-11th right posterior intercostal veins (Option B)
  • Hemi-azygos vein at the level of the lower border of the 8th thoracic vertebra.
  • Accessory hemiazygos vein at the level of the upper border of the 8th thoracic vertebra.
  • Right bronchial vein (Option D), near the terminal end of the azygos vein
  • Several oesophageal, mediastinal, pericardial veins. 

The hemi-azygos vein is formed by the union of the left lumbar azygos, left ascending lumbar, and left subcostal veins.

9th to 11th left posterior intercostal veins and esophageal veins drain into the hemi-azygous vein. It is also known as the inferior hemi-azygos vein.

The accessory hemiazygos vein is also known as the superior hemiazygos vein. 5th to 8th left posterior intercostal veins and sometimes the left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein.

Given below is a schematic representation of the venous drainage of the thoracic wall:

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding vitamin D synthesis?
  1. Synthesis occurs sequentially in the skin, liver, kidney
  2. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin
  3. 25 hydroxylase acts in the kidney
  4. 1-α-hydroxylase is present in the liver
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1 and 2.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin. 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis:

Step 1: In the skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.

Step 2: In the liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol). The enzyme responsible for this is 25 hydroxylase. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3: In the kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to either 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

The synthesis of vitamin D is summarized in the image below.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome. The physician performs a clinical test, where direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs. Which of the following clinical tests is being performed?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is Durkan's test or carpal compression test.

Clinical tests in carpal tunnel syndrome include the reproduction of sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pain by performing the following tests:

  • Durkan's test - By applying direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds.
  • Tinel's test (sign) - By percussing the median nerve.
  • Phalen's test - By holding the wrist in flexion for about 60 seconds.

The following image shows Phalen's test:

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies can be done in patients with atypical symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome. The tests will show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist.

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually presents at an age of 40-50 years. The common risk factors are pregnancy, rheumatoid disease, renal failure, and gout.

Most of the patients present with burning pain, tingling, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve. The symptoms worsen with activity and at night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed and shaking the arm relieve the pain.

Night pain and pregnancy-related symptoms can be reduced by using splints to prevent wrist flexion. Temporary relief from pain can be attained using steroid injection and is a diagnostic tool also.

In patients with an intermediate and chronic syndrome, an early carpal tunnel release can be performed. This surgery is beneficial in most patients and maximum improvement is seen in 6 months after the release.

Other options:

Option D- Semmes-Weinstein monofilament test measures the response to a touching sensation of the monofilaments using a numerical quantity. It is used to detect peripheral nerve injuries and compression syndromes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of heartburn and regurgitation of food for the past few years. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy showed the following histopathological finding.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This condition occurs as a complication of GERD
Obese white men are at a higher risk
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma
It affects the area above the gastroesophageal junction

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy findings showing intestinal metaplasia are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus which increases the risk of adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, and it is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60 years represent the highest-risk group.

It is characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells. The greatest concern in Barrett's esophagus is that it confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

A histological image showing goblets cells is given below:

On endoscopy, Barrett's is recognized as areas of red, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction. Such areas alternate with normal pale squamous esophageal mucosa. Diagnostic confirmation is by endoscopic biopsy. Biopsy reveals intestinal metaplasia characterized by the presence of goblet cells. Goblet cells are seen as cells with pale mucous vacuoles that stain blue. 

 

The sequential changes seen due to intestinal metaplasia in Barrett's is depicted in the histological image given below:

questions.text: A single mother is taking care of her twin infants(one male, one female). She generally artificially feeds them. Which among the following points, in this case, is not a criterion for identifying as 'at-risk' infants?
questions.solution:
A female child is not mentioned as a criterion for identifying 'at-risk' infants.

The following are considered as criteria to identify 'at-risk' infants:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with protein-energy malnutrition, diarrhea
  • Working mother or single parent

The 'at-risk' infants contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality. Hence, a special intensive care, is usually suggested for these infants.

questions.text: A multigravid woman with a previous classical cesarean section presents, in the current pregnancy, with dull aching pain and a sense of something giving way at the height of the contraction. Examination reveals loss of uterine contour and palpable fetal parts. She also has vaginal bleeding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this scenario is uterine scar rupture. 

Uterine rupture is defined as the separation of all uterine layers beyond 28 weeks of gestation. Scar rupture in this patient is most likely due to a previous history of classical Cesarean section. The scar in the classical C section is weak which is more prone to rupture during future pregnancies. 

Uterine rupture can occur spontaneously, due to scar rupture, or iatrogenically. Spontaneous causes of uterine rupture are rare. They occur due to previous damage to the uterus as seen in dilation and curettage, manual removal of placenta, Couvelaire uterus, or in grand multiparous women. Women who have had surgical management of uterine malformations are also at risk. Scar rupture occurs in women who have had previous uterine surgery such as a cesarean section, myomectomy, cornual resection of ectopic pregnancy, or hysterotomy. The incidence is lowest with lower segment cesarean section and highest with classical section. Iatrogenic rupture can occur due to excessive administration of oxytocin, use of prostaglandins, forcible external version, or trauma to the abdomen. 

Clinical features include stoppage of uterine contractions, suprapubic pain, maternal breathlessness and tachycardia, bradycardia in the fetus, acute onset scar tenderness, and in severe cases, shock and hypotension are observed. 

Other options: 

Option A - Placental abruption would also present with acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. However, palpable fetal parts is suggestive of uterine rupture.

Option B - Placenta previa would present with painless bleeding per vagina. 

Option D - Scar dehiscence is disruption of part of the scar (not the entire length) with intact fetal membranes and minimal bleeding per vagina. There is no disruption of the visceral peritoneum, and the fetus, placenta, and umbilical cord remain within the uterine cavity.

questions.text: The number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate is called:
questions.solution:
The number of daughters a newborn girl will bear in her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates is called Net Reproductive Ratio (NRR).

NRR is a demographic indicator and NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately attaining the 2-child norm in India. If the NRR is less than one, it indicates that the reproductive capacity of the population is below the replacement level.

Other options:

Option A- Gross reproductive rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Option C- Total fertility rate is the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass-through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group.

Option D- General fertility rate is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods. 

The following image shows a unilateral vocal nodule:

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with slowly progressive swelling and pain in the right leg. His x-ray of the right leg is given below. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen reveals epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with slowly progressing swelling and pain in the leg, x-ray showing multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis, and epithelial cells seen in a fibrous stroma on microscopy is suggestive of adamantinoma.

Adamantinoma is a rare malignant tumor. Most cases appear in the lower extremities and classically in the tibial diaphysis. It is most often seen in the second to fourth decade of life. The patient usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling. Intralesional or marginal excision causes local recurrence, so complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice. 

The image below shows an x-ray and gross specimen of an adamantinoma.

Option B - Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. It has a bimodal age distribution—at adolescence and in the seventh decade. It is typically seen in metaphyseal regions of the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. 

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance. Microscopy shows osteoid production from malignant spindle cells and marked nuclear pleomorphism.

The x-ray below shows the sunburst appearance of osteosarcoma.

Option C - Osteoclastoma also known as giant cell tumor (GCT). It is a locally aggressive benign neoplasm, most often seen between 20-40 years of age. Most of the cases appear in the epiphysis of lower extremities, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. Microscopy shows multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells.

Rarely malignant transformations may occur in GCT. 

The image below shows an x-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

Option D - Osteoid osteoma is a benign neoplasm most often seen in men aged 10-20 years. Most of the cases appear in the lower extremities commonly in the femur and tibia. A patient typically presents with pain that worsens at night and gets relieved on aspirin. Microscopy shows a central nidus composed of highly vascularized bone and intertwined osteoid. 

The below x-ray shows osteoid osteoma demonstrating a zone of dense sclerosis surrounding a radiolucent nidus.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the treatment of gout except:

choices.text: Colchicine is used in acute gout and in its prophylaxis
Hypersensitivity is the most common adverse effect of allopurinol
Oxypurinol is an orphan drug used in allopurinol intolerant patient
Febuxostat is a purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor

questions.solution:
Febuxostat is a non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor.

Febuxostat is a selective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase thereby reducing xanthine and uric acid. It does not affect any other enzymes of the purine or pyrimidine metabolic pathway. It is indicated in the treatment of hyperuricemia in gouty patients. Febuxostat is more potent than allopurinol. 

The adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, diarrhea, joint pain, and rash. A flare in the gout attack can be seen during the initiation of therapy due to a decrease in serum uric acid levels that results in the mobilization of uric acid from tissue deposits.

Drugs used in the management of gout can be classified as:

Drugs that relieve inflammation and pain- These drugs are useful in the management of acute attacks of gout. They are:

  • NSAIDs- They mainly exert their antiinflammatory action by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX). This enzyme converts arachidonic acid to prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins
  • Colchicine- It arrests the cell division by interfering with microtubule and spindle formation. This results in decreased neutrophil recruitment decreased neutrophil motility and decreased release of chemotactic factors. 
  • Glucocorticoids- These drugs bind to the nuclear receptors and decrease the transcription of genes for COX-2, inducible NOS (NOS2), inflammatory cytokines, collagenase, etc, that are responsible for inflammation.

Drugs that inhibit urate formation- These drugs inhibit urate formation by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. Eg. allopurinol and febuxostat. The most common adverse effect of allopurinol is hypersensitivity reactions. Oxypurinol is a metabolite of allopurinol and inhibits xanthine oxidase thus reducing uric acid production. It is an orphan drug and is used in patients intolerant to allopurinol.  

Uricosuric drugs- These drugs increase the excretion of uric acid. Important ones are:

  • Probenecid- it inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting organic acid transporter (OATs), principally URAT-1.
  • Benzbromarone- It increases uric acid secretion by reversibly inhibiting urate–anion exchanger in the proximal tubule
  • Lesinurad- It inhibits the URAT-1 and OAT-4 transporters, thereby reducing renal uric acid reabsorption.

Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive.

questions.text: You have been posted as an intern in the labor room where you have to monitor the number, duration, and intensity of uterine contractions in a 34-year-old, G2 P1 with a term pregnancy. She has moderate contractions. How long do they last?
questions.solution:
Moderate uterine contractions lasts for 20-40 seconds.

  • Weak contractions: <20 s
  • Moderate contraction: 20–40 s
  • Strong contractions: >40 s

Uterine contractions have to be documented in the partograph based on the number of contractions palpated in 10 minutes and the duration of each contraction. The partograph has to be updated every 30 minutes. 

Uterine contractions are felt as intermittent pain per abdomen. They are associated with the hardening of the uterus. At first, they are not strong enough to cause discomfort and come at an interval of 15-30 minutes lasting 30 seconds. As labor progresses, the interval shortens. 

True labor pains are characterized by painful contractions at regular intervals, increasing frequency, intensity, and duration of contractions, association with 'show', progressive effacement and dilation of the cervix, the descent of the presenting part, formation of 'bag of forewaters' and not relieved by enema or sedatives. 

They have to be differentiated from false labor pains which are dull in nature, confined to lower abdomen and groin, not associated with hardening of the uterus, relieved by enema or sedative.

Braxton-Hicks contractions are painless, irregular, and do not affect the cervix. 

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: You are involved in a study about various types of zoonotic diseases. Which of the following is an example of a metazoonosis?
questions.solution:
Plague is an example of metazoonosis.

Metazoonoses are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. In the invertebrate vectors, the infective agent develops or multiplies, and after an extrinsic period of incubation (prepatent period) transmission to another vertebrate host occurs. Examples include arboviral infections, plague, and schistosomiasis

Zoonoses are diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from other vertebrates to man. They can be transmitted from either animals or other humans.

Zoonoses are classified based on their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropo-zoonoses are infections transmitted to man from lower vertebrate animals, e.g. rabies.
  • Zoo-anthroponoses are infections transmitted to lower vertebrate animals from a man, e.g. tuberculosis of cat and monkey
  • Amphixenoses are infections maintained in both men and lower vertebrate animals that may be transmitted in either direction, e.g. staphylococcal infections

Related Pearl: Classification of Zoonoses

Classification based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification based on life cycle if infecting agent is:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact/fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission.

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

More than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle. Invertebrate hosts will not suffice.

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors. Inside the invertebrate, the infective agent develops / multiplies. After an extrinsic period of incubation, the infective agent is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir.

Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came to the orthopedic outpatient unit for follow-up of his right tibial fracture that was managed with a plaster cast. The doctor observes that the patient lifts his right leg high to take a step. On examination, the right foot is inverted and there is no sensation perceived on the whole dorsum of the right foot. Which nerve is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The nerve affected in this patient is the common fibular nerve (common peroneal nerve)

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th - 5th lumbar and 1st-2nd sacral ventral rami. The sciatic nerve divides into the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve.

The common fibular nerve runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves.

Superficial fibular nerve 

Motor innervation: 

  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis

Sensory innervation: 

  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

Deep fibular nerve

Motor innervation:

  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius

Sensory innervation:

  • The first interdigital space

History of plaster cast implies compression of the common fibular nerve resulting in foot drop (which causes high stepping gait), loss of eversion of the foot, and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot.

Other options:

Option B- Superficial fibular nerve causes inverted foot and sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot but not foot drop.

Option C- Deep fibular nerve causes sensory loss only in the first interdigital cleft. It also causes weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and extension of all toes. 

Option D- Sural nerve gives cutaneous innervation to the posterolateral aspect of the distal third of the leg and the lateral aspect of the foot, heel and ankle.

questions.text: Which of the following about catatonia is false

choices.text: Catatonia is seen exclusively with schizophrenia

questions.solution:
Catatonia is mostly seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses, including schizophrenia

The features of catatonia are:

  1. Mutism: Complete absence of speech
  2. Rigidity: Maintenance of a rigid posture against efforts to be moved
  3. Negativism: An apparently motiveless resistance to all commands and attempts to be moved, or doing just the opposite.
  4. Posturing: Voluntary assumption of an inappropriate and often bizarre posture for long periods of time
  5. Stupor: Akinesis (no movement) with mutism but with evidence of relative preservation of conscious awareness
  6. Echolalia: Repetition, echo or mimicking of phrases or words heard
  7. Echopraxia: Repetition, echo or mimicking of actions observe
  8. Waxy flexibility: Parts of the body can be placed in positions that will be maintained for long periods of time, even if very uncomfortable; flexible like wax.
  9. Ambitendency: Due to ambivalence, conflicting impulses and tentative actions are made, but no goal directed action occurs, e.g. on asking to take out tongue, the tongue is slightly protruded but taken back again.
  10. Other signs such as mannerisms, stereotypes (verbal and behavioural), automatic obedience (commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature) and verbigeration (incomprehensible speech).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding parenteral administration of alteplase?

choices.text: It increases the formation of plasminogen
It is indicated in hemorrhagic stroke
It can cause bleeding, which can be counteracted by aminocaproic acid
Alteplase has the advantage of activating free plasminogen

questions.solution:
All thrombolytics can cause bleeding, which may be counteracted by the administration of antifibrinolytics, such as aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid.  

Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator and activates plasminogen bound to fibrin, and catalyses the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, resulting in increased formation of plasmin(Option A). This results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus(thrombolysis). It is indicated in pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, severe deep vein thrombosis, ascending thrombophlebitis, acute ischemic stroke and acute myocardial infarction.  

Alteplase has the advantage of only activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) but not free plasminogen (option D). 

Contraindications of alteplase:

  • Risk of bleeding(including intracranial hemorrhage (Option B), subarachnoid hemorrhage, and those with active internal bleeding)
  • Recent intracranial, intraspinal surgery or head trauma in previous 3 months
  • Intracranial neoplasm, arteriovenous malformation, or aneurysm
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Severe uncontrolled hypertension

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: A patient is brought to the primary health center with a history of snakebite. The area of the bite is painful and appears red and swollen. From his description, the snake that bit him had a triangular head with a V-shaped mark, as shown in the image below. All of the following statements regarding this snake bite are true, except ___.

choices.text: Death is due to shock and hemorrhage
Persistent bleeding from bite site is noticed
Bleeding and clotting time are prolonged

questions.solution:
From the patient's description and the image, the snake is most likely Russell's viper. The victims of Russell's viper may become oliguric within a few hours of the bite suggesting renal ischemia.

The Russell's viper has a flat and triangular head with a V-shaped mark, white in color, with the angle of the V pointing forwards. Along the back, it has three rows of diamond-shaped spots. Other points of identification include broad plates on its belly, the small scales on the head, and a shield beneath the tail divided into two rows. It is commonly found throughout India.

Russell's viper venom contains two proteases that affect the blood-clotting cascade. Though more than half the victims have minimal or no poisoning, few develop serious generalized poisoning. At the spot where venom is injected, the patient develops severe pain and the area around the bite becomes red and painful. Persistent bleeding from the bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in some hours which progressively involves the entire limb. Skin temperature is raised. Intravascular hemolysis may lead to hemoglobinuria which progresses to renal failure.

Since the venom affects the blood-clotting cascade, the bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. Patients may develop hemorrhagic syndrome due to bleeding from various sites like gums, rectum, etc. Death is usually due to hemorrhagic shock.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Severe
    • Edema and necrosis
  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

Sea snake:

Related Pearl: Identification of Poisonous Snakes

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presented with a retroperitoneal mass. The biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed amplification of p53 inhibitor MDM2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a well-differentiated liposarcoma.

The biopsy image shows mature adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (inlet). This along with amplification of MDM2 and the location of the mass confirms the diagnosis of well-differentiated liposarcoma.

Liposarcoma: It is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in the 6th to 7th decade of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum.

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes:

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes and scattered spindle cells with hyperchromatic nuclei as shown in the image below. It is associated with the amplification of p53 inhibitor MDM2.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: It is associated with t(12;16). It contains an abundant basophilic extracellular matrix with branching capillaries. Few immature adipocytes are found scattered within the matrix as show below. 
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and a few immature adipocytes as shown below. These have ill-defined complex karyotypes.

Among the three subtypes, the pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignancy behavior.

Other options:

Option B - Lipomas are the most common soft tissue tumor in adults. They present as a well-encapsulated mass of mature adipocytes as shown below.  It usually arises in the subcutis of the proximal extremities and trunk at around 40-60 years of age.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty in breathing. The flow-volume curve after spirometry in the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Pink line - Patient's response
Green dashed lines - Normal response
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The flow-volume curve of the above (patient 1) shows decreased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right. This is seen in restrictive lung disease. Airflow is greater than normal at comparable lung volumes because the increased elastic recoil of the lungs holds the airways open.

Asthma, COPD, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow patterns. Although all airflow is diminished, expiratory prolongation predominates, and mean expiratory flow < mean inspiratory flow. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to the left.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

 

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung directly related to the intensity and duration of exposure. 

Asbestos fibers induce oxidative injury due to the generation of reactive oxygen species by the transition metals on the surface of the fibers as well as from cells engaged in phagocytosis. These mechanisms result in lung fibrosis.

Irregular or linear opacities initially in the lower lung fields are the hallmark of asbestosis in chest radiographs. A ground glass appearance in the lung fields may be seen.

The chest X-ray below shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques consistent with asbestos-related pleural disease:

 

No specific therapy is available for asbestosis. They are managed with supportive therapy. The most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure is lung cancer. Pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma are also associated with asbestos exposure. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Emphysema and asthma are obstructive lung disorders. In these conditions, the flow-volume loop would be a scooped-out curve.

Option D: Vocal cord paralysis causes variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction. The flow-volume loop would have a flat inspiratory curve.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

questions.text: Identify the vessel marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the MR angiography of cerebral circulation. The structure marked is the anterior cerebral artery which is a branch of the internal carotid artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Pepsinogen is secreted by which of the following marked cells in the gastric gland from the body of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Pepsinogen is secreted by chief cells marked as 4.

Chief cells are identified by their location towards the base of the gland. These cells secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase.

The structure marked 1 in the region of the isthmus of a gastric gland. Mucous neck cells and stem cells are present in this region.

The structure marked 2 is the parietal cell (oxyntic cell). It is characterized by the presence of canaliculi. The cell has numerous mitochondria because it is actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid.

The structure marked 3 is the enterochromaffin-like cell (ECL). It is identified by its location in the subepithelial region. The function of this cell is to release histamine which in turn stimulates the parietal cells to secrete HCL. The ECL is stimulated by gastrin secreted by G cells from the pylorus and acetylcholine secreted by the vagus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida delivers a child by cesarean section. The mother's blood group is O negative, and the newborn's blood group is A positive. All the following complications are more likely to occur in her second pregnancy, except __________.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Rh alloimmunization. Potter's syndrome is not a complication of this condition. 

Potter's syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the changes in physical appearances of neonates due to oligohydramnios caused by renal agenesis. It is characterized by limb deformities, pulmonary hypoplasia, and a flattened face. 

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. It occurs in two stages. First, sensitization occurs during the first pregnancy, and then immunization occurs. Sensitization occurs during situations of fetomaternal bleeds.

Examples of these situations:

  • Miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, hydatidiform mole, intrauterine fetal demise
  • Amniocentesis, embryoreduction, cordocentesis
  • Placenta previa with bleeding, abruption of the placenta
  • Delivery of an Rh-positive infant to an Rh-negative mother

It can also occur during the third stage of labor, manual removal of the placenta, and after a cesarean section. 

The antibodies formed as a result of immunization are IgM and IgG. However, only IgG antibodies are small enough to cross the placenta and cause hemolytic disease in the fetus. The three manifestations of the hemolytic disease include hydrops fetalis, icterus gravis neonatorum, and congenital anemia of the newborn. 

Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of Rh hemolytic disease in the fetus. There is widespread erythrocyte destruction leading to anemia, anoxemia, and metabolic acidosis. This leads to hepatic injury, causing hypoproteinemia and subsequently generalized edema, ascites, and hydrothorax. 

The following image shows a stillborn baby with hydrops fetalis. 

Icterus gravis neonatorum is a condition in which a baby is born without jaundice but develops it within 24 hours of life. In this condition, hemolysis occurs while the fetus is in utero, and the bilirubin is excreted in amniotic fluid. Once the cord is clamped, the hemolysis continues and icterus becomes apparent. 

Congenital anemia of the newborn is the mild version of Rh incompatibility. Here, there is mild hemolysis without clinically evident jaundice. 

Rh immunization can be prevented by the administration of Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) intramuscularly after childbirth. It should ideally be administered within 72 hours or preferably earlier after delivery or abortion. The dose can be calculated using the Kleihauer-Betke test.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with malaise, fever, a cutaneous ulcer, and preauricular lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with tularemia. Which among the following is a vector that transmits the disease?
questions.solution:
The vector that transmits tularemia is a hard tick.

Hard ticks are ectoparasites of vertebrate animals. They mainly transmit tularemia, tick typhus, and Kyasanur forest disease.

The dorsal surface of a hard tick is covered by scutum which is made up of chitin. This is absent in soft ticks. The head of the hard tick is at the anterior end. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks are:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g. Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis

Tularemia is a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis. It is a gram-negative bacillus and a category A bioterrorism agent. It is a disease of rabbits and rodents. The most common mode of transmission is by direct contact with rodents or tick bites. They manifest as flu-like symptoms with cutaneous ulceration and preauricular lymphadenitis.

Other options:

Option A- Soft tick mainly transmits Q fever and relapsing fever.

Option C- Blackfly mainly transmits onchocerciasis.

Option D- Sandfly mainly transmits kala-azar and oriental sore. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient who recently moved here from Peru was suspected to have Chaga's disease. Which is the drug used for the treatment of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The drug used in the treatment of Chaga's disease is benznidazole. 

Chagas disease or American trypanosomiasis is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted by the Reduviid bug (also known as the kissing bug). It is endemic to North, Central, and South America.

Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms-

  • Epimastigotes- in the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes- in the bloodstream, it is the infective form.
  • Amastigotes- Intracellular form, seen predominantly in the heart muscle, parasympathetic ganglia, etc. 

It is introduced into the host when infective trypomastigotes from the infected Reduviid bug feces are implanted into the skin due to rubbing or scratching. It can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, organ transplantation, or across the placenta. 

Following this, acute Chagas disease is seen which may be asymptomatic or be characterized by-

  • Fever
  • Regional lymphadenitis
  • Localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site called chagoma
  • Unilateral swelling of the eyelids is known as the Romaña's sign. 

Some patients may progress to a chronic stage that may include-

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with fibrosis leading to arrhythmias and sudden death
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis may be established by demonstrating the parasite in the blood smear, CSF, or other body fluids, PCR, or by serology.

Chagas disease is managed by benznidazole 2.5mg/kg BD or nifurtimox 2mg/kg QID for 60 days. Benznidazole is better tolerated in nifurtimox in adults. In adults with chronic cardiomyopathy, benznidazole has no impact on disease progression and mortality risk.

Other options-

Option A: Pyrantel pamoate is effective for the treatment of pinworm, Ascaris, Trichostrongylus Orientalis infections, and hookworm.

Option B: Albendazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of hydatid disease and cysticercosis. It is also used in the treatment of pinworm, hookworm, ascariasis, trichuriasis, and strongyloidiasis.

Option D: Mebendazole is used in ascariasis, trichuriasis, hookworm, pinworm infections, and other helminthic infections.

Given below is an image of Romaña's sign.
