questions.text: You are a molecular biochemist working on genetic elements and the organization of human recombinant chimeric DNA (cDNA). In a sample of extracted DNA element, you determine the percentage of thymine residues to be 22%. What would be the expected percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 28%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species,

Purines = Pyrimidines

Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 22%, therefore adenine is also 22%.

Hence adenine + thymine = 44% and Guanine + cytosine = 56%. 

No of Guanine = No of Cytosine, so the percentage of cytosine = 56/2 = 28%.

Chimeric DNA (also known as recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant.
 
The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:
  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and stem cell therapy

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with complaints of itching, pain, and foul-smelling watery discharge from her right ear. Otoscopy shows a black filamentous growth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is otomycosis. 

Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear caused commonly by Aspergillus niger, A.fumigatus, or Candida albicans. It is frequently seen in tropical areas and in individuals who use antibiotic drops to treat otitis media/ otitis externa.

Patients present with intense pruritus, discomfort, pain, blocked sensation in the ear, and foul-smelling watery discharge. Otoscopy will show a fungal mass whose appearance depends on the causative organism. Aspergillus niger can be seen as a black-headed, filamentous growth. Aspergillus fumigatus presents as a pale blue or green mass. Candida appears as a white, creamy mass in the ear.

Aural toileting and topical antifungal agents are the primary treatment. Nystatin, clotrimazole, and povidone-iodine are the commonly used antifungals. 2% salicylic acid in alcohol works as a keratolytic to remove the superficial layers of the epidermis along with the fungal mycelia.

Other options:

Option B: Diffuse otitis externa occurs due to bacterial infection of the external ear. It presents as severe pain worsening with jaw movement, discharge of purulent material, and conductive hearing loss. In the chronic phase, meatal skin can undergo scaling and fissuring. 

Option C: Otitis externa hemorrhagica is probably viral in origin. It presents with severe pain and blood-stained discharge due to rupture of hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and meatus.

Option D: Malignant otitis externa occurs due to infection by pseudomonas commonly in diabetics and patients with immunosuppression. Symptoms are similar to otitis externa but examination will reveal granulations in the external auditory canal. It can cause facial nerve paralysis and has a high tendency to spread.

Related Pearl: Eponyms of the ear

Eponym

Description

Boxer’s/ Cauliflower ear

Organized hematoma of pinna

Surfer’s ear

Exostosis

Swimmer’s ear

Diffuse otitis externa

questions.text: A 30-year-old man underwent elective cholecystectomy. The cut specimen is seen below. The calculi observed is not associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pigmented gall stones and they are not associated with rapid weight reduction.

Pigment gallstones represent complex mixtures of insoluble and inorganic calcium salts with unconjugated bilirubin. Disorders with elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin increase the risk of developing pigmented gallstones. The various conditions associated with increase risk of pigmented gallstones are:

  • Demography: Asians more than Westerners, rural more than urban
  • Chronic hemolytic syndromes
  • Biliary infection with E.coli, Ascaris lumbricoides, and C. sinensis
  • Ileal disease
  • Ileal resection or bypass
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

Cholesterol gallstones are non-pigmented. Cholesterol is rendered soluble by bile by forming micelles with bile salts and lecithins. When cholesterol concentrations increase and surpass the solubilizing capacity of bile(supersaturation), it precipitates into solid cholesterol monohydrate crystals. The four mechanisms of cholesterol gallstone formation are:

  • Supersaturation of bile with cholesterol
  • Hypomobillity of the gallbladder
  • Accelerated cholesterol crystal nucleation
  • Hyper- secretion of mucus in the gallbladder

The conditions associated with an increased risk of development of cholesterol gallstones are:

  • Demography: Northern Europeans, North and South Americans, Native Americans, Mexican Americans
  • Advancing age
  • Female gender and sex hormones
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy
  • Obesity and metabolic syndrome
  • Rapid weight reduction
  • Gallbladder stasis
  • Inborndisorders of bile acid metabolism
  • Hyperlipidemia syndromes

questions.text:
A mother brings her 5-year-old daughter for evaluation. Physical examination reveals breast development, axillary hair, and pubic hair Laboratory studies show elevated GnRH, LH, and FSH. Which of the following is not a goal of treatment for this condition?

GnRH - Gonadotropin-releasing hormone
LH - Luteinizing hormone
FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

choices.text: Preventing short stature as an adult

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is suggestive of central precocious puberty. Blocking the production of sex steroids is not considered a goal of treatment in this condition. It is a goal of treatment in peripheral precocious puberty which is characterized by excessive estrogen and decreased gonadotropin hormones(FSH and LH).

Central precocious puberty occurs when there is an increase in pulsatile secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). This leads to increased production of hormones like luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) leading to increased sex steroid hormone production. 

Patients present with symptoms of puberty except that they present earlier than expected. Girls will show breast development, axillary and pubic hair growth, axillary odor, and if progressed, they may also start menses. Radiography will show advanced skeleton age. 

The main goal of treatment of central precocious puberty is to prevent short stature as an adult (Option B) because epiphyseal fusion is an estrogen-dependent process and excessive estrogen leads to premature fusion of the epiphyseal plates. 

Another goal of therapy is to relieve psychosocial stress (Option C). 

Treatment involves administrating GnRH agonists in order to suppress the pituitary-gonadal axis (Option D). This leads to decreased estrogen which further causes regression of breast and uterine size, and cessation of menses. Duration of treatment is determined by age of onset, maximizing height, synchronizing puberty with peers, and reducing distress. It is generally stopped at around 11 years of age.

questions.text:
You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

choices.text: Can be used as an emergency contraceptive
Can be used in patients with mennorrhagia

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

  • Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.
  • Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option D) or lower genital tract infections
  • Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy 
  • Scarred uterus
  • Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years. 

The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years. 

The following images represent the copper T 380A, multiload 375, and copper T 200. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A trial on a new antiemetic drug that can be used in post-chemotherapy patients was done. 20% of the patients in the treatment group had vomiting whereas 80% had vomiting in the placebo group. Calculate the relative risk reduction.
questions.solution:
Relative risk reduction in the above clinical trial is 75%.

Relative risk reduction(RRR) is the relative measure of treatment effectiveness. It shows an estimate of the proportion of the baseline risk that is removed by the intervention in a clinical trial.

RRR= (CER- EER)/CER where CER is the control event rate (adverse outcome in the control group) and EER is the experimental event rate (adverse outcome in the intervention group).

In the above clinical trial, 

CER= 80%=0.8, EER= 20%=0.2

RRR= (0.8-0.2)/0.8= 0.75 or 75%

RRR can also be calculated by finding the risk ratio (RR), i.e. RRR= 1- RR.

CER- EER: is risk difference.

Note:

Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo and the drug.

In this scenario, ARR = 80% - 20% = 60%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female who received an MMR vaccination, mentions that she plans to conceive soon. What would you advise her regarding this?

choices.text: There is no contraindication for pregnancy
Not to become pregnant over the next 3 months
Not to become pregnant over the next 1 month
Not to become pregnant over the next 6 months

questions.solution:
The recipients of the MMR vaccine should be advised not to become pregnant over the next 1 month (4 weeks). 

Rubella vaccination is usually done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of rubella. It is usually administered in combination with measles and mumps as the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine (MMR) vaccine. After live vaccines such as MMR and varicella vaccinations, women are advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 month. They should not be given during pregnancy. 

Conditions that are seen if infection occurs in 1st trimester:

  • Abortions
  • Stillbirth
  • Skin lesions: Blueberry muffin lesions
  • Triad of congenital rubella syndrome
    • Sensorineural deafness
    • Congenital heart defects 
    • Cataracts

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fever and diarrhea for 3 days. He recently had a course of ampicillin for otitis media. Laboratory investigation showed a WBC count of 17,000/mm3. A colonoscopy was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment in this patient to avoid relapse?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an elderly male presenting with fever and diarrhea after a course of antibiotics with WBC count more than 15,000, and a colonoscopy image showing numerous adherent pseudomembranes on the mucosa is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to clostridium difficile. Among the given options, fidaxomicin is superior in reducing relapse rates.

Clostridium difficile infection is the most common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

The majority of the cases (>80%) occur in patients above 65 years of age with comorbidities. The onset is insidious and may occur within 1 - 6 weeks after the initiation of antibiotic treatment. The symptoms include lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea. In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Detection of clostridium toxins A or B in the stool. Stool screening is initially done for the detection of glutamate dehydrogenase enzyme (GDH) produced by C. difficile or PCR to detect C. difficile nucleic acid. If the screening is positive, C. difficile toxin ELISA or tissue culture cytotoxicity is usually performed. Sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

If the patient is currently prescribed any antibiotics, they should be stopped, and the patient should be isolated. First-line therapy includes treatment with metronidazole, 500 mg orally 3 times daily for 7-10 days. Vancomycin 125 mg orally 4 times daily for 7-10 days is an alternative to metronidazole. However, vancomycin is reserved for use in case of relapse, due to the emergence of vancomycin resistance in other microorganisms.

Fidaxomicin may also be prescribed as a second-line agent and is associated with lower relapse rate than vancomycin. Intravenous immunoglobulin and/or glucocorticoids may be administered in patients with the most severe disease or those who are unresponsive to the initial therapy.

In cases of recurrent C. difficile infection, fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is usually done, which helps in restoring the gut microbiome profile.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with neurofibromatosis 1 (NF 1) brings her 9-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. She wants to know if the girl has NF 1. The presence of which of the following features would confirm NF 1 in the daughter?

choices.text: One iris hamartoma in the left eye

questions.solution:
The presence of one plexiform neurofibroma would confirm NF 1 in the daughter.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or von Recklinghausen's disease is an autosomal disease. NF1 is the most common of all neurofibromatosis. It is caused by a loss of function mutation, on the neurofibromin (NF1) gene. 

To diagnose neurofibromatosis 1, two or more of the following clinical manifestations should be present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules: > 5 mm in diameter in prepubertal and > 15 mm in diameter in postpubertal individuals
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris)
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

The FDA has recently approved a new drug selumetinib, mitogen-activated protein kinase 1 & 2 inhibitors for the treatment of NF1 in pediatric patients who are 2 years or older with symptomatic, inoperable plexiform neurofibromatosis. It can help reduce tumor progression. 

Related Pearl: Chromosomal abnormalities and syndromes associated with brain tumors

Syndrome Gene defect Tumor
Neurofibromatosis type 1 Neurofibromin (chr 17q)

Neurofibromas,

malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve gliomas,

hamartomatous lesions, pheochromocytomas.

 
Neurofibromatosis type 2 Schwannomin (chr 22q)

Bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, multiple meningiomas,

ependymomas of the spinal cord

 
Cowden's disease PTEN (chr 10)

Dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma (Lhermitte-Duclos disease),

meningioma, astrocytoma
 VHL   VHL gene (Chr 3p) 

Hemangioblastomas, Retinal angiomas
 MEN 1 Menin ( chr 11q) 

Pituitary adenoma, malignant schwannomas
Li-Fraumeni syndrome p53 (chr 17p)

Gliomas, medulloblastomas

questions.text: A 20-year-old female gave birth to a newborn baby with evisceration of the bowel as shown in the image given below. Identify the true statement regarding the condition shown.

choices.text: Defect is usually at the umbilicus
Most common associated anomaly is intestinal atresia
This defect cannot be diagnosed prenatally.
Definitive surgery is done in one sitting.

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of gastroschisis and intestinal atresia is the most common anomaly associated with it. As the herniated bowel contents are not covered by a membrane it is a case of gastroschisis and not omphalocele where the herniated content is completely covered by an amniotic membrane or sac.

Gastroschisis represents a congenital anomaly characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. The abdominal defect is located usually to the right of the umbilicus at the junction of the umbilicus and normal skin. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. It is usually <4cm in size without an overlying sac as seen in omphalocele.

Gastroschisis is commonly associated with intestinal atresia. The intestine is thickened, edematous and foreshortened in gastroschisis as the intestine is directly exposed to the amniotic fluid in utero due to the absence of an overlying sac. 

Gastroschisis can be diagnosed by a prenatal ultrasound scan. 

Below is the prenatal ultrasound image showing irregular loops of bowel outside the abdominal cavity without an overlying sac. 

Treatment: All newborns with gastroschisis require urgent surgical treatment. IV fluids are administered to counter the significant evaporative fluid losses. The reduction of the bowel is staged using a silo-plastic bag that is attached to the abdominal wall containing the herniated bowel that is gently reduced every 12-24 hours. Surgical closure can be done within approximately 1 to 2 weeks. 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where the bowel and the solid viscera are covered by the peritoneum and amniotic membrane. It occurs from a small size with intestinal contents to giant omphaloceles which have >4 cm abdominal wall defect.

Omphaloceles can be associated with other syndromes such as exstrophy of the cloaca (vesicointestinal fissure), Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (macroglossia, macrosomia, hypoglycemia, visceromegaly and omphalocele) and Cantrell's Pentalogy (lower thoracic wall malformations, ectopia cordis, epigastric omphalocele, anterior midline diaphragmatic hernia and cardiac anomalies). 

Treatment: Immediate treatment includes attending to the vital signs and maintaining the body temperature. Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in case a rupture of the sac occurs. Small-medium sized defects have a better prognosis. In cases of large-sized defects, primary repair of the omphalocele is attempted if the pulmonary status is satisfactory.

Below is the image of an infant with omphalocele.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with anterior epistaxis. His mother says that he frequently picks his nose. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of epistaxis is pinching the nose with the thumb and index finger for a few minutes. This action leads to compression of the vessels located in Little's area. 

Epistaxis refers to any bleeding from inside the nose. Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis. The blood may flow out from the front of the nose anteriorly when the patient sits, making it anterior epistaxis. If blood flows into the back of the throat, it is posterior epistaxis. 

The blood supply of the nasal septum and the lateral wall of the nose is by the branches of the external carotid system and the internal carotid system. Little’s area is the site of 90% of the patients with anterior epistaxis. It is located in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, above the nasal vestibule. This area is the site of Kiesselbach's plexus, the anastomosis of four arteries: anterior ethmoidal artery, the septal branch of the superior labial artery, the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery, and the greater palatine artery. 

This area, due to its location, is exposed to the drying effect of inspired are, and fingernail or instrumentation-related trauma. Thus, it is the usual site of epistaxis in children and young adults. 

The following image shows the blood supply of the nasal septum. 

Bleeding may also arise from Woodruff's plexus, which is located inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. This is the site for posterior epistaxis.

It may be local, general, or idiopathic. Local causes include trauma, infections, foreign body, neoplasm, and atmospheric changes. General causes may be attributed to systemic diseases of the heart, liver, kidney, and infections. Epistaxis is mostly idiopathic in the elderly.

Management of epistaxis is as follows: 

First aid involves pinching the nose for five minutes. This compresses Little's area. Trotter's method involves asking the patient to lean over a basin to spit out blood and to simultaneously breathe from the mouth. The application of cold compresses can cause reflex vasoconstriction and reduce bleeding. 

The following image shows Trotter's method.

Cauterization (Option C) is performed when the site of bleeding has been identified, especially in anterior epistaxis. The area should be anesthetized and then cauterized by silver nitrate or electrocautery. It can also be performed endoscopically. 

Nasal packing (Option D) can be anterior or posterior depending on the site of bleeding. Here, the nose is cleared of debris and cauterized. If this does not work, then a ribbon gauze soaked in paraffin is placed in each cavity and left for up to a few days. Antibiotics should be given to prevent infection and toxic shock syndrome. 

In the submucous resection (SMR) operation, the mucoperichondrial flap is elevated and then repositioned. This causes fibrosis and constriction of blood vessels. 

If bleeding is from the external carotid, maxillary, or ethmoidal arteries, they can be ligated. The internal maxillary artery can also be embolized by an interventional radiologist with femoral artery catheterization. The ethmoidal arteries cannot be embolized.

The transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) (Option B) is a procedure done under sedation with a rigid endoscope. Here, a mucosal flap is lifted and the sphenopalatine artery is localized as it exits the foramen. It is closed with a clip and the distal branches can be cauterized followed by repositioning of the flap. This is very successful in refractory posterior bleeds. 

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a child's developmental milestones. She is able to stand with support and says words like mama and dada. The doctor hands an object to her and lets her play with it. When she takes the object and hides it under the towel, the child searches for it. What other milestone is attained by the child at this age?
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario, the age of the child is 9 months and at this age, the child waves bye-bye.

At 9 months of age, a child is able to stand with support (motor milestone), can say bisyllables like ma-ma, da-da (language milestone), and the child would have attained object permanence. 

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when not seen. When the pediatrician hides the object, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age would not search for it and quickly gives up, while a baby of 9 months of age understands that the object is hidden and continues to exist, and therefore searches for it.

The other milestones attained at this age are waving bye-bye (social and adaptive milestone) and immature pincer grasp and probes with forefinger (fine motor milestone). An immature pincer grasp is grasping the object from the radial side of the hand. A mature pincer grasp is using the index finger and thumb to approach any object and it develops at the age of 12 months.

Other options:

Option A- A child points to objects of interest by the age of 15 months.

Option B- A child copies or mimics parents in tasks by age of 18 months.

Option D- A child understands simple questions by age of 12 months.

Related Pearl: Social and adaptive milestones

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 54-year-old female patient with non-productive cough, exertional dyspnoea, and fatigue, you notice cyanosis and clubbing. On further examination, you hear late inspiratory velcro crackles at lung bases that are unaltered by coughing and the pulmonary function test showed a restrictive deficit. Which of the following conditions should this typical clinical picture prompt you to suspect?
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) should be suspected in this patient.

ILD or diffuse parenchymal lung disease  is a heterogeneous collection of disorders that share a common presentation (dyspnea), physical findings (late inspiratory crackles), and chest radiographs (septal thickening and reticulonodular changes)

ILD occurs in patients aged more than 60 years and is common in women. They may present with an insidious onset of progressive dyspnea and non-productive cough. Late inspiratory velcro crackles on the lung base are one of the physical findings present in ILD. Cyanosis and clubbing are seen in advanced diseases.

In ILD, Pulmonary function test show a restrictive deficit. 

Based on the histopathological pattern on lung biopsy-

 Type of ILD Histologic pattern seen
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia A fibrotic or cellular pattern of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis associated lung disease
Systematic sclerosis-associated ILD Both UIP and NSIP
 Sarcoidosis Non caseating granuloma

Other options:

Bronchiolitis, bronchiectasis, and bronchial asthma are obstructive lung diseases. Pulmonary function test show obstructive pattern. 

Note: Velcro crackles may also be heard in case of radiation pneumonitis. Also, it may be difficult to reliably distinguish the same from crackles of pulmonary edema. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A mass casualty was brought into the hospital due to an explosion. Which of the following statement is false about blast injuries?

choices.text: Tympanic membrane rupture is the most common primary blast injury
Traumatic amputations occur in tertiary blast injuries
Secondary blast injuries result in blunt injuries
Quarternary blast injuries include burns and inhalational injuries

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding blast injuries is secondary blast injuries result in blunt injuries.

Secondary blast injuries result in penetrating injuries due to the fragments that are accelerated from the explosion. Souces of fragments are casing of the device, nails, bolts, glass, stones adherent of near to the device, a bone from a suicide bomber. The velocity and wounding potential of the fragments are subject to inverse square law.

Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. Severity depends on the strength of the blast, range from detonation, and surrounding environment. Primary blast injuries predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the tympanic membrane, lungs, and intestine.

The most commonly injured hollow organ is the tympanic membrane > lungs. Damage to the lungs results in a blast lung that results in hypoxia, intrapulmonary hemorrhage, and pulmonary edema. The caecum is the most sensitive among intestinal blast injuries. Solid organs are more resistant to primary blast injuries.

Tertiary blast injuries result in blunt injuries due to gross movement of personnel, objects by blast wind. Traumatic amputation can occur in this type of blast injury.

Quarternary blast injuries refer to the miscellaneous injuries due to the explosion like burns, inhalational injuries, and late-onset respiratory problems.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman was found to have complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. How would you consider treating this patient?

choices.text: Progesterone therapy and endometrial biopsy every 6 months
Progesterone therapy only for a duration of  2 years

questions.solution:
Progesterone therapy followed by endometrial biopsy every 3 to 6 months is the best treatment in the above case.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

  • Simple without atypia: there is an increase in number of glands but the architecture is not compromised. 
  • Simple with atypia: simple hyperplasia with features of nuclear atypia (variation in nuclear shape, size, and prominent nucleoli)
  • Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded and irregular
  • Complex with atypia: complex hyperplasia with atypical nuclear features. 

However, there is generally no clear histological distinction between the above mentioned classification, so endometrial hyperplasia is classified into hyperplasia without atypia and atypical hyperplasia/endometrioid intraepithelial neoplasia. 

Type of hyperplasia Risk of progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

Management of Endometrial hyperplasia:

1) Hyperplasia without atypia:

Intrauterine or continuous oral progesterone. Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system is preferred due to its lower side effect profile, higher rate of disease resolution. Oral progesterone can be given in the form of medroxyprogesterone acetate 10-20 mg/day. 

Endometrial surveillance in the form of biopsy should be performed at 6-month intervals. At least 2 consecutive negative biopsies should be obtained. Those at high risk (body mass index of more than 35, treated with oral progesterone) should be advised annual follow-up. 

2) Atypical hyperplasia:

Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is suggested in those with atypical hyperplasia due to the risk of progression to malignancy. 

Premenopausal women who want to preserve their fertility should be counseled regarding the risk of progression to cancer. Once fertility is no longer required, then hysterectomy should be offered. 

Those who refuse hysterectomy should have routine endometrial biopsies every 3 months until 2 consecutive negative biopsies are obtained.

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics will be most appropriate for managing the burn wound in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a burn eschar. Among the given topical antibiotics, only mafenide acetate penetrates burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue.

This agent has the disadvantage that it is quite painful on any partial thickness areas, and it is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can potentially cause metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his right scrotum. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum with an absent cremasteric reflex. On Doppler ultrasound, there is an absence of arterial flow to the right testis. Surgical exploration is done and the testis was not necrotic. What is to be done for the testis in the contralateral scrotum?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy presenting with acute pain in the scrotum, absent cremasteric reflex, and absent arterial flow on doppler is suggestive of testicular torsion. During surgical management of testicular torsion, orchiopexy at the same sitting is to be done for the contralateral testis which is viable.

Testicular torsion is a condition where the blood supply to the testis is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord resulting in ischemia of epididymis and testis. The condition is most common in adolescent males. The risk factors for torsion testis are undescended testis, testicular tumor, and bell-clapper deformity of the gubernaculum.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, apyrexia. Testis seems to be high in the scrotum and the tender, twisted spermatic cord can sometimes be palpated. The cremasteric reflex is lost on the side of the affected testis.

A diagnosis is arrived at primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning shows absent or decreased intratesticular blood flow compared to the contralateral side.

Immediate scrotal exploration is indicated even if there is a doubt regarding the diagnosis. An incision is taken along the midline (median raphe) or bilateral scrotal incisions are taken.

Surgical placement of the testicle in the scrotum is called orchidopexy (or orchiopexy). It is primarily used as a procedure to correct undescended testis but it is also used in testicular torsion.

Initially, the testis is detorsed and an intraoperative Doppler ultrasound is done. If the testis is found to be viable, a three-point fixation with non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea and dartos fascia of the testis is done to prevent recurrence. 

In the same exploration, orchiopexy should be done to the contralateral testes to prevent future contralateral torsion as there is a chance for the same anatomical deformity to be present in the contralateral side.

Other options:

Options A and D: Contralateral testis will be at high risk of torsion in the future. Hence, orchidopexy has to be done in the same surgical exploration.

Option B: Orchidectomy is preferred in non-viable or necrotic testes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain, bloody stools, and generalized muscle pain. Her blood pressure is 200/110 mmHg. She was diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). What are the histopathological changes seen on biopsy?

choices.text: Fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina
Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates and intimal hyperplasia
Segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation with aneurysms
Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the capillaries

questions.solution:
The histopathological changes seen on biopsy in PAN are segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation with aneurysms.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic vasculitis affecting the small-medium-sized arteries. PAN characteristically involves the renal and visceral vessels and spares the pulmonary vasculature. There is no association with antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA), but a third of the patients are positive for hepatitis B. 

The commonly involved organs in PAN are the kidney, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. Inadequate perfusion results in ischemia, ulcerations, infarcts, or hemorrhage.

It classically presents as rapidly accelerating hypertension, acute abdominal pain, bloody stools, diffuse myalgias, and motor peripheral neuropathy. The diagnosis is based on a biopsy showing segmental necrotizing transmural inflammation of small-medium-sized arteries with aneurysms and thrombosis of the vessels involved, as shown below.

Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small- and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. An angiogram showing aneurysms of renal arteries is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina (black arrow) is seen in giant cell arteritis. It affects large to small-sized arteries. The involved segments have thickened intima, reduced luminal diameter, fragmented internal elastic lamina, and multinucleated giant cells (yellow arrow). Clinically, it presents after 50 years of age with headache or facial pain, most intense along the course of the superficial temporal artery, painful to palpation, and visual symptoms.

Option B: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates and intimal hyperplasia is seen in Takayasu arteritis. It affects larger vessels. It is characterized clinically by ocular symptoms and weakened pulses in the upper extremities. Aortic root involvement causes dilation and aortic valve insufficiency.

Option D: Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the capillaries is seen in microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). It is also known as leukocytoclastic vasculitis as only neutrophil infiltration is present. It presents as hemoptysis, hematuria and proteinuria, bowel pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura, depending on the vessel and organ involved.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with muscle weakness, abnormal tingling sensation over the face, and pain and swelling over the knee joint for 3 months. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Investigations show hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria with metabolic alkalosis. His x-ray knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with muscle weakness, paresthesia over the face, hypotension, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, metabolic alkalosis, and x-ray knee showing chondrocalcinosis as punctate density on the cartilage are suggestive of Gitelman's syndrome. 

Gitelman's syndrome is an autosomal recessive salt-losing renal tubulopathy. It occurs due to a mutation of Na+-Cl– co-transporter (NCCT) in the distal tubule. 

NCCT helps in the absorption of sodium and chloride ions from the lumen of the distal tubule. In Gitelman's syndrome, due to the loss of function of NCCT, there will be increased sodium and chloride delivery to collecting duct and volume retraction. This results in increased renin and aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone act on epithelial sodium channels in the collecting duct causing increased reabsorption of sodium and increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

Downregulation of magnesium-permeable channels in Gitelman syndrome leads to urinary loss of magnesium resulting in hypomagnesemia.

There is increased passive reabsorption of calcium in the proximal convoluted tubule in Gitelman syndrome resulting in hypocalciuria. 

Hypomagnesemia impairs the function of calcitropic hormones and down-regulates the normal inverse association between ionized calcium, parathyroid hormone, and calcitriol. This results in reduced skeletal sensitivity of PTH and impaired intestinal calcium transport and explains the lack of hypercalcemia response to hypocalciuria. 

Low magnesium levels result in the reduction of pyrophosphate activity that could promote pyrophosphate crystallization in joints causing joint pains and chondrocalcinosis.

Even though patients present above the age of 6 years, the diagnosis in most cases is established during adulthood. Patients often present with signs of tetany, paresthesias, and chondrocalcinosis, as a result of hypomagnesemia and fatiguability. 

Hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia prolong the duration of the action potential of cardiomyocytes and consequently increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmia. 

Other options:

Option A: Bartter's syndrome affects the Na+/K+/Cl-  co-transporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It causes hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Liddle's syndrome causes increased activation of epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) channels expressed on the apical membrane of principal cells of the collecting duct. It results in severe hypertension with hypokalemia.

Option D: Fanconi's syndrome occurs due to a defect in the proximal tubular function that prevents the absorption of electrolytes and other substances that are normally absorbed by the proximal tubule. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother of a newborn is brought to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal cramps, and massive desquamation of the skin. The patient presents with a red skin rash,  affecting mainly the soles, palms, and buttocks. Further probing reveals that she had consumed the substance shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest boiled lobster syndrome seen in poisoning with boric acid, a common household poison commonly seen in baby powders, lotions, and antiseptics used in the treatment of diaper dermatitis.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, and buttocks, can be seen. The characteristic appearance is known as "boiled lobster appearance," which is marked by intense erythema, followed by extensive exfoliation.

Other options:

Option A- Pink disease or acrodynia is caused due to hypersensitivity reaction resulting from repeated ingestion or contact with mercury. There are pinkish morbilliform/ acral rashes, desquamation of palms and soles, pain in the extremities, excessive salivation or perspiration, photophobia, anorexia, insomnia, constipation or diarrhea, etc.

Option B- Blackfoot disease is caused due to chronic arsenic poisoning. Chronic arsenic poisoning causes peripheral vascular insufficiency, leading to dry gangrene.

Option D- Erethism refers to psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is commonly seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.

Eponymous features associated with mercury poisoning:

  • Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.
  • Acrodynia (Pink disease)
  • Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury.
  • Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.
  • Mercuria lentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

Eponymous features associated with arsenic poisoning:

  • Raindrop pigmentation - seen on temples, eyelids, and neck
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines - white lines on finger and toe nails
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

questions.text: A 28-year-old man undergoes a submucosal resection. One week later, he presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and pressure sensation over the nasal bridge. On examination, smooth, rounded swelling of the septum is seen bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is a septal hematoma. 

Septal hematoma occurs when there is an accumulation of blood beneath the periosteum or perichondrium of the nasal septum. The most common cause of hematoma is nasal surgery or trauma. However, it is also seen in individuals with bleeding disorders. 

Patients present with bilateral nasal obstruction, frontal headache, and pressure sensation over the bridge. 

Examination, as seen in this patient, will show bilateral smooth rounded swellings of the nasal septum. If palpated, the mass will be soft and fluctuant.

The following image shows the bilateral, smooth, rounded swellings of the nasal septum indicative of septal hematoma. 

Treatment of septal hematomas involves aspiration with a wide bore needle if small, and incision and drainage if large. The incision can be made parallel to the nasal floor. Removing a small piece of nasal mucosa will aid in drainage. After drainage, the nose has to be packed bilaterally to avoid reaccumulation. 

Complications of not draining the hematoma include organization into fibrous tissue leading to the permanent thick septum. It can also become infected leading to septal abscess formation.

Other options: 

Option A - Septal abscess occurs usually when there is a secondary infection of a septal hematoma. It is characterized by fever, chills, and frontal headaches. 

Option C - Septal perforation can occur after nasal surgery. Features depend on the size of the perforation. Smaller perforations can present with whistling while the larger perforations will present with epistaxis and crust formation. An image of septal perforation is given below.

Option D - Septal deviation is characterized by chronic unilateral or bilateral nasal obstruction. There is usually an external deformity and associated sinusitis, epistaxis, and anosmia.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text:
All of the following can determine protein structure except _____.

(NMR - nuclear magnetic resonance)
questions.solution:
High-performance liquid chromatography cannot determine protein structure. It is used for separation, purification, and identification of proteins.

Given below are the various methods to determine protein structure:

  • X-Ray crystallography
  • NMR spectroscopy
  • Mass spectrometry
  • Infra-red spectroscopy
  • Polychromatic X-ray crystallography
  • UV light spectroscopy
  • Optical rotatory dispersion
  • Circular dichromism
  • Computer-based modeling

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient who had been to a movie theatre came to the emergency room with complaints of ocular pain and blurring of vision. She gives a history of being on prophylactic medications for migraine. On examination, her intraocular pressure is elevated with a shallow anterior chamber. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
Topiramate is the most likely cause of her presentation.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma characterized by the precipitating factors i.e., female gender and movie theatre (movie in a darkened hall) and increased intraocular pressure with a shallow anterior chamber.

Topiramate causes ciliochoroidal effusion, leading to acute angle-closure glaucoma. Other sulfa-derived drugs like sulfonamides can also cause angle-closure glaucoma. The treatment would consist of reducing the intraocular pressure and stopping the causative drug.

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that blocks the voltage-gated Na+ channels. Apart from that, it activates hyperpolarizing K+ channels, increases GABA activity, and blocks glutamate AMPA-kainate receptors. It is also a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor due to which it may precipitate renal stones.

Topiramate is used in the treatment of refractory focal, refractory generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and prophylaxis of migraine. It is also effective in drop-attacks and seizures in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. This drug can cause weight loss and renal stones.

Other options: 

Option A - Sodium valproate is an antiseizure drug that acts by prolonging the recovery of inactivated Na+ channels and decreasing T-type Ca2+ channel currents. It is used in the treatment of focal, tonic-clonic, absence, and myoclonic seizures. It is also used as a prophylaxis in migraine headaches. 

Option C - Propranolol is a non-selective β-blocker. It is the most common and most effective first-line drug for migraine prophylaxis. Some of the common adverse effects include dizziness, decreased exercise tolerance, and depression. Contraindications include severe asthma, peripheral vascular disease, severe bradycardia, and heart blocks.

Option D - Gabapentin is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.

questions.text: A biochemist performs the cyanide nitroprusside test on a non-essential purely glucogenic amino acid. The test is positive for the same. Identify the amino acid being tested.
questions.solution:
Cysteine is a non-essential, glucogenic amino acid that tests positive for nitroprusside reaction.

Cyanide nitroprusside test

Cyanide nitroprusside breaks the S-S bond (disulfide bond) and releases free sulfhydryl groups which react with sodium nitroprusside to give a reddish color. The test is positive for cysteine.

Sulfur test can also be performed to detect free sulfhydryl groups.

Other options:

Option A: Glycine is a non-essential, purely glucogenic amino acid and tests negative for nitroprusside reaction. It does not contain the sulfhydryl group. 

Option C: Threonine is an essential, purely glucogenic amino acid. It contains a hydroxyl group and hence tests negative for nitroprusside reaction

Option D: Tyrosine is a non-essential, both glucogenic and ketogenic amino acid. It contains a phenol group and hence tests negative for nitroprusside reaction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 26 weeks of gestation presented with an episode of painless bleeding per vagina. The bleeding has since resolved. She experienced abdominal pains which were determined to be contractions prior to the episode. The image given below represents her condition. Which of the following is not indicated in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an abnormally implanted placenta that is overlapping the internal os is suggestive of placenta previa. The digital examination is not indicated in placenta previa as it can lead to severe hemorrhage. 

Common risk factors for placenta previa include previous cesarian section or myomectomy, advanced maternal age (>35 years), smoking, multiple gestation, multiparity, and prior curettage.

Clinical features include painless bleeding. This usually occurs around the end of the second trimester but can occur earlier. It occurs without an inciting event or contractions and is not severe enough to be fatal and stops on its own. However, it can recur. In patients with a low-lying placenta, the bleeding may only present at the time of labor. 

Management options can be divided into expectant management and active or definite management. 

Expectant management has been described by Macafee and Johnson.

Prerequisites: Blood should be available for transfusion if required, and facilities for cesarean section should be made available 24 hours a day. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa:

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%)
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG and cardiotocography)

The components of expectant treatment include: 

  • Bed rest (Option A) with bathroom and toilet privilege
  • Investigations like hemoglobin estimation, blood grouping, urine for protein, etc
  • Periodic examination of vulval pads
  • Fetal surveillance with ultrasound at an interval of 2-3 weeks
  • Supplementary hematinics should be provided
  • If the patient is anemic, then the loss of blood is treated with adequate cross-matched blood transfusion
  • 2-3 days after the bleeding stops, the patient is allowed out of bed and examined with a gentle speculum to rule out local causes of bleeding
  • Tocolysis (Option C) if associated with contractions
  • Rh immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative mothers

Ideally, a hospital setting is ideal but if prolonged, then bed rest at home can be considered if the patient lives close to the hospital, has 24-hour transportation, and is well motivated to understand the risk. 

Expectant management can be continued till 37 weeks of gestation. 

Indications of definitive management (delivery) include :

  • Bleeding occurs at or after 37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The patient is in labor.
  • The patient is in an exsanguinated state on admission.
  • Continuous bleeding and of a moderate degree.
  • Baby with nonreassuring cardiac status, dead, or known to be congenitally deformed. 

Patients with placenta previa confirmed on ultrasound are always scheduled for cesarean delivery (Option D), which is performed in patients who are near-term and are not currently bleeding. This is usually scheduled for 36-37 weeks of gestation. Vaginal delivery may be considered if the placental edge is 2-3cm away from the internal os as confirmed by ultrasound. 

The following image shows the different degrees of placenta previa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency room where a neurosurgeon was available. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) dropped by 4 points from the time of injury to hospitalization. CT scan reveals the following findings. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a CT scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of a subdural hematoma (SDH). The best treatment option for this patient with a subdural hematoma and who has a drop in GCS by 4 points is open craniotomy.

Subdural Hematoma (SDH):

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH. Elderly and alcoholic patients due to brain atrophy are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma. On head CT scan, SDH appears as a bright or mixed-density, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in the question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm
  3. GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Note: Conservative management can be done in patients with a midline shift of <10 mm on a CT scan and a GCS score of 15 initially, reserving urgent craniotomy and evacuation of the hematoma in deteriorating neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old psychiatric patient is admitted for electroconvulsive therapy. He is likely to be suffering from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely to be suffering from major depression with psychosis, which is an indication for electroconvulsive therapy.

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) involves inducing a bilateral generalized seizure in an anesthetized patient using an electrical current. Some indications of ECT include:

  • Major depression
    • Psychotic depression
    • Treatment-resistant depression
    • Food refusal secondary to depression
    • Suicidality
  • Mania
  • Acute exacerbation of schizophrenia
  • Catatonia
  • On and off phenomenon in Parkinson's disease
  • Neuroleptic malignant disorder

Pre-treatment evaluation includes a thorough history, examination, and laboratory tests. These include full blood counts, urine tests, a chest X-ray, and ECG. The patient should not eat anything orally for 6 hours before the procedure.

The procedure is done under general anesthesia, and oxygen is administered. Methohexital is the most commonly used agent. Thiopental is another agent that can be used. A muscle relaxant such as succinylcholine is also administered to reduce the risk of injuries resulting from the seizure.

A brief muscular contraction is seen in the jaw and facial muscles with the flow of current. Adverse effects include confusion and delirium shortly after the procedure, memory impairment, and other minor injuries.

Other options: 

Option A - Narcissistic personality disorder is treated with psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Lithium is used for mood swings. Antidepressants may also be used since these patients are prone to depression.

Option B - Generalized anxiety disorder is treated with a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. The three main drugs that are used are benzodiazepines, buspirone, and venlafaxine.

Option C - ECT is not known to be effective in conversion disorder. It usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented supportive therapy, anxiolytics, and psychoanalysis are treatment modalities used. 

Related Pearl: Signs and symptoms of depression

Mnemonic "SIGECAPS"

Sleep disorder (increased or decreased)

Interest deficit (anhedonia): loss of interest in previously pleasurable activities

Guilt (worthlessness, hopelessness, regret)

Energy deficit

Concentration deficit

Appetite disorder (increased or decreased)

Psychomotor retardation or agitation

Suicidal tendency

Related Pearl: Psychiatric conditions and associated neurotransmitter activity

Psychiatric Condition Associated Neurotransmitter Activity
Depression Decrease in serotonin, norepinephrine and dopamine
Mania Increase in dopamine and decrease in GABA
Schizophrenia Increase in dopamine and serotonin
Anxiety Increase in norepinephrine and decrease in GABA ad serotonin
Alzheimer's disease Decrease in Norepinephrine and decrease in Acetylcholine

 

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer of a primary health center in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Leishmania

L. mexicana (Chiclero ulcer)

Related Pearl: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

  • Tests for antigen detection
  • Tests for antibody detection

questions.text: A child, while playing in a field, stepped his right foot over a sharp-pointed stone. Immediately, as a reflex action, he lifted his right leg and extended the left leg. The action of the left leg is attributable to which of the following reflexes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, when the right foot is placed on the sharp stone, the right leg is lifted off due to the flexor withdrawal reflex, while the left leg is extended due to the crossed-extensor reflex.

When a painful stimulus is applied to a limb, then the limb is immediately flexed to pull away from the danger. This reflex is called the flexion withdrawal reflex. Within 0.2 to 0.5 seconds, the extensor muscles of the opposite limb contract, to shift the weight of the body onto the other side, in the case of the lower limb, or to push the dangerous stimulus away from the body. This reflex is called the crossed-extensor reflex.

After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has a longer period of after-discharge when compared to the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

The image below shows the flexor reflex

The image below shows the crossed extensor reflex

Other options:

Option A- The patellar tendon reflex, which is activated by tapping the patellar tendon, is a type of stretch reflex.

Option C- Positive supportive reaction is a primitive postural reflex, wherein the pressure applied on the footpad causes extension of the limb.

Option D- The Golgi tendon reflex provides a negative feedback mechanism that prevents the development of excessive tension in a muscle.

Related Pearl: Summary of Muscle Reflexes

Reflex

(knee-jerk)

Relaxation of muscle
