questions.text:
An ASHA worker attends her second visit for a 3-day-old newborn delivered at home. She noticed multiple pustular lesions sparing palms and soles as shown below and referred to you. What is the next line of management?

ASHA - Accredited social health activist
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an image showing yellow-white papules or pustules with surrounding erythematous flare are suggestive of erythema toxicum. They do not require any treatment.

Erythema toxicum is a benign transient dermatological lesion that resolves spontaneously without any treatment. 

Erythema toxicum occurs in one-half of all full-term infants and less commonly in preterm infants. Lesions are firm yellow-white to white 1- 2 mm papules or pustules. They are surrounded by erythematous flare. The lesions are sparse or numerous and either clustered or widely spread over much of the body surface with sparing of palms and soles.

Most of the lesion occurs in 1- 3 days of life and persists for 1 week. Generally, they resolve without pigmentation.

Eosinophils can be demonstrated on intralesional contents and cultures are usually sterile.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A study was conducted to find the different factors that control the plasma potassium level. Which of the following factor decreases the plasma potassium levels?
questions.solution:
Excess insulin decreases plasma potassium levels.

Insulin stimulates the sodium-potassium adenosine triphosphate (Na+- K+ ATPase) activity in tissues including skeletal muscle. This leads to the transport of potassium into the cells. After a meal, the insulin helps in increasing the potassium uptake leading to increased cellular uptake. In patients with insulin deficiency, there is a higher rise in plasma potassium concentration.

To correct hyperkalemia, insulin injections are used. 

Other options:

Option B: In aldosterone deficiency as in Addison disease, hyperkalemia occurs due to the accumulation of potassium in the extracellular space along with the renal retention of potassium. 

Option C: During strenuous exercise, potassium is released from skeletal muscles into the extracellular space causing mild hyperkalemia.

Option D: Beta-adrenergic blockade causes potassium to move out of the cells and creates a tendency towards hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by posttranscriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient who has been diagnosed with short bowel syndrome is to be given parenteral nutrition. All of the following are true about parenteral nutrition except:

PICC - peripherally inserted central venous catheter

choices.text: Central venous access can be achieved through subclavian vein
PICC line can produce irreversible thrombophlebitis
Peripheral feeding can be used for more than 2 weeks
Catheter-related sepsis is a common complication

questions.solution:
All of the above are true about parenteral nutrition except that peripheral feeding can be used for more than 2 weeks. 

Parenteral nutrition is defined as the continuous infusion of all the required nutrition through the intravenous route to completely avoid the use of the gastrointestinal tract. It is usually indicated when protein and energy demands cannot be met by enteral nutrition administration. They include causes such as short bowel syndrome, enterocutaneous fistula, etc.

It can be provided by obtaining either peripheral venous access or central venous access. Peripheral venous access is achieved either by inserting a catheter into a peripheral vein and then maneuvering it into the central vein (peripherally inserted central venous catheter-PICC) or by a short wrist vein cannula. PICC lines have a mean survival duration of 7 days and can cause irreversible thrombophlebitis. 

Central venous access is achieved by the subclavian, internal jugular, or external jugular vein. The infraclavicular subclavian approach is preferred as it is easier to provide nursing care. For long-term parenteral nutrition, Hickman lines are more appropriate.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) the insertion of a PICC line (C) a patient with a PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

Parenteral nutrition can cause metabolic complications such as fluid overload, hyperglycemia (due to insulin resistance in critically ill patients), vitamin deficiencies, and impaired liver function. Catheter-related sepsis is common and can be diagnosed by culturing organisms from the blood or catheter tip. Refeeding syndrome is caused by severe fluid and electrolyte shifts in patients undergoing refeeding and results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: A 20-year-old nonsmoker male patient with a past history of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) has been scheduled for surgery. For postoperative pain, he was given opioids. What score is assigned to this patient based on the Apfel scoring system used to predict the risk of PONV?
questions.solution:
According to the Apfel scoring system used to predict the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), this patient will be given a score of 3.

Apfel scoring system is used for the risk stratification based on four factors, each factor is given a score of 1. The incidence of PONV with the presence of 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 risk factors is about 10%, 20%, 40%, 60%, and 80%, respectively. The four factors are:

Risk Factors Score
Female 1
Nonsmoking status, 1
History of PONV 1
Use of postoperative opioids 1
Sum  0 to 4

PONV is the second most common complaint after postoperative pain that a patient presents with. It occurs in about 20-30% of the general surgical population and its incidence is markedly raised in those with predisposing risk factors. Prevention is better than cure.

Risk factors for PONV:

In addition to the above-mentioned factors, those of a younger age (<50 years) have delayed gastric emptying due to diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, pregnancy, increased intracranial tension, etc. Surgical procedures such as cholecystectomy, laparoscopy, gynaecological surgeries, and breast surgery are also associated with PONV.

The Society for Ambulatory Anesthesia (SAMBA) provides extensive guidelines for the management of PONV, which includes:

  • 5-HT3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones
  • Dexamethasone
  • Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists - Aprepitant
  • Acupuncture and acupressure can reduce PONV incidence and medication requirements.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness and fatigue for 5 months. Chest X-ray showed left atrial enlargement with straightening of the left cardiac border. Echocardiogram showed reduced opening of the mitral valve during diastole with thickening of the valve leaflets. Which among the following findings can be heard during auscultation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis (MS), and a mid-diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

MS is a valvular heart disease, most commonly caused by rheumatic fever. Other causes include:

  • Congenital defects like cor triatriatum and parachute valve
  • Mitral annular calcification with leaflet involvement
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Left atrial myxoma
  • Infective endocarditis with large vegetations

Chronic inflammation causes thickening of the valve leaflets and shortening and fusion of chordae tendineae, leading to the formation of a funnel-shaped or fish-mouth valve. Calcification immobilizes the leaflets and narrows the valve further. Thrombi are also commonly formed from the calcified valve or dilated left atrium (in atrial fibrillation).

Patients present with dyspnea and cough in early stages of the condition. But as the disease progresses, daily acitivities are limited and the patient develops orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Hemoptysis can occur due to rupture of pulmonary-bronchial venous connections as a result of pulmonary venous hypertension.

Auscultatory findings of MS include:

  • Accentuated and slightly delayed first heart sound (S1)
  • Close splitting of the second heart sound (S2)
  • Accentuated pulmonic component of S2 (P2) when pulmonary artery pressure is elevated
  • Opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve following the aortic component of S2 (A2):
    • Audible during expiration at or just medial to the cardiac apex
  • Mid-diastolic murmur following OS:
    • Low pitched, rumbling
    • Heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral position
    • Accentuated by mild exercise
    • Duration of the murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis
    • Reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole in patients with sinus rhythm (presystolic accentuation)
  • Soft systolic murmurs heard at or medial to the apex (signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation)

When the cardiac output is severely reduced, the typical auscultatory findings may not be heard. This is known as silent MS. Hepatomegaly, pedal edema, ascites, and pleural effusion, may occur in patients with right ventricular failure.

Other associated murmurs include:

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo’s sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

Other options:

Option B:

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after S1, increases in intensity toward the middle of ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

A systolic ejection click can be heard in young patients with a bicuspid aortic valve, but disappears as the valves become calcified. A2 and P2 may be heard at the same time or A2 may follow P2, resulting in paradoxical splitting of S2. A fourth heart sound (S4) is often heard at the apex, indicating the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Option C:

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. Wide splitting of S2 may occur due to premature closure of the aortic valve. A low-pitched third heart sound (S3) may occur following A2. S4 can also be audible in patients with acute severe MR.

Option D:

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent and occasionally, S4 also may be heard.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

 

Related Pearl: The causes of holosystolic murmur are:

  1. Mitral regurgitation

  • Best heard at the apex
  • Radiates to axilla or base
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • A2 is not heard at the apex

  2. Tricuspid regurgitation

  • Best heard at lower left sternal border
  • Radiates to the epigastrium and right sternal border
  • Increases in intensity during inspiration
  • Prominent c-v waves seen in JVP

  3. Ventricular septal defect

  • Beat heard over left 3rd and 4th intercostal space
  • Radiates widely
  • Palpable thrill present
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • Wide splitting of S2 seen

questions.text: A 54-year-old man who is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension experiences severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. He was admitted to the emergency ward. An ECG is taken which is as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding blood lactate dehydrogenase levels in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset chest pain with profuse sweating and 12 Lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) with ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of myocardial Infarction. Serum LDH 1 > LDH 2 levels are seen in this condition. 

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. So, normally LDH 2 > LDH 1 in blood. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream. This results in a flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio where LDH 1 > LDH 2.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH Type  Composition Location
LDH-1 HHHH Heart and RBC
LDH-2 HHHM RBC and kidneys
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, brain, lymphatic tissues, and platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

Related Pearl: Principal Serum Enzymes Used in Clinical Diagnosis

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT/SGPT) Viral hepatitis
Creatine kinase

CK-BB Brain, Brain injury, meningitis, abnormal cell growth, severe shock, stroke, hypothermia, or restricted blood flow to the bowel.
CK-MB Heart and skeletal muscle, Myocardial Infarction, Muscular dystrophy
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

HHHM(I2)/LDH-2 Reticuloendothelial system
HHMM(I3)/LDH-3 Lungs
HMMM(I4)/LDH-4 Liver & Skeletal Muscles

Others

questions.text: A young male patient presents with painless hematuria. Urine microscopy revealed an egg of Schistosoma haematobium. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice used in its treatment?

choices.text: Stimulates Ca2+ efflux and causes spastic paralysis
Stimulates Ca2+ efflux and causes flaccid paralysis
Stimulates Ca2+ influx and causes spastic paralysis
Stimulates Ca2+ influx and causes flaccid paralysis

questions.solution:
The drug of choice for Schistosoma infections is praziquantel and the mechanism of action of this drug is to stimulate Ca2+ influx and cause spastic paralysis of the organism.

Praziquantel is an anti-helminth drug. It acts by promoting Ca2+ influx in schistosomes and other praziquantel-sensitive parasites. This results in increased muscular activity and later causes contraction and spastic paralysis of the worm. Praziquantel may also act by generating reactive oxygen species. 

It is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis caused by all Schistosoma species that infect humans. A single oral dose of 40 mg/kg is curative in the majority of cases. It is also preferred in infections by:

  • Cestodes like Hymenolepsis nana, Taenia saginata, Taenia solium, and Diphyllobothrium latum
  • Trematodes like Clonorchis sinensis, Opisthorchis viverrini, Paragonimiasis westermani, Fasciolopsis buski, Heterophyes heterophyes, and Metagonimus yokogawai

Fasciola hepatica is resistant to praziquantel.

The adverse effects include abdominal discomfort, eosinophilia, rashes, arthralgia, and myalgia. Praziquantel is contraindicated in ocular cysticercosis because the host response can cause irreversible damage to the eye. In neurocysticercosis, an inflammatory response to praziquantel can lead to meningismus, seizures, and cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis. Hence, the drug of choice in neurocysticercosis is albendazole.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of poor scholastic performance and episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control. No confusion is reported after regaining consciousness. Episodes are precipitated by hyperventilation. Which of the following drug is preferred in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control, no postictal confusion, and episodes provoked by hyperventilation are suggestive of typical absence seizures. Among the given options, ethosuximide is the first-line agent for the treatment of typical absence seizures

Ethosuximide inhibits the T-type calcium currents in thalamic neurons and thus reduces the absence seizures.

Absence seizures are of two types

Typical absence seizures which are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control. They last for only a few seconds and consciousness returns immediately. It is usually accompanied by subtle motor signs such as rapid blinking of eyelids, chewing movements, or clonic movements of the hands. It is usually described as unexplained daydreaming. EEG reveals a 3Hz spike and slow wave discharges precipitated by hyperventilation. Ethosuximide, valproate and lamotrigine are used in the management.

Atypical absence seizures are characterized by less abrupt onset and cessation, longer duration of lapse in consciousness, and are usually accompanied by obvious motor signs. Valproic acid, lamotrigine, and topiramate are used in the management.

Other options:

Option A- Levetiracetam is used for focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). 

Option B- Lacosamide is used as an adjuvant in focal seizures.

Option D- Carbamazepine is used in patients with GTCS seizures.

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

Type of seizure  1st-line antiepileptic drugs

Focal seizures 
  • Carbamazepine
  • Oxcarbazepine 
  • Lamotrigine
  • Levetiracetam
  • Phenytoin
GTCS 
  • Sodium valproate
  • Levetiracetam 
  • Lamotrigine 
Typical absence seizures 
  • Ethosuximide (drug of choice)
  • Sodium valproate
  • Lamotrigine
Atypical absence seizures
  • Sodium valproate 
Myoclonic seizures
  • Sodium valproate (drug of choice)
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of common anti-epileptics

Mechanism of action of some common antiepileptics:

Mechanism of action Antiepileptics
Sodium channel blockers
  • Phenytoin
  • Carbamazepine
  • Oxcarbazepine

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has frequent episodes of fever with a productive cough and frequent headaches. On examination, his second heart sound was prominently heard on the right side of the chest. The patient reported infertility for the past 7 years. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in the lungs of this patient?

choices.text: Dilated airways in the lower lobes
Collapse of the right lower lobe

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes Kartegener syndrome. The findings of bronchiectasis will be seen in the lung, which is dilated airways in the lower lobes.

Kartagener syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder presenting with the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus - leading to the right-sided heartbeat
  • Chronic sinusitis - leading to headaches
  • Bronchiectasis - leading to fever, excessive productive cough, and foul-smelling expectoration.

Bronchiectasis is defined as the permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles caused by the destruction of the smooth muscle and the supporting elastic tissue by chronic necrotizing infections.

It presents as a severe, persistent cough with foul-smelling expectoration, and on occasion bloody sputum and hemoptysis. In severe cases, it may present as orthopnea, dyspnea, cor pulmonale, brain abscess, and amyloidosis.

In bronchiectasis, normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchial obstruction which results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, often with necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually dilation of airways as shown below:

Bronchiectasis usually affects the lower lobes bilaterally, with a predilection to vertical segments and distal bronchi and bronchioles. The airways are dilated up to four times the normal size and a probe can sometimes be passed all the way to the pleural surface. On the cut surface, the bronchi appear as cystic and are filled with mucopurulent secretions as shown below.

Other options:

Option A - Panacinar emphysema is seen in cases of α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

Option C - Collapse of the right lower lobe is not associated with bronchiectasis.

Option D - Interstitial fibrosis is seen in diseases like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A critically ill patient was given an infusion of an intravenous anesthetic as given in the image below at a dose of 4 mg/kg/hour. After approximately 48 hours, the patient developed refractory bradycardia. Laboratory investigations show hyperkalemia, hyperlipidemia, and high anionic base metabolic acidosis. Which is the first line of management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The white-colored intravenous anesthetic shown in the image is propofol. The given scenario points towards the diagnosis of propofol infusion syndrome. The first line of management in this condition is to discontinue the drug.

Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but invariably lethal syndrome seen due to the administration of propofol. It is seen when infusion doses of propofol exceed more than 4 mg/kg/hour for 48 hours or longer. It is commonly observed in children and in critically ill adults. 

The risk factors that lead to the development of propofol infusion syndrome are recent infusion in propofol at doses >4mg/kg/hr for 48 hours, critical illness, use of vasopressors, glucocorticosteroids, carbohydrate depletion in starvation and malnutrition, medium-chain acyl CoA deficiency(MCAD), carnitine deficiency, and subclinical mitochondrial disease. 

Clinical features of propofol infusion syndrome:

  • Acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole
  • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
  • Rhabdomyolysis - hyperkalemia and acute kidney injury
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure
  • Wide QRS complex with Brugada syndrome-like patterns (particularly type 1)
  • Lipemia is often the first sign.

Management is mainly supportive as there is no known antidote for the treatment of propofol infusion syndrome

  • First-line therapy of suspected cases is the immediate discontinuation of propofol
  • Transvenous pacing for bradyarrhythmias
  • IV sodium bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis 
  • Dialysis for hyperkalemia and rhabdomyolysis
  • Vigorous fluid administration
  • Administration of calcium, insulin with or without dextrose, beta 2 agonists, and potassium binding resin can also be considered in the management of hyperkalemia
  • Cardiogenic shock is managed with the support of vasopressors and inotropes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who has a known history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension was diagnosed with Wallenberg syndrome.  He developed dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice. Which cranial nerve nucleus in the brainstem is involved that leads to the symptoms mentioned above?

choices.text: Nucleus ambiguus from general visceral efferent column
Nucleus ambiguus from special visceral afferent column
Nucleus ambiguus from special visceral efferent column
Nucleus ambiguus from general visceral afferent column

questions.solution:
Dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice seen in Wallenberg syndrome is due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus from the special visceral efferent column.

Nucleus ambiguus is a common motor nucleus containing the efferent fibers of the glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and the vagus (CN X) nerves. These supply the pharyngeal constrictors, intrinsic laryngeal muscles, and striated muscles of the palate and upper esophagus. This nucleus is also involved in the gag reflex and the cardiac parasympathetic activity. Lesions this nucleus in leads to dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice seen in Wallenberg syndrome. Nucleus ambiguus arises from the special visceral efferent column present in the medulla.

Wallenberg syndrome occurs due to thrombosis in the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (the most tortuous artery in the body) causing infarction of the inferior cerebellar peduncle, nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nucleus, spinal lemniscus, the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, and the sympathetic chain. 

This results in ipsilateral ataxia, loss of pain and temperature, drooping of the eyelid, miosis, anhidrosis, loss of ciliospinal reflex, apparent enophthalmos, dysphagia, dysarthria, nasal regurgitation, hoarseness of voice, contralateral loss of pain and temperature, vertigo, nystagmus, and vomiting.

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

Functional Component Cranial nerves 

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

 3,4,6,12

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

 3,7,9,10

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

 2,8

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibers, have the GVE component.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with complaints of feeling anxious, irritable, difficulty in concentrating, and worrying excessively over the past 6 months. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of generalized anxiety disorder. Olanzapine is not used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. It is an atypical antipsychotic mainly used in the treatment of schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder. 

Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive worry and anxiety about several activities and events for most days during a 6 month period. The worry is difficult to control and is often associated with somatic symptoms including:

  • Irritability
  • Sleeplessness
  • Restlessness
  • Difficulty in concentrating
  • Muscle tension
  • Fatiguabilty

Management of generalized anxiety disorder: A combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy is effective.

The current first-line drugs, in order of preference, are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), and pregabalin. Psychotherapy comprising cognitive-behavioral therapy, insight-oriented therapy, and supportive therapy are offered along with the medication.

Other options: 

Option B - SSRIs such as sertraline can be used for generalized anxiety disorder, especially in the presence of comorbid depression. Sertraline, citalopram, or paroxetine are usually prescribed. 

Option C - Buspirone is a second-line drug used in generalized anxiety disorder. It takes around 2-3 weeks for its actions to become evident. Hence, it is usually started with a benzodiazepine which is then tapered. 

Option D - Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam are usually prescribed on an as-needed basis so that patients can take them when they're feeling particularly anxious. They are not part of first-line management and should be used on a short-term basis only.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain

  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

questions.text: Sathish, your gym partner and father of a 12-month-old child, calls you for a teleconsult. His child has been passing loose watery stools without fever. He wants to know the medications to be given to his child. What dose of oral zinc would you prescribe to this child?
questions.solution:
All children older than 6 months of age with acute diarrhoea should receive oral zinc (20 mg/day) for 10-14 days during and after diarrhoea.

Most of the cases of under-five acute diarrhoea are infectious in aetiology with more than 50% due to the Rotavirus, which is self-limiting. Treatment will include fluid and electrolyte correction and zinc supplementation.

questions.text: A young boy who is a known case of Klinefelter's syndrome presents with a painless scrotal swelling and precocious puberty. After an initial ultrasound that revealed a testicular mass, surgical removal was done. The specimen was sent for histopathological analysis; the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the biopsy findings points towards the diagnosis of a Leydig cell tumor.

Development of a painless testicular mass in a child with a history of Kleinfelter's syndrome and precocious puberty is suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumor like Leydig cell tumor. The biopsy shows large polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm. The cytoplasm also shows rod-shaped crystals referred to as "crystalloids of Reinke" which confirms the diagnosis.

Leydig cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and in some cases estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. Leydig-cell tumors are associated with:

  • Kleinfelter's syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma syndrome caused by germline mutations in the enzyme fumarate hydratase.

It appears as a homogenous golden-brown tumor, that is usually less than 5cm. On microscopy, round or polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm are seen. In about 25% of the patients, the cytoplasm contains crystalloids of Reinke as shown below:


Other options:

Option B - Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome. On microscopy, tumor cells are arranged in trabaculae to form cord-like structures and tubules as shown below:


Option C - Yolk-sac tumor is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor of the testis also known as endodermal sinus tumor. They secrete α-fetoprotein. On microscopy, a typical lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, is seen. In half the cases, a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells is present known as Schiller-Duval bodies as shown below:


Option D - Seminoma testis is the most common germ cell tumor. They present as large bulky tumors, without any hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopy, seminoma cells are round to polyhedral and have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm, and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli as shown below:

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of neurofibromatosis 1(NF-1) presents with a slow-growing mass over the chest and abdomen. Biopsy from the mass shows the characteristic "divergent differentiation".  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST)

Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) is a high-grade tumor, that occurs commonly in patients with neurofibromatosis 1(NF-1). Most cases of MPNST arise from preexisting plexiform neurofibromas. They are associated with large peripheral nerves over the chest, abdomen, pelvis, neck, or limb-girdle. MPNSTs are the most common cause of death in NF-1.

They present as ill-defined masses that infiltrate along the axis of the parent nerve and invade adjacent soft tissues. They appear as a 'bag of worms ' as they arise from plexiform neurofibromas. On biopsy, a phenomenon called “divergent differentiation” is seen, which refers to the presence of focal areas that exhibit other lines of differentiation, including glandular, cartilaginous, osseous, or rhabdomyoblastic morphology. Typical cases show the fasciculated arrangement of spindle cells with mitoses, necrosis, and nuclear anaplasia. A separate entity containing only the rhabdomyoblastic component is known as a Triton tumor.

The only definitive treatment of MPNST is surgical resection with wide negative margins. 

Other options:

Option B - Plexiform neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors arising from Schwann cells. They develop in deep or superficial locations in association with large nerves or nerve roots and are uniformly NF1-associated. On biopsy, expanded nerve fascicles due to infiltrating tumor cells are seen. At higher resolution, bland spindle cells admixed with wavy collagen bundles are seen similar to "shredded carrot" as shown below.

Option C - Schwannomas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors arising from Schwann cells. They are associated with neurofibromatosis 2(NF-2). They present as compression symptoms of the underlying structure. Schwannomas at the cerebellopontine angles compress the 8th cranial nerve and present as tinnitus and hearing loss. On biopsy, dense eosinophilic areas called Antoni A, hypocellular areas with myxoid extracellular matrix known as Antoni B, and palisading row of nuclei with anuclear zones known as Verrocay bodies as shown below.

Option D - Undifferentiated sarcoma varies from MPNST due to the absence of development from a pre-existing plexiform adenoma, and the absence of histological phenomenon of divergent differentiation. An undifferentiated sarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that does not have any distinctive histological features. They form in muscles and have an aggressive course.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with left hip pain and an inability to walk after a slip and fall at home 5 days ago. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. Her X-ray is given below.  Which of the following is appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an elderly female with a history of trivial injury, shortened, externally rotated lower limb, and X-ray showing a transverse break in the neck of the femur is suggestive of a fracture of the neck of the femur. In the above scenario, since the age is less than 60 and the duration of injury less than 3 weeks, the appropriate treatment is an internal screw fixation.

In fracture neck of femur, internal fixation is performed with a minimum of 3 cannulated screws. 

Fracture neck of femur is more often seen in fifth to the sixth decade of life and generally occurs after trivial trauma. Examination of the affected limb will reveal external rotation, shortening of the limb, groin tenderness, pain with movement, and no active straight leg raising. 

Treatment of fracture neck of femur depends on the age of the patient and duration of the injury.

In undisplaced fracture, fixation is performed with multiple screws. In a displaced fracture:

  • For people less than age 60 years of age, internal fixation with multiple screws is performed
  • For people greater than 60 years of age, having a:
    • Hip with pre-existing arthritis, a total hip replacement is done
    • Normal hip, a hemiarthroplasty is performed

McMurray's osteotomy is an old procedure used to fix fractures of the neck of the femur, where an oblique osteotomy was performed at the intertrochanteric area. This converts the forces at the fracture site into compressive forces to enhance union. 

 

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

CN V - Cranial nerve V

choices.text: Most common site of origin is the fossa of Rosenmuller
CN V involvement leads to reduced corneal reflex
Hearing loss is the most common presentation
Tumor can invade the orbit and cause exophthalmos

questions.solution:
The statement ‘hearing loss is the most common presentation’ is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

The most common presenting symptom is cervical lymphadenopathy, occurring in 60-90% of cases. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types -

  1. Keratinizing carcinoma
  2. Nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma
  3. Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller (Option A). From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to invasion of levator palatini muscles may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia, the most common cranial nerve involved
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex (Option B)
    • CN II - exophthalmos (Option D)
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Diagnosis is made by high resolution, contrast-enhanced CT of the neck.

The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Stage I and II can be treated with radiotherapy alone, while higher stages require combination treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient who is known to have polycystic ovarian syndrome comes with complaints of excessive facial hair as shown below. Which of the following is an androgen receptor antagonist that can be used in the treatment of this symptom?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing excessive facial hair are suggestive of hirsutism. Among the above options, flutamide can be used to manage hirsutism.

However, the use of flutamide should be made with caution as it can cause hepatotoxicity (not commonly used for cosmetic purposes). 

Flutamide is a non-steroidal androgen receptor antagonist used in the treatment of prostatic cancer and in female hirsutism. Other anti-androgens like bicalutamide, nilutamide, and enzalutamide are mainly used with a GnRH analog (such as leuprolide) in managing metastatic prostate cancer. They cannot be used alone in prostate cancer because they increase LH secretion which further causes an increase in serum testosterone secretion. 

Hirsutism is an increased male pattern of hair growth in women of the reproductive age group. It can occur as a benign condition or can be a part of overt virilization caused by excessive androgen production (due to ovarian/adrenal tumors). Other specific causes include PCOS, Cushing's syndrome, etc. Initial therapy is usually with a combination of oral contraceptive pills and, if patients fail to respond, can be changed to anti-androgens like spironolactone, cyproterone acetate, finasteride, and flutamide. Finasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor that also reduces prostate size.

Other options:

Option A - Nilutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used to treat prostate cancer. It is not used in the management of hyperandrogenic states like hirsutism and acne.

Option C- Dutasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D- Letrozole is a non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of breast cancer.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was rushed to the emergency room with symptoms of dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, and confusion. His attenders reported a history of him consuming an unknown plant. On examination, his pulse rate was 170 beats/min, and he had warm and dry skin. Pupils were dilated. Which of the following can be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Physostigmine can be used in the management of this patient.

The above clinical scenario of dryness of mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, confusion, tachycardia, warm and dry skin, and dilated pupils are suggestive of poisoning with an atropine-containing plant.

The adverse effects of atropine are due to the antimuscarinic effects. Below is an image of a mnemonic to remember the symptoms of atropine overdose.

Treatment of atropine intoxication includes a short-acting barbiturate or diazepam to control convulsions. Physostigmine is used as an antidote in atropine poisoning to treat delirium and coma. Other symptomatic management measures like respiratory support and control of hyperthermia are done.

Option B: Atropine is the causative toxic agent in the above scenario. It is used in the management of organophosphate poisoning.

Option C: Hyoscine is also a muscarinic receptor antagonist. It is used in the prevention of motion sickness.

Option D: Pralidoxime is the cholinesterase regenerator compound due to the presence of the oxime group present in this. It is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning.

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of facial puffiness, frothy urine, and hypertension. She gives a history of infection with Hepatitis B. Urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria. Given below is the histological image of the kidney biopsy. Which of the following statements is false with regard to this condition?

PLA2R - Phospholipase A2 receptor

choices.text: Spike and dome pattern on silver stain

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy findings is suggestive of the diagnosis as secondary membranous nephropathy. This condition is not commonly associated with the presence of PLA2R (phospholipase A2 receptor) autoantibodies.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It occurs commonly in men aged between 30-50 years.  It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary (biopsy image) and sub-epithelial deposits of immune complexes. 

The majority of cases of membranous nephropathy(MN) are idiopathic/primary occurring due to the autoantibodies against the renal antigen phospholipase A2 receptor. PLA2R is a transmembrane glycoprotein receptor on the surface of podocytes. These autoantibodies are absent in secondary membranous nephropathy. The various conditions leading to secondary membranous nephropathy are:

  • Drugs: Captopril, NSAIDs, infliximab, penicillamine, etc
  • Infections: Hepatitis B and C, syphilis, tuberculosis, CMV infections, EBV infections, malaria, and streptococcal infections
  • Malignancy of breast, lung, colon, ovaries, neuroblastoma, etc.
  • Autoimmune diseases like SLE, Sjorgen syndrome, sarcoidosis, primary biliary cirrhosis, etc.
  • Sickle cell disease

As in this case, there is a history of hepatitis B infection, the likely etiology is secondary membranous nephropathy. Hence PLA2R autoantibodies are absent. 

Patients present with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, nonselective proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria. Membranous nephropathy has the highest reported incidences of renal vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and deep-vein thrombosis. 

Diagnosis:

  • Light microscopy show diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes and dome pattern on silver staining.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy shows granular deposits containing IgG and complement along the glomerular basement membrane. IgG4 is the principal immunoglobulin deposited in most cases of primary membranous nephropathy.
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes
Management is primarily by administration of immunosuppressive drugs such as steroids, cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, mycophenolate mofetil, etc.
 
Image: The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of the basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. As disease progresses, these spikes thickens to form dome like protrusions. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops. 

Above image shows electron microscopy image showing subepithelial deposits in the kidney

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has been depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a filamentous virus, hence, it is most likely to be the Ebola virus. 

Option A: Corona virus has petal/club-shaped peplomers radiating like sunrays.

 

Option B: Adenovirus is space-vehicle shaped.

 

Option D: Rabies virus is bullet shaped.
