questions.text: A patient presented with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia. She also developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of the onset of these symptoms as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia, and nose hyperpigmentation (chik sign) points towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. 

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus, spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever, arthralgia, and myalgia with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the serum with ELISA or RTPCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Hyperpigmentation of the centrofacial face (nose and cheeks) mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if proper history is not taken. Melasma is hyperpigmented macules of the face that increase after sun exposure. 

The following image shows the hyperpigmentation of the face seen in melasma.

Option B- Melanocytic papillomatous nevi are acquired dermal nevi that are very common. They protrude from the skin surface and may be pigmented or skin-colored. Upon histological examination, they exhibit nevus cell nests in the dermis. Therapy consists of excision, shave excision, or laser therapy. 

Option C- Actinic keratosis is a pre-malignant lesion that consists of crusty, scaly patches of skin. It is associated with UV light exposure and is therefore associated with solar damage to the surrounding skin. 

The following image shows the scaly patches of skin suggestive of actinic keratosis of the scalp.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about cadaveric rigidity in contrast to cadaveric spasm?
  1. It is due to the depletion of ATP
  2. Muscles respond to electrical stimuli
  3. It happens instantaneously after death
  4. It is an antemortem phenomenon
  5. It indicates time since death
questions.solution:
Cadaveric rigidity is also known as rigor mortis. It is due to the depletion of ATP and indicates time since death. Muscle stiffening is not marked and can be overcome by moderate force. The rigor starts occurring 1-2 hours after death (postmortem nature) and muscles do not respond to electrical stimuli.

Cadaveric spasm / instantaneous rigor/ cataleptic rigidity/ death clutch is a phenomenon where a group of muscles in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death until molecular death occurs.

Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem phenomenon and occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like:

  • In cases of excitement, fear, severe pain
  • Exhaustion at the time of death
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Injury to the nervous system
  • Drowning
  • Strychnine poisoning

Examples:

  • In case of drowning, weeds and grass caught in hand during struggle remain firmly grasped even after death. This indicates that the person was alive when entering the water
  • In case of suicides, weapons remain firmly grasped in the hand

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

Trait Cadaveric rigidity Cadaveric spasm
Production Freezing and exposure to a temperature above 650C will produce rigor Cannot be produced by any method after death
Mechanism Reduction of ATP Not clear
Predisposing factors Nil Sudden death, excitement, fear, etc
Time of onset 1 – 2 hours after death Instantaneous
Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline
Medicolegal importance Indicates the time of death Indicates manner of death

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure is frequently associated with:

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibers, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Internal hemorrhoids are located proximal to the dentate line. They present with painless bleeding which is separate from the stool, and with a mass near the anal orifice. Pain is not a common feature and is present if hemorrhoids are prolapsed. 

Option D: External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line; these may engorge, causing pain. Pain is present throughout the day and is not only associated with defecation or rectal examination. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain. 

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient while undergoing hemodialysis, had a sudden drop in blood pressure and complained of leg cramps. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Stop hemodialysis and check arterial blood gases
Discontinue ultrafiltration and start saline infusion
Continue hemodialysis and send blood for serum electrolytes
Check serum K+ and arterial blood gases

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypotension which is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The treatment includes the infusion of saline.

Hypotension occurs due to hypovolemia, caused by excessive removal of fluids. Hypotension can be prevented by careful evaluation of the dry weight and by ultrafiltration modeling, such that more fluid is removed at the beginning rather than the end of the dialysis session. Removal of excess fluid may also cause muscle cramps due to a decrease in muscle perfusion.

Factors causing hypotension during hemodialysis are:

  • Excessive ultrafiltration with inadequate compensatory vascular filling
  • Impaired vasoactive or autonomic responses
  • Osmolar shifts
  • Excessive use of antihypertensive agents
  • Reduced cardiac reserve

The management includes discontinuing ultrafiltration, the administration of 100–250 mL of isotonic saline, or administration of salt-poor albumin.

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis
Comparatively difficult access Easy access
Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Must be done in hospital Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: A pediatrician referred a newborn with the given deformity to the orthopedics department. Which of the following is the true order of correction according to Ponseti's method?
questions.solution:
The given image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) or clubfoot. The order of correction according to Ponseti's method is cavus-adduction-varus-equinus (CAVE).

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are:

  • Cavus - this deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint
  • Adduction - this deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint
  • Inversion - occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus - this deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints

Ponseti's method is a successful method of manipulation in CTEV. It should begin as early as the first 2 weeks after birth. Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with help of plaster casts. 

To begin with, the first metatarsal is elevated to correct the cavus. This creates a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot. Then, the forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals. This everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination. Finally, the equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. In most cases, a percutaneous Achilles' tenotomy is required later for complete correction of the equinus deformity.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 Antibodies against leptospirosis appear in the blood 5-7 days after infection. Serotype-specific tests for leptospirosis includes:  

  • Microscopic agglutination test 
  • Macroscopic agglutination test  

Other options: 

Option A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid fever

Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  

Option D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A child with congenital thrombocytopenia presents with eczema and recurrent infections. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the WASP gene. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: It is an X-linked recessive disorder
High levels of IgM are found in the serum
The definitive treatment is stem cell transplantation
There is an increased risk of lymphoreticular malignancies

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wiskott Aldrich syndrome. Here, serum IgM levels are low, but IgG levels are usually normal, and these are associated with increased levels of IgA and IgE.

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive immunodeficiency. The WASP gene on Xp11.23 encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein, which plays a crucial role in cytoskeletal organization in lymphocytes and platelets. This primarily affects platelets, lymphocytes, and the immune system, leading to:

  • Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count with small-sized platelets).
  • Eczema, often resembling atopic dermatitis.
  • Recurrent infections due to both B-cell and T-cell dysfunction.

Immunoglobulin abnormalities in WAS (due to T-cell dysfunction leading to defective B-cell activation and class switching, impairing IgM production while allowing IgA and IgE to be upregulated) include:

  • Low IgM results from defective B-cell signaling and impaired class switching.
  • Normal IgG levels.
  • Elevated IgA and IgE levels contribute to the eczema and allergic diathesis seen in these patients.

These abnormalities increase the patient's susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections, such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. They also increase the risk of lymphoreticular malignancies. 

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only definitive management of this condition. Supportive care includes IVIG therapy, prophylactic antibiotics, and platelet transfusions in severe thrombocytopenia. 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A young man developed hyponatremia following transurethral resection of prostate (TURP). He was then started on intravenous medication to treat acute hyponatremia. After 30 minutes, he suddenly developed spastic quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, and diplopia. The MRI of his brain is shown below. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows the face of piglet sign seen in osmotic demyelination syndrome which is due to rapid correction of hyponatremia by vaptans. The only FDA-approved vaptan (Vasopressin receptor antagonist) for parenteral administration and treatment of hyponatremia is conivaptan. 

Osmotic demyelination syndrome:

Rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells. It is characterized by the acute onset of quadriparesis, pseudobulbar palsy, coma, and death. 

Rapid correction of hyponatremia by more than 8-10 mmol in 24 hours or 18 mmol in 48 hours results in the development of osmotic demyelination syndrome. 

Hyponatremia:

Hyponatremia is a condition characterized by serum sodium levels < 135 mEq/ L. Hyponatremia could be euvolemic, hypovolemic, or hypervolemic. 

Hypovolemic hyponatremia:

  • Renal losses:
  • Diuretic toxicity
  • Salt-losing syndromes
  • Bicarbonaturia

Extra-renal losses:

  • Burns
  • Pancreatitis
  • Trauma
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Fluid collection in third spaces

Hypervolemic hyponatremia:

  • Renal failure
  • Cardiac failure
  • Liver failure

Euvolemic hyponatremia:

  • Glucorticoid deficiency
  • SIADH
  • Thyroid disorders 
  • Stress

Causes of acute hyponatremia:

  • TURP
  • Colonoscopy
  • Glycine irrigation
  • Vasopressin 
  • Thiazide diuretic
  • Ecstacy or molly ingestion

Treatment of acute hyponatremia:

  • Fluid restriction
  • Injection furosemide or oral tablets in combination with oral salt tablets. Furosemide inhibits the renal countercurrent mechanism and blunt urinary concentrating ability, whereas the salt tablets counteract diuretic-associated natriuresis.
  • Demeclocycline - inhibits principal cells
  • AVP antagonists- (oral) tolvaptan and (parenteral) conivaptan.
  • Hypertonic (3%) sodium chloride infusion.

The vaptans are a group of drugs commonly used for the treatment of SIADH and act as antagonists for the vasopressin receptor. Their site of action and common side effects are as follows:

Drug Receptor Adverse events
Conivaptan Non-selective blocker Injection site pain
Tolvaptan V2 blocker Hepatotoxicity

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

Infections

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Meningitis, Encephalitis
  • AIDS

Vascular

  • Cerebrovascular occlusions, haemorrhage
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Neurologic

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Delirium tremens
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Congenital malformations

Metabolic

  • Acute intermittent porphyria

Respiratory

  • Asthma
  • Pneumothorax
  • Positive-pressure respiration

Drugs

  • Vasopressin or desmopressin
  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors
  • Oxytocin (high dose)
  • Vincristine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Nicotine
  • Phenothiazines
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors

questions.text: The MRI of a woman presenting with recurrent headaches is given below. Microscopy of the resected tumor shows psammoma bodies and the tumor cells express progesterone receptors. Which of the following is the most common cytogenetic abnormality noted in this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given MRI showing homogeneously enhancing extra - axial, dural based tumor and the microscopic findings are highly suggestive of meningioma. The most common cytogenetic abnormality in meningioma is 22q deletion.

Meningioma is predominantly a benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura. It arises from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. 50% - 60% of the sporadic meningioma harbors mutations in the NF2 gene (in chromosome 22q12) resulting in the absence of functional merlin protein. In meningioma without NF2 mutations, the most common mutations occur in TNF­ receptor - associated factor 7 (TRAF7).

questions.text: A 39-year-old morbidly-obese female patient presented with deranged liver function test. Ultrasound showed a grade 2 fatty liver with hepatic fibrosis and inflammation. She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive, and has no history of smoking or drinking. A diagnosis of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has been made. Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is considered the first-line treatment for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated, showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-Asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Most of the patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work. Some patients with NASH can present with right upper quadrant pain due to stretching of the liver capsule from hepatomegaly, or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance or with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis. Currently, a biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia). Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Other options:

Option A- Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Option C- Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH as it has not been known to improve liver histology.

Option D- N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via the oral or intravenous route.

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. You notice that the senior resident uses the trauma scoring system which involves the energy of the injury as one of the components. Which of the following trauma scoring systems is being used here?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the mangled extremity severity score involves the energy of the injury as one of the components. 

Components of mangled extremity severity score :

  • The energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

 Note: A score of 7 or higher predicts the need for amputation.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with myopia at 10 years of age came for an opinion on LASIK surgery. On routine preoperative assessment, the estimated residual stromal bed was calculated to be 200 μm, and surgery was deferred. Which of the following anticipated complications made the surgeon take such a decision?
questions.solution:
LASIK, when performed in this patient, would predispose him to ectasia of the cornea (keratectasia) because of the inadequate residual stromal bed thickness.

Because LASIK is a procedure involving the ablation of stroma, a preoperative calculation of the residual stromal bed thickness can aid the eye surgeon to predict the postoperative risk for corneal ectasia.

The residual stromal bed thickness can be calculated by subtracting the anticipated flap thickness and maximum ablation depth from the central corneal thickness. A residual stromal bed thickness of 250 to 300 μm is generally recognized as a minimum requirement before LASIK surgery. Hence, the calculation of central corneal thickness is an important element of preoperative evaluation.

Patient selection is of utmost importance in refractive eye surgeries. The following factors must be considered before taking up a patient for refractive eye surgery.

  • Minimum age of 21 years
  • Stable refraction for at least 1 year
  • Measurement of the central corneal thickness ( to calculate the residual stromal bed thickness)
  • A detailed review of ocular and systemic conditions

Limitations and contraindications of LASIK: The following group of patients poses a high risk for laser vision correction, and when done are associated with adverse surgical outcomes.

  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Autoimmune and immunodeficiency diseases
  • Pregnant and nursing mothers
  • Keratoconus
  • Chronic intake of isotretinoin and amiodarone
  • Fuchs corneal dystrophy
  • Ophthalmic herpes simplex and herpes zoster

Other options:

Option A- Punctate epithelial dystrophy (dry eye) is the most frequent complication of LASIK surgery, and the same can be managed with frequent lubrication using artificial tears.

Option B- Flap displacement usually occurs within 24 hours after surgery. Once diagnosed, the flap should be lifted and repositioned as soon as possible.

Option D- The corneal epithelium grows in the interface between the flap and stromal bed. This is termed epithelial ingrowth. If it causes vision disturbances, Nd:YAG laser application is warranted to treat the condition.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with India ink.

The India ink preparation is employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. Direct microscopy of the sample stained by India ink is the most rapid method for the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly colored background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream colored, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

Related Pearl: Types of capsules in microorganisms

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain. On examination, there is tenderness and guarding with an ill-defined mass in the right iliac fossa. A CT scan shows an appendicolith and a complete blood count reveals leucocytosis. The patient improves on conservative treatment. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of appendicular mass. Interval appendectomy is done after the conservative management of an appendicular mass with appendicolith.

Clinically, patients with the appendicular mass present with a mass in the right iliac fossa, fever, abdominal pain, and increased pulse rate. In appendicular mass, the inflammatory process is already localized and any surgical intervention may be difficult and dangerous. 

Hence, if the general condition is satisfactory, the conservative Ochsner–Sherren regimen is used. After conservative management, a CT scan follow-up should be done to check for complete resolution of the mass.

Following successful management of appendicular mass, removal of the appendix is advised by a procedure called interval appendectomy in 6-8 weeks after conservative management. The rationale for interval appendectomy is to prevent recurrent appendicitis and risks associated with emergent appendectomy or perforation of the appendix.

Interval appendectomy is reserved in:

  • Recurrent appendicitis
  • Appendicolith (leads to recurrent appendicitis)
  • Children

Other options:

Option A: Immediate appendectomy after conservative management has an overall higher rate of complications, wound infections, and abdominal/pelvic abscess formation. So it is better to be avoided.

Option C: Percutaneous drainage is to be done when pelvic abscess and appendicular abscess do not resolve with conservative management.

Option D: Appendicolith increases inflammation and leads to recurrent attacks of appendicitis. Hence it is not advisable to wait and watch for its spontaneous resolution.

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient with a previous history of cesarean section presented with 8 weeks of delayed periods, vaginal spotting, and sharp abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed an empty uterine cavity. Based on the findings, identify the most common location of implantation for the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The underlying condition based on the given clinical scenario of a young female with delayed periods, vaginal spotting, and sharp abdominal pain with positive UPT and empty uterine cavity on TVS is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. The most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy is the tubal ampulla. 

Almost 95% of ectopic pregnancies implant within the fallopian tube. Within the fallopian tube, the ampulla is the most commonly affected location in 70% of the cases. The remaining implant is in the isthmus (12%), fimbria (11%), and interstitial tube (2%). 

The other sites of implantations are the ovary (Option A), peritoneal cavity, cervix (Option B), or prior cesarean scar (Option C). 

The classic triad of symptoms for an ectopic pregnancy is delayed menstrual cycle, abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. 

The examination may reveal abdominal tenderness, pain in cervical motion, a bulging posterior vaginal fornix, boggy mass next to the uterus. Vaginal bleeding or spotting may be present. Ruptured ectopic will lead to intraabdominal haemorrhage, leading to reciprocal changes in vital signs. 

Investigations used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy include a positive beta-human chorionic gonadotropin to diagnose a pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound can be used to identify the gestational sac or determine if the case is a pregnancy of an unknown location. In an ectopic pregnancy, the endometrial stripe will appear as a trilaminar pattern and anechoic fluid collections may be present. 

Medical management of ectopic pregnancy involves the use of methotrexate, a folic acid antagonist. Surgical management depends on whether the patient is hemodynamically stable (laparoscopy versus laparotomy) and whether she desires future fertility (salpingectomy versus salpingostomy).

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest and widest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms. 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with headache and nuchal stiffness. The CD4 count is 90 and CSF sample with India-ink staining shows the presence of encapsulated yeast cells. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in CSF with India ink staining are suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis. Amphotericin B plus flucytosine is the treatment of choice for this patient.

Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.

In cryptococcal meningitis, amphotericin B combined with flucytosine is the current gold standard treatment in immunocompromised patients, especially in AIDS patients. 

In non-immunocompetent patients, the role of additional flucytosine along with amphotericin B is less clear. 

Oral fluconazole is used for consolidation and maintenance therapy after two weeks of induction therapy with amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presents with proximal muscle weakness, vomiting, seizures with focal neurological deficits, and altered consciousness. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and CSF protein <1g/L. The muscle biopsy is shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the biopsy findings point towards the diagnosis of mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke (MELAS).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) with a background of blue myofibres. 

MELAS is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to deficiency of complex I (NADH-Q oxidoreductase) or complex IV(cytochrome oxidase). Children usually present with recurrent attacks of a migraine-like headache, anorexia, vomiting, seizures, proximal myopathy, encephalopathy, stroke, altered consciousness, and cardiomyopathy. Children with MELAS are also frequently found to have short stature.

Evaluation includes MRI showing multi-focal infarct-like cortical areas in different stages of ischemic evolution and elevated serum and cerebrospinal fluid lactate levels. CSF protein is increased but is usually ≤1 g/L. Muscle biopsy shows ragged red fibers as described above.

There is no known treatment to stop disease progression. Anti-epileptic medication is used to control seizures. 

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Myoclonus epilepsy is associated with ragged red fibers (MERRF)
  • Leigh’s syndrome
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy(LHON)
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome(KSS)
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia(CPEO)
  • Pearson syndrome

Other options:

Option B- Kearns-Sayre is a rare neuromuscular disorder that may present as a triad of onset before 20 years of age, chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia, and pigmentary retinopathy. In addition to the triad, the patient may have a complete heart block, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein >1g/L, or cerebellar ataxia. Serum creatine kinase and lactate are normal or slightly elevated.

Option C- Becker muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease that causes progressive weakness and wasting of cardiac and skeletal muscles. It is caused due to mutations in the DMD gene coding for dystrophin. Myopathy develops starting from the pelvic and lower limb musculature, progressing to shoulders, upper limb, and the respiratory system. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase. Cardiomyopathy is also seen.

Option D- Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also an X-linked recessive disorder. Children usually present with delayed motor developmental milestones, pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles, cardiomyopathy, and progressive muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother
  • These diseases include: (mnemonic: KLMNOP)

L: Leigh disease

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is suspected to have Fragile X syndrome. He is sent to the psychiatric OPD for a referral. After a psychiatric evaluation, the consultant asks you, an intern, to assess the child's IQ. Which test is the most widely used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The most widely used test of intelligence for school-age children and adolescents is the third edition of the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children

It is applicable for children from 6 to 17 years of age and yields a verbal IQ, a performance IQ, and a combined full-scale IQ.

Verbal subtest categories :

  • Vocabulary
  • Information
  • Arithmetic
  • Similarities
  • Comprehension
  • Digit span (supplemental)

Performance subtest categories :

  • Block design
  • Picture
  • Completion
  • Picture arrangement
  • Object assembly
  • Coding
  • Mazes (supplemental)
  • Symbol search (supplemental)

Scoring :

  • An average full-scale IQ is 100
  • 70 to 80 represents a borderline intellectual function
  • 80 to 90 is in the low average range
  • 90 to 109 is average
  • 110 to 119 is a high average
  • above 120 is in the superior or very superior range

Other options :

Option B - The Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale (2 to 24 years) relies on pictures, drawings, and objects for very young children and on verbal performance for older children and adolescents. It gives a mental age score as well as an intelligence quotient.

Option A and C - The McCarthy Scales of Children's Abilities and the Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children are two other intelligence tests that are available for preschool and school-age children. They do not cover the adolescent age group.

Related Pearl: Intelligence Quotient

  • The intelligence quotient is a score that can be obtained from several standardized tests to assess human intelligence.
  • Historically, IQ = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age
  • Here, the mental age is obtained from intelligence tests.
  • Higher the IQ, the more brilliant is the person.
  • Classification of IQ according to Levine and Marks (1928) is as follows:

questions.text: A female patient with ovarian cancer is started with paclitaxel. Which of the following is false about this class of drugs?

choices.text: Also used in chemotherapy regimen of breast cancer
Glove-stocking sensory neuropathy is an adverse effect.

questions.solution:
Paclitaxel belongs to the class of taxanes. Taxanes promote the polymerization of tubulin protein, stabilize the microtubules and result in mitotic arrest.

Taxanes are cell-cycle-specific cytotoxic drugs. Taxanes bind to the β-tubulin subunit of the microtubules, promote polymerization, and prevent the disassembly of these microtubules that result in M-phase arrest of the cell cycle. Examples of taxanes are paclitaxel, docetaxel, and cabazitaxel.

Resistance to taxanes occurs due to increased expression of efflux proteins. They are used in chemotherapy regimens of metastatic ovarian tumor, breast, lung, gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and head and neck cancers. Paclitaxel is used in the first-generation drug-eluting stent for primary coronary intervention and used as an antiproliferative agent. 

The adverse effects include bone marrow suppression, peripheral glove-stocking sensory neuropathy, hypersensitivity reactions, myalgia, mucositis and fluid retention.

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small, uneducated village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best method to do so?
questions.solution:
A pictogram is the best method of presenting data to people who cannot understand orthodox charts/ uneducated populations. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. Basically, pictograms are a form of bar charts.

The following image shows an example of a pictogram.

Statistical data after collection must be arranged in such a manner so as to bring out the relevant points clearly. Various methods to depict the statistical data include tables, charts, diagrams, graphs, and pictures.

Other options:

Option B: Line diagrams can be used to show the trend of events in a given period of time. 

Option C: A histogram is a pictorial diagram of a frequency distribution that consists of a series of blocks. The frequencies are given along the vertical axis and class intervals on the horizontal axis. The area of each block obtained is proportional to frequency. 

Option D: Frequency polygon is another method to diagrammatically represent frequency distribution. It is obtained by joining the midpoints of the histogram blocks.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text:
A young mother is experiencing tearfulness and mood swings 5 days after her baby was born. She is suspected to have postpartum blues. All are true regarding this condition except?

DSM-5: Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition

choices.text: Occurs due to hormonal changes after childbirth
Evaluate for postpartum depression if symptoms last >2 weeks
Main treatment is support and education
Subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5

questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is not a subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5 (Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition). 

Postpartum blues is a common condition seen in mothers during the puerperal period. It is characterized by transient mood disturbances like a labile mood, sadness, and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels and the stress of childbirth. The anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood is also a contributory factor. Education and support form the mainstay of management. However, symptoms lasting longer than 2 weeks should be evaluated for postpartum depression.

Postpartum depression is marked by a depressed mood, excessive anxiety, insomnia, and weight changes usually within the 4-6 weeks of delivery. There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby, which is not present in postpartum blues. It is a subtype of major depressive disorder in DSM-5.

Postpartum psychosis or puerperal psychosis is a psychotic disorder that may occur in women after delivery. It is listed as a subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5. The condition is characterized by depression, delusions, and thoughts of harming either herself or her infant. Suicidal ideation or infanticidal thoughts should be carefully monitored. The mean time of onset is usually within the first 2-3 weeks following delivery. Subsequent pregnancies are associ­ated with an increased risk of a second episode.

 

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated blood uric acid levels, and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch 
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Allopurinol should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Hers disease (GSD VI). Patients usually present in early childhood with hepatomegaly and growth retardation. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.

Option B: Phosphorylase kinase deficiency leads to Type IX GSD. Phosphorylase kinase is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. It presents in the first 2 years of life with short stature and hepatomegaly. Unlike GSD I, lactic acidosis, bleeding tendency, and loose bowel movements are not characteristic.

Option C: Liver glycogen synthase deficiency leads to Type 0 GSD. It presents in infancy with early-morning drowsiness, pallor, vomiting, fatigue, and sometimes convulsions. Hypoglycemia, hyperketonemia, and low lactate levels are seen. There is no hyperlipidemia or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Contraceptive failure occurs in a 32-year-old woman who is taking an oral contraceptive pill (OCP) and tetracycline simultaneously. What is the mechanism causing OCP failure in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracyclines suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen, leading to a lowering of plasma estrogen levels and resulting in contraceptive failure.

Enzyme inhibitors like verapamil, fluconazole, erythromycins inhibit the degradation of OCPs. OCPs thus have a longer duration of action and less incidence of contraceptive failure with these.

However, most other antiepileptic drugs are enzyme inducers, causing increased degradation of OCPs and hence leading to contraceptive failure. Eg: carbamazepine, phenytoin, efavirenz, primidone, nevirapine, rifampicin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was diagnosed with monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance(MGUS). Which of the following statement is false with regard to this condition?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow clone cells >10% is a false statement regarding monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance(MGUS).

MGUS is a clinicopathological variant of plasma cell disorders. It is the most common plasma cell disorder. It is commonly seen among the elderly.

The diagnostic criteria for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) are:

  • Non-IgM type serum monoclonal protein <30 g/L 
  • Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow <10%.
  • The absence of amyloidosis or myeloma-defining events such as hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and lytic bone lesions.

The three distinct clinical types of MGUS are:

  • Non-IgM MGUS
  • IgM MGUS
  • Light chain MGUS (LC-MGUS)

The most prevalent non-IgM MGUS are IgG > IgA > bi-clonal > IgD.

Patients with MGUS are usually asymptomatic. MGUS is a premalignant condition with approximately 1% of patients with MGUS developing asymptomatic plasma cell neoplasm, usually multiple myeloma. A non-IgG subtype, abnormal lambda/kappa free light chain ratio, and serum M protein >15 g/L (1.5 g/dL) are associated with a higher incidence of progression of MGUS to myeloma.

Treatment is generally not recommended for patients with MGUS and periodic follow-up is advised as there is a risk of progression to lymphoproliferative malignancy.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants
A. PLASMA CELL NEOPLASMS
 Multiple myeloma (previously plasma cell myeloma)
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 3g/dL and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L
Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone
Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes
  • TEMPI syndrome 
  • AESOP syndrome
B. MONOCLONAL IMMUNOGLOBULIN DEPOSITION DISEASES 
Immunoglobulin-related (AL) amyloidosis (previously primary amyloidosis)
  • Systemic AL amyloidosis
  • Localised AL amyloidosis
  • Heavy chain amyloidosis
Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition disease (previously light and heavy chain deposition disease)
  • Light chain deposition disease
  • Heavy chain deposition disease
  • Light and heavy chain deposition disease
C. MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHIES
  • Cold agglutinin disease
  • Monoclonal gammopathy of renal significance
  • IgM and non-IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined signifcance

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the structure of a skeletal muscle sarcomere. He takes a cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow in the image below. What will he find?
questions.solution:
The cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow marks the A band. It consists of myosin surrounded by actin. 

Sarcomere is the area between two dark Z-lines. It is composed of thick filaments like myosin and thin filaments like actin, tropomyosin, troponin. 

The difference in the refractive index of various muscle fibers leads to cross-striations when viewed under a microscope. The various levels of section of the sarcomere and the myofilaments they are composed of are as follows: 

Sections Myofilaments
I band Only actin
A band (exculding H zone) Actin and myosin
AI junction Actin and myosin
H zone Only myosin
M line Thick filament linked with accessory proteins

Note: Pseudo-H zone is referred to the lighter areas around the M-line including the M-line.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with lethargy, constipation, and weight gain, with a poor appetite for a few months. The thyroid profile revealed a high thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and low free T4 levels. Which of the following features will most likely be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Increase in blood flow to skin

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with elevated TSH level and low level of free T4 is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Among the given options, a reduction in stroke volume is the feature most likely to be seen in hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism leads to a decrease in myocardial contractility and pulse rate, resulting in reduced stroke volume and bradycardia.

Enzymes involved in regulating calcium fluxes in the heart are controlled by thyroid hormones, including the calcium-dependent adenosine triphosphate and phospholamban.

In hypothyroidism, the expression and activity of these enzymes decrease so that it could potentially impair systolic performance and diastolic relaxation.

Expression of the beta-adrenergic receptor is also decreased in hypothyroidism, resulting in a reduced response to a catecholamines-mediated increase in inotropy. 

The thyroid hormone relaxes the vascular smooth muscle and reduces peripheral vascular resistance. Conversely in hypothyroidism, the release of endothelial-derived relaxing factors is decreased causing a contraction of smooth muscle and, thereby, an increase in peripheral vascular resistance (option A) leading to hypertension. 

This change causes a reduction in stroke volume and tissue perfusion. This leads to an inflow of blood away from the skin (option C) and results in cold extremities.  

Pericardial effusion occurs almost in 30% of cases with hypothyroidism (Option B). In hypothyroidism, the permeability of the epicardial vessels will increase and lymphatic drainage of albumin will decrease. This results in the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space.

Patients with hypothyroidism often present with tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, poor memory, constipation, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination, they may have cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, bradycardia, and peripheral edema.

In primary hypothyroidism, TSH will be elevated and free T4 is low.

Patients with hypothyroidism who have no evidence of heart disease are managed with levothyroxine 50 to 100 mcg daily. The goal of the treatment is to maintain TSH in the lower half of the reference range.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a painless swelling and watering in his left eye for a few weeks. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding his diagnosis?

choices.text: Most commonly seen in upper eyelid

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of chronic painless swelling and watering of eyes along with the image showing a reddish nodule in the lid is suggestive of chalazion. Infection of chalazion leads to hordeolum internum. 

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst.

They are most commonly seen in the upper eyelid than the lower eyelid because the upper eyelid has more meibomian glands. 

Histopathology shows a lipogranulomatous picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells.

Most of the patients present with gradually enlarging painless rounded nodules, watering of the eyes, blurring of vision, and blepharitis. Rosacea is associated with multiple and recurrent chalazia. 

A recurrent chalazion should be biopsied to exclude malignant transformation. In elderly patients, malignant transformation to meibomian gland adenocarcinoma can be occasionally. 

Complete spontaneous resolution occurs rarely. Oral antibiotics are only required for lesions with significant bacterial infections. Daily hot compression can help in the resolution of early lesions. 

Treatment includes incision and curettage, which is conventional and effective.

Intralesional injection of steroid into and around the lesions give a similar resolution to incision and curettage.

Other options:

External hordeolum is also known as stye, is an acute suppurative inflammation of the lash follicle. It is a painful condition, with swelling of the eyelids, photophobia, and mild watering. Given below is an image of the external hordeolum.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of floaters and blurring of vision of both eyes for a few weeks.  Fundoscopic examination shows inferior snow banking.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young female presenting with floaters, blurring of vision, and fundoscopy showing snow banking is suggestive of intermediate uveitis or pars planitis

Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation involving pars plana ciliaris, peripheral retina, choroid, and vitreous base. It is predominantly seen in young females and most often presents with floaters and bilateral blurring of vision.

Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis. This occurs due to the coalescence of snowball opacities.

Other Signs of intermediate uveitis:

  • Snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities)- typical exudates present near the ora Serrata in the inferior quadrant
  • Few keratic precipitates (KP) due to spillover anterior uveitis

Intermediate uveitis is managed  by the Kaplan 4-step protocol:

  • Periocular steroid- Sub tenon injection of triamcinolone acetate
  • Systemic steroid
  • Cryotherapy in cases with a snow banking
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis or iridocyclitis is the inflammation of tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. It is the most common form of uveitis. They present with:

  • Circumcorneal conjunctival hyperemia
  • Aqueous flare is the haziness of the clear fluid in the anterior chamber due to leakage of protein from the damaged blood-aqueous barrier
  • Keratin precipitates (KPs) are present in the inferior part of the anterior chamber. They are composed of inflammatory cells. They often appear in a triangular pattern with the apex pointing up under the influence of gravity called the Arlt triangle
  • Posterior synechiae occur due to the inflammatory adhesions between the pupil margin and the anterior lens capsule

Option C: Posterior uveitis is the inflammation of the choroid with or without inflammation of the retina. They are classified as:

  • Choroiditis comprises inflammation of the choroid and it can be focal, multifocal, or diffuse 
  • Chorioretinitis comprises inflammation of the choroid and overlying retina.
  • Retinochoroditis comprises of inflammation of the retina and overlying choroid
  • Neuroretinitis comprises inflammation of the retina and optic nerve head.

Option D: Fuchs' uveitis or Fuchs heterochromatic iridocyclitis is a chronic non-granulomatous condition. They are usually unilateral. A difference in color between the iris of both eyes termed heterochromia iridis is characteristically seen here. Posterior synechiae are absent. A characteristic stellate-shaped keratic precipitates are located diffusely over the entire corneal epithelium.

Related Pearl: Different types of keratic precipitates (KPs)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with complaints of severe itching every time he takes a hot shower for the past few months. He also reports a burning sensation in his fingers and frequent headaches. His hemoglobin is 18 g/dL and his erythropoietin levels are low. Which of the following cannot be used in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera and nitrosourea is not used in the treatment of polycythemia vera. 

Alkylating agents like nitrosourea are leukemogenic in polycythemia vera and its contraindicated. 

Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation on Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. 

Polycythemia shows a slight predominance in males. Most of the cases are incidental findings with high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis. Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera. 

Digital ischemia, easy bruising, or gastrointestinal bleeding can occur due to thrombocytosis or vascular stasis.

Treatment: Phlebotomy serves initially to reduce the hyperviscosity by reducing the red cell mass. Ruxolitinib, hydroxyurea, pegylated interferon alpha are used for pruritis intractable to the antihistamine.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

Related Pearl: Pathophysiologic Classification of Polycythemia

Pathophysiological classification of polycythemia

Primary (Low Erythropoietin)
Polycythemia vera
Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations (rare)
Secondary (High Erythropoietin)
Compensatory
  • Lung disease
  • High-altitude living
  • Cyanotic heart disease
Paraneoplastic
  • Erythropoietin-secreting tumors (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioblastoma)

Hemoglobin mutants with high O2 affinity

Inherited defects that stabilize HIF-1α

  • Chuvash polycythemia (homozygous VHL mutations)
  • Prolyl hydroxylase mutations
